title: My journey to acoustic
post_content: Hi allIve been on the forum for a bit, those who have read my posts will know me as a bit of a detail geek. Ive gone through several boards before I worked my way up to the magnificent Stage 3. Like many I chased that perfect piano sound and as far as digital instruments go the Nord is about as close as that gets for me.So .... a little story that is long overdue but which I am excited to share...A few months ago I was early to meet someone and decided to pass time by swinging into our local piano dealer (acoustic pianos only both new/used). Usually the place is full of old junk and a few nice Yamaha and Kawai grands that are out of my budget. I played a couple of uprights and as I was working my way around tucked away in the corner I spotted a shiny black baby grand which caught my eye. A second hand Young Chang G157 with a price tag at roughly the price of a Nord Stage 3So I sat to have a go not expecting much of it, and it simply blew me away. The action was so light and responsive, allowing so much expression. The sound filled the room and just sustained and resonated for what seemed like forever and I looked at my 10 year old daughter in amazement as her face beamed and we both went... WOW!! It sounds amazing. I just couldn't stop playing it, and walking around it. I played a Yamaha G5 next to it that was Much more expensive, then a Kawai GL30, again 5x the price. Back to the Young Chang and by far I preferred it, it just had something special about it.We went home thinking about it more and more. I couldnt strictly afford to just buy it, but never have I wanted an instrument so much. Truth be told, I havent been doing much live work recently due to other commitments and I was starting to feel sorry for my Stage 3 seeing little stage action. I toyed with selling it to buy this grand that knocked my socks off, but I CANT, I CANT sell my Stage 3.Anyway we called by again, and played it again, which was a bad mistake as it just made me want it moreA month later and a third visit, and the Stage 3 had been advertised for sale, and a deposit left. It had won me over and the Grand was coming home with me before someone else bought it.So we have had her since April and I really dont know how I have not bought an acoustic piano much much sooner. I play it every day and just love it to bits, it just connects with me on a whole new level and the best part about it, it didn't have to come at the highest price in the shop. Its taught me that as good as digital sounds can be, chasing a great piano sound doesnt have to mean you need the newest of digital kit, and your musical heart could well be sitting in your used piano dealer somewhere nearIt has even been given a name (Eleanor) thanks to my 10 year oldAnd here it is.My daughter loves it tooAnd a final note, the Stage 3 sale fell through so decided to keep it anyway(bank manager not happy! )Thanks for reading folks

title: RE: My journey to acoustic

title: RE: My journey to acoustic
post_content: Congrats for your new piano. Good choice.Before buying my upright, I tested a lot of grand and upright pianos. I tested some Young Chang models and they were surprisingly great comparing to the price.Electronic and acoustic instrument are for me complementary. This is not the same use.I own an old 30yo Seiler Upright which works perfectly (one tuning by year is enough) and I recently switch my Roland RD-300GX to NS3. I mainly use the NS3, because I can play when I want without making noise in the house: in fact, I mainly play after my daughter goes to bed. And I obvisouly cannot take my upright to play with my band and I can use a lot more sounds with the NS3.Nothing can replace playing with an acoustic piano. Electronic boards can only mimic piano on a record or through PA, but cannot mimics all the range of sound variations an acoustic piano can produce.An acoustic piano doesn't only produce sounds, but there is also an interaction between the piano and the player.

title: RE: My journey to acoustic
post_content: Wow thanks for the comments everyonetoniolito wrote:Nothing can replace playing with an acoustic piano. Electronic boards can only mimic piano on a record or through PA, but cannot mimics all the range of sound variations an acoustic piano can produce.An acoustic piano doesn't only produce sounds, but there is also an interaction between the piano and the player.I think this describes it well. The acoustic has no sample recording constraints, no limits to velocity layers, no min max dynamic ranges, no amplification or speaker barriers, just pure raw sound.

I do this maybe 3-4 times a day.  I think there's an inventory of 40+ songs/patterns I play.  More would be good, but I still work for a living.Right now, I'm in my summer place with a Yamaha AvantGrand N3.  Super stiff action, it's like going to the gym.  Sonically, it's a blast as it's always in perfect tune, well amplified, etc.  It has a volume control, which is helpful when I don't want to blast.  The EPs and harpsichords voices are fun as well. People are entranced by the sound and how it permeates through the house.  When I don't play, there are quiet complaints.Little ones will stop watching videos, and come watch me play, entranced. title: RE: My journey to acoustic
post_content: HI everyone.So an update with this thread after a good while being addicted to the pleasures of playing an acoustic piano in the house.Its with ultimate sadness to say that my father passed away at the late part of 2021. My father was a musical man himself who was regarded as one of the top brass players in the British Army in the mid to late 70's and he loved a performance of any kind of live music. He could play a little piano too, but preferred to listen to me play as I grew up to be the only real piano player in the family and proudly came to plenty of my gigs over the years. My dad was a mere 63 and his passing was sudden and unexpected - this is still hurting heavily. His estate afforded me some funds and early 2022 I was struggling with grief, and looking for anything to pull me up somewhat. I know if there was anything he would have wanted me to have then a real deal piano would have been it. Don't get me wrong there is absolutely nothing wrong with a Young Chang G157 and it was what I could afford at the time, but there is no denying that this is a budget instrument and lacking in overall body below middle C. I set about looking for a more substantial instrument to own in honour of my late father.After some searching some large dealers and playing lots of pianos I was struggling to come across anything which really grabbed my attention. There really are some ghastly and uninspiring instruments out there, some with names on which one would not expect. A trip further afield to a huge piano warehouse left me spoilt for choice but among the noise I stumbled across a particular beautiful reconditioned Yamaha C6 that just had that special something after playing it only for a few seconds. It growled when I played the left hand bass notes and sang so perfect in the mids and highs I was just hooked on a new cloud of sound experience and couldn't find anything to dislike about it. It reminded me of when I discovered the Young Chang and my ears pricking up with interest only this was on a whole new level. The dealer was happy to take in the YC as part exchange so I did the deal. I've owned her a while now and felt it was time to update my acoustic journey thread. Unlike the old piano it doesn't have a name (yet) and my daughter has fallen out of love with piano in favour of learning guitar which is a shame, but it has inspired me to play even more than I ever have and its very specialHere is my father, playing my first Nord, the Piano 2HP (which I will say he was very impressed with), and the C6 - a magnificent instrument. I just wish my father was here to see and play it..... but I don't get a choice in that matterI can only play it in his memory now.If you are still with me. Thanks for readingmc.jpg (100.08 KiB) Viewed 4163 timesyc6.jpg (1.37 MiB) Viewed 4163 times

title: All Nord Gig Rig
post_content: My fusion band did a rare gig this past Saturday, and I thought I'd come out in full regalia. I own a Stage 2EX 76 and an Electro 6D 73, and usually only take out one or the other depending on the need. I decided to do a rare dual keyboard setup. Here are a few pictures:View from the top:Front view. I play through a pair of QSC K8.2 speakers. The K10 in the back belongs to the sax player. In this picture, you can also see the 2nd tier struts I made for my K&M 18880 stand. The design was inspired by the original Invisible Stand, one of which I still own:I use a small pedal board with this group. I output the synth lead patches out Output 3 on the Stage and route it through a Moog Minifooger MF Drive pedal and Seymour Duncan Vapor Trail analog delay. The Moog filter in the Drive pedal gives a nice warm fatness to the sound, which works well with the old-school analog delay.I have to say that it's not really necessary to bring all this stuff out. The Stage will cover all my needs for almost everything except heavy organ playing (the HP action is not ideal for anything other than simple technique), so the Electro is kind of superfluous. I actually only used it on two songs the entire night. We had a jazz jam session intermixed with the fusion material, where I tend to play mostly piano anyway.

title: RE: All Nord Gig Rig
post_content: Nice setup, Mike!There is nothing wrong with bringing a pair of Nords to a gig if it's worth the effort.  My current weapons of choice are a NP4 below for weighted stuff, with all the sounds being generated above by a NS3C.  Nothing external except a few control pedals, e.g. no effects, no mixer, etc.I feel more comfortable with a "spare" board in the rig (vs. a weighted controller) as I can limp through the gig if the NS3C gets a brain cramp.  Thankfully, this has never happened.One of the best features I like about the NS3 is the "song" mode which means I can easily enter the night's set list and simply go to the next one with no effort.  Since I tend to forget what key some songs are in, I just code that into the name of the song.  Simple is good, although it's low on the nerd-o-meter.If you want to go even more flashy, consider the bright-red Stay stands.  Not the most stable if you bang the boards at the ends, but otherwise quite capable.

title: RE: All Nord Gig Rig
post_content: Hey guys, I figured that I would chime in here as well.  I too have joined the 2-Nord Club.I had been trying to figure out a solution for a backup for my NS3-HA88, which I used as a single-board rig. I was getting way too nervous when I powered up for the first time at gig, knowing if there was an issue, I (and the band) would be out-of-luck.Only 10-15 of the 75 or so songs in my band's repertoire (mostly keyboard-driven or featured) have a single AP/EP program and/or a simple split with an organ. The rest involve some combination of 2-way/3-way splits, customized synths with effects, morphs and multiple programs for different parts of a song. After trying a Juno-DS61 and a MODX7 (both great values for their price range, by the way), I came to the conclusion that it wasn't practical to re-create what I needed to survive a gig with either board, which resulted in my getting an NS3 Compact. It's 2/3 the size of the HA88 and just a little more than 1/2 the weight.  Other than converting about 20 programs with splits to have both 88-key and 73-key friendly versions, all I need to do now is a two-minute backup and restore process from one keyboard to the other to keep them in-sync.The first gig, I kept the NS3C in a case on standby, then realized that was a waste and now run a 2-tier setup with a K&M 18880 and modified 18881 stacker.  I drilled an additional set of holes to bring the top tier closer to the bottom tier and cut 3" off the support arms so they didnt stick out over the keybed of the bottom board. The pins aren't needed as I use marine weathersripping to securely keep the NS3C from sliding on the top tier.  I really like the virtual invisibility of the 18880, the stability, and the ease of transport and setup.I'm moving some of the parts I play to the NS3C to reduce the number of program changes in a song and to add parts that I wasn't able to cover in a single board. I also have the benefit of bringing my entire set of sounds in a more compact format for rehearsals and casual situations where dragging a large 88-keyboard around isn't practical.Finally, yes, Song Mode is great.  I set all my programs up in alphabetical order, then use Song Mode to set up my setlist for the evening, which is really helpful for the songs that use multiple programs.  The rest of the songs are placed at the end in alphabetical order so they are easy to find if needed.

title: RE: All Nord Gig Rig
post_content: Thanks, Mike!  Yes, it's a bit of a splurge, but a 36-month 0% interest promo helps keep things cash-flow positive, although I'll try to stay out of the new equipment game for a while (famous last words)!I do like the narrower pedestal look for standing while playing.  Keeping the width to 18" also gives me clear access to all the jacks on the back of the NS3 and mostly eliminates any side-to-side sway and twist for me.  Still working on optimizing the pedal arrangement since I use sustain, control, organ swell and rotor switch for each, but I have plenty of room and the feet don't really get in the way of where I like to place the pedals.From what I read on KC, it seems like K&M is discontinuing the 18880 but is possibly coming out with a new model.  It would be interesting to see how they would improve it.  Maybe they'll make it height adjustable without tools.  If mine was damaged, I'd definitely buy another just like it.I have a gig tomorrow night so I'll take some pictures when I tear down.  It's nothing close to being as creative as your making the wood inserts, but it turned out to be just what I needed.

title: RE: All Nord Gig Rig
post_content: Rusty Mike wrote:Can you post pics of your modified stand without the keys on it? I’d like to better understand what you did.Hi Mike - as promised, here’s a picture of the 18880 stand without the keys and a picture of the modified 18881 stacker. I cut off 3” of the arm that the keyboard sits on and drilled an extra height-adjustment hole with the same spacing as the other holes so the upper tier can be lowered.  The height-adjustment knob is in the new hole.  You can also see the marine weatherstripping I used to replace the thin rubber pads on the stacker:https://www.homedepot.com/p/M-D-Buildin ... /202066509Usually I set the top board at the edge of the weatherstripping, but can pull it forward an extra two inches when programming.  I may eventually cut off the extra two inches for even more clearance to the bottom board.Let me know if a different angle would be helpful.

title: RE: All Nord Gig Rig
post_content: UPDATE: I just saw the comment that not all pictures appeared. I hope this correction improves things.I'm following up in this thread, as I was asked about my bespoke 2nd tier for the K&M 18880 stand. This could have easily gone into another thread, and I can cross post if needed.Anyway, I've had some inquiries about the 2nd tier specs, and I want to share them. The tier design was inspired by the old Invisible Stands from the 1980's, which I think were the best keyboard stands ever made. I still have one in great shape, but don't use it for gigs because it's a bit too tall for playing while seated. The design is great because it brings the upper keyboard very close to the lower one.The first picture includes the dimensions that I created. I first made a template out of cardboard, trimming to get the sized and angles I wanted. I've included measurements in both English and metric, and got as close as I could for accuracy. Please note that the drawing itself is not to scale, so don't try to make a template directly from it.The important thing to note is that only a few of these numbers are critical. The post in the middle need to fit into the tube of the K&M stand. You can see in the picture below that I added a shim to the post so that it is wide enough to not wobble while in the stand. Had I used a wider piece of wood that would not have been necessary. The other critical number is the 1-18"/2.9cm just in front of the post, as it determines how the tier will sit on the front rail of the stand.The distance from the post to the front was driven by how far forward my lower keyboard sits on the stand; If you use a deeper lower keyboard, this will be narrower. Likewise, the front height dimension is based on how high I wanted the front of the upper tier to be, and the tilt angle by how I wanted to view the upper tier. The triangle section at the rear is a stabilizer that supports the weight of the upper keyboard.The black triangles are areas I shaved off largely for aesthetics. The exception is the small piece in front of the post. The K&M has a weld spot there, so the corner needed to be rounded off to fit correctly.There is a flat top piece that sits on top of the wedge to provide a wider stable sitting area for the upper board. The whole thing was finished with black paint and clear coat.Here are a few pictures of the unpainted finished product:And painted:The stuff on the top is that gooey pad that people put on their car dashboards to stick their mobile phones on, just cut to fit. It seemed like a cheap way to keep the upper keyboard from sliding.I hope someone finds this useful.

title: RE: All Nord Gig Rig
post_content: Lead 3 A.JPG (199.1 KiB) Viewed 5343 timesWaves (2).jpg (81.34 KiB) Viewed 5343 timesMy C2DC2D A1.JPG (1.01 MiB) Viewed 5343 timesMy "Red Rig"Red Rig.JPG (241.76 KiB) Viewed 5343 times+50 years of gigging and ownership of many keyboards, over the time period, brought me to NORD in late 2015. I've had my entire collection of 46 keyboards rehomed and replaced by my "Red Rig," during the past 3 years. Any and every musically useful sound that I am required or want to make is performed by my beloved NORDS, including bleeps, bloops and farts!Whether playing live, recording or playing at home, my NORDs deliver the goods, reliably and without problems. I have arrived at my dream rig, consisting of C2 and C2D organs, a pair of Electro 4D 61 SWs, a pair of Waves Mk.1 and a Lead 3. Whatever the gig and musical genre, my NORDs can cover it.

title: Welcome home, Stage 3
post_content: Proud to be part of the Nord family!Took a little work and I'm not 100% sold on the CP8s (my issues outlined in a thread in the amplification section), but so far I think I'm happy with the sound. My only issue is the audible hiss from the speakers, but the hiss is there even without an input plugged in, so it isn't my signal chain.I've got the Stage 3 going into a sub-mixer with Chase Bliss Blooper and Habit on aux sends. I’ve been having fun creating textures with feedback, sending the Habit to Blooper and back to Habit, both with long, frippotronic-style decay. The only thing left to do is to get the right side of the studio (Nord, Blooper, and Moog semi-modulars) MIDI-synced to the MPC for when I'm doing more rhythmic stuff.c19825441c48eec1127281f7cb6224e3362b3d06_2_664x500.jpeg (132.3 KiB) Viewed 7079 times

title: RE: Welcome home, Stage 3
post_content: CP8's are entry level QSC speakers so some hiss doesn't surprise me.   Plus using PA speakers for a home recording setup why don't you get a nice set of studio monitors and use the CP8's for gigging, or use good headphone at home.  You got a flagship level keyboard need speakers that will let you hear all that quality sound.

title: RE: Welcome home, Stage 3
post_content: docbop wrote:why don't you get a nice set of studio monitors and use the CP8's for gigging, or use good headphone at home.Because I spent all my money on the Stage 3! hahaI hear you, and that's the same advice I recently in my other thread. Still within the return period of the CP8s, will probably return them for HS8s or Alpha 80s.

title: Another synth pop track
post_content: https://soundcloud.com/markwilkins/respiteThis song does not include any sounds from Nord keyboards. But the NS3 88 plays a central part in each song I make. It almost always is the heart at the beginning of the song when noodling around with different sounds and riffs. And I typically play all MIDI parts on the Stage 3. On this song, most of the sounds are rendered from a Sequential Circuits Prophet 6, u-he Diva, and Spectrasonics Omnisphere. It’s just a simple synth pop/rock song.

title: Richard Marx Right here waiting band cover piano parts.

title: Clean Tone Studio: Beginning of the Learning Curve
post_content: Hey Everybody,The passing of my Mom in March of 2021 inspired me to chase my dream of writing, performing, recording, and producing music. She left a small inheritance which I turned into two guitars and amps, mics, Logic Pro, etc. I started transforming part of my basement into a small recording studio this past summer.While mixing and mastering my first song, I met a remarkable audio engineer, Michael DiVestea, who helped me pick up some Logic Pro skills much more quickly than I would have on my own. (I connected with Michael through fiverr.com.) I shared with him that I was interested in a keyboard/midi controller.My first song can be found here:https://johndavidfarrell.hearnow.com/I had almost purchased a Native Instruments Komplete Control S88 mk3 before Michael brought to my attention his Nord Stage 3 HA 88. He spoke highly of its versatility and quality. I dug around this forum, nordkeyboards.com, YouTube, etc. It captured my imagination and heart. I took delivery of my Nord Stage 3 HA 88 this weekend. The Roland KC-600 amp that will bring it to life is on backorder; hope to see it in 3-4 weeks. I plug it into my studio monitors for now. I'll be learning to use this instrument for years. Thanks to all of you who have helped accelerate the beginning of my learning journey with this beautiful instrument.Mom's inheritance had long run out; I was making this purchase strictly powered by GAS.Attached are pictures of my little music room in the basement: Clean Tone Studio.

title: RE: Clean Tone Studio: Beginning of the Learning Curve
post_content: Touching inspiration and a great start.A small word of warning though - that Roland amp will not do justice to the high quality sound of your Stage, or any other keyboard for that matter. If your setup is strictly for studio, I would strongly recommend cancelling the Roland and putting the money toward a nice pair of 8" powered studio monitors. You will be very disappointed by the sound of the Roland.

title: RE: Clean Tone Studio: Beginning of the Learning Curve
post_content: Rusty Mike wrote:Touching inspiration and a great start.A small word of warning though - that Roland amp will not do justice to the high quality sound of your Stage, or any other keyboard for that matter. If your setup is strictly for studio, I would strongly recommend cancelling the Roland and putting the money toward a nice pair of 8" powered studio monitors. You will be very disappointed by the sound of the Roland.Yours is the first negative review I’ve read about the sound of this amp; the only criticism I’ve read is about its high price and limited functionality (simple 3-band eq, only 4 channels, no effects). Would you be willing to share any more experiences or observations?

title: RE: Clean Tone Studio: Beginning of the Learning Curve
post_content: The Roland KC series amps (or any other amp in this “keyboard” style) are notorious for their bad sound. The single 15” woofer has a horrible midrange, which is where the majority of your piano quality sound is going to be. The small tweeter is simply not powerful enough to handle the necessary mid-highs. You will get a sound that is deep, muddy and with a lack of clarity.This is an amp design from the 70’s for the most part. Digital pianos and synthesizers have come a very long way since then, and this design is not equipped to keep up. They are loud, heavy, expensive and (as someone on the Keyboard Corner once wrote) “horribly, horribly reliable.”You are much better off putting your money toward a pair of decent studio monitors for a studio-only rig. In my studio, I use a pair of old Gemini 8” powered studio monitors. While they are not world class, they sound a whole lot better in my studio than the old Crate Keyboard amp I had (it was a very similar design to the Roland KC).If you plan to play out, a pair of QSC CP-8’s or similar from Yamaha or Electro Voice will serve you well. You spent good money on a Nord Stage; give it the quality amplification it deserves.

title: RE: Clean Tone Studio: Beginning of the Learning Curve
post_content: Thank you @Rusty Mike! I appreciate your sharing your perspective. I’m going to research those powered speakers you recommended.

title: RE: Clean Tone Studio: Beginning of the Learning Curve
post_content: Rusty Mike wrote:They are loud, heavy, expensive and (as someone on the Keyboard Corner once wrote) “horribly, horribly reliable.”Another of my favourite Keyboard Corner quotes about the KC's is: "The only thing I'd put through a Roland KC amp is a chainsaw".I agree that you can find much better amplification for the same or less money. A modern class-D amp will be smaller, lighter, cheaper, more powerful and with a MUCH better sound. Which studio monitors are you using now? Most likely, you already have a better sound than the Roland would provide. The Nord Monitors are high quality but expensive (as anything Nord). As mentioned, you might research a pair of good 6' or 8' monitors, or even some small full-range speakers like the EV ZX-A1 or QSC K8. These are probably too much for just a small studio, but would be great if you ever plan on taking them out on a gig.Also, don't forget the used market! You may find some great bargains there and, if you don't like what you get, you will lose much less money in reselling it.Have fun in your new musical journey!

title: RE: Clean Tone Studio: Beginning of the Learning Curve
post_content: Thank you, @Spider, for your input. I'm leaning toward the QSC CP-12. I'll start with one, which should be plenty of oomph for my home studio. Really appreciate the help!

title: RE: Clean Tone Studio: Beginning of the Learning Curve
post_content: NordBanger wrote:Thank you, @Spider, for your input. I'm leaning toward the QSC CP-12. I'll start with one, which should be plenty of oomph for my home studio. Really appreciate the help!The 12 may be overkill for the studio. You should give the 8 a try.I play with several big bands using a single K8. It has plenty of power and presence for all but the most demanding rooms. I will carry a second one on the rare occasion. It’s also been my experience that the QSC’s sound better from 10’ away than from 3’ away.The ZXA-1 is an excellent choice as well, as Spider recommended.

title: I Love White Grand
post_content: I started playing piano before 10 monthsThe only thing i knew before i start playing piano was which note is every key on the pianoI did 6 lessons and i watched some youtube videos..Ofc i am proffesional bouzouki player and singer in my country which helps extremely a lotWhat do you think of the results for the moment??Any proffesional pianist advice will appreciated muchThanks in advance

title: RE: I Love White Grand
post_content: Sounds excellent to me Mitsos, but you asked for professional advice, so that rules me out.  Seldom am I hired for my keyboard skills.  I have fooled a couple local bands into hiring me for my guitar skills, but that's another topic.  Bouzouki intrigue's me, I have dabbled with American 5 string banjo and Mandolin.   I like the sound of the White Grand.  You are an excellent singer, I wish I had your voice.  Of course, it would confuse my band mates if I started singing in Greek.... Good job Mitsos.

title: RE: I Love White Grand
post_content: You seem like you have enough music DNA that you can simply learn by doing.  A few lessons on technique would not hurt, but really aren't necessary to enjoy the instrument.   The White Grand (and just about anything on a Nord) sounds great, even with very simple and sparse music.  The tone quality is good enough that you can sound long tones, and they sound good with resonance, reverb, etc.  From there, maybe try learning different scales in different keys, then different chord positions, then tying them together in various ways -- and it all sort of flows from there.  Or just try to play things that sound good to you.The only time I have sought out instruction (formal or informal) is when I've encountered something I didn't know how to do, and I wanted to do it.  You can learn a lot from Youtube, by the way.EDIT: there are many people on this forum who would qualify as "professional" pianists, and I am not one of them.  I just love to play, and have become really good at it.

title: RE: I Love White Grand
post_content: I'm no phenomenal instrumentalist, but my somewhat trained musical ear would have one remark:Pay a lot of attention to voicing (or inversions). I dont know much about bouzouki, but there is one major shift in thinking that might help you. Bouzouki and the human voice are very unrestricted intonation-wise. As in: you can tune or bend strings differently to get different colours, or just sing a bit higher or lower. With piano and other instruments (especially if you stick with TET), the tuning is kept precisely as it is, and different inversions will not only determine register and note density, but also how "out of tune" notes are against each other. Take C major for example. Play it in 1st inversion, with an added C one octave lower, and you get a very static, maybe uneasy sound. Then play another inversion: C2, G2, E3. It is not only more spread out, but i feel like the intonation is nicer as it is.EDIT: this example is my subjective experience. Do what you want with it. I'll keep playing my spread out voicings.

title: RE: I Love White Grand

title: Flashback: The Magic of Santana
post_content: This was a band I was musical director and keyboardist for from 2010 to 2016.Featuring the legendary Alex Ligertwood on lead, who sang the original cut on Santana's 1981 album "Zebop!". The wonderful Tony Lindsay, original vocalist for Santana from 1990-2015, features on backing vocals and some percussion.Thanks to our drummer's GoPros, there's actually a full show's worth of multicam footage from my office, as it were, recorded on our tour of Spain in 2016.I finished this mix and the video in time for the fifth anniversary of this gig, on January 31st.I'll probably add two or three more songs from this show over the next few weeks.Gear is a 1968 Hammond B3 into a Leslie 760, a Yamaha Motif XS6, and a Nord Stage 2 compact (since replaced by a Stage 3 compact).Enjoy!

title: Ski Day - SPS
post_content: I wrote and recorded this song with my wife a couple months ago.https://soundcloud.com/markwilkins/ski- ... ps-final-1It is definitely outclassed here by what other people post. There are some amazing musicians on this forum, and I am astonished by what is created. I know I will never reach the level that so many of you are at (I will keep my day job as a programmer). But music can be a wonderful hobby and I so love playing music and playing around with trying things.The bulk of the melody on this is a simple EP patch from the Nord Stage 3. The original plan was to make some kind of “electric guitar-ish” sounding melody. As a super quick stand-in, I used a Rhodes patch and added a bunch of distortion. And I ended up rather liking it so left it. Plus it was easy to drop into the sweet undistorted Rhodes sound during the bridge. A Novation Peak is used for the arpeggio backing and for the lead melody on one verse right after the bridge. The Prophet 6 is used for the bass and for backing pads.

title: Virtual Big Band Recordings
post_content: Like a lot of other musicians, our big band has become virtual. This is the latest composite video we've created. It's Chris Connolly's arrangement of Makin' Whoopee, which is a tenor feature.I'm playing the Amber Upright sample on my Stage 2EX, fairly dry. The growth experience for me has been with doing the audio mixing, along with the agony of making video recordings of myself.The featured player is the band leader's father. I can't get over his smooth tone. If silk made a sound, this would be it!

title: RE: Virtual Big Band Recordings
post_content: Continuing in reverse order, this is the second video we did. It's a big band arrangement of America The Beautiful. The Band Leader wanted to make something a bit patriotic, and this was an arrangement we played before.Nothing Nord related in this one, but I did get a chance to play my old Hammond M3.I was not happy with the audio mix I did for the video, so I did a complete remix. Specifically, the trombones have this great rhythmic pulse that gets lost in the original mix, and I wanted to bring that out. I also felt the sax section sounded like an accordion and wanted to smooth that out a bit. The remix is much less muddy to me.https://soundcloud.com/baldrust/america-the-beautiful

title: RE: Virtual Big Band Recordings
post_content: This is the first track we did, which is a standard arrangement of Fly Me To The Moon. It was the first time I mixed for big band, the start of the adventure so to speak.No Nords involved, I played the Native Instruments Maverick piano using my Roland RD-800 as the controller.I plan to do a complete remix of this as well.

title: RE: Virtual Big Band Recordings
post_content: Nice work rusty mike! Must have been a huge amount of work. Love that tenor sound on makin' whoopee. I wonder if a tinkly grand piano sound would complement the sax / big band sound vs the amber (which has a lot of character but maybe a bit too nasal / mid sounding?) - perhaps either White Grand or something brighter like Studio Grand 2? Anyway, it sounds great, would love to hear some more of your piano... maybe your next track needs a piano solo

title: RE: Virtual Big Band Recordings
post_content: Thank you spradders!The mix was a big challenge in that I had to sync up all the parts. When playing alone, each person has a slightly different idea of where and when to hit the notes. It required a lot of splicing and nudging in Cubase to line everyone up. That was rather tedious to do, but I think it was worth it in the end.I appreciate your comment about the selection of the piano sound. I actually chose the Amber precisely for its lyrical fundamental tone. I'm a big fan of the jazz recordings of the 50's and the pianos were always very fundamental forward without a lot of bright overtone. I know it had a lot to do with the ability of the recording technology of the time, but I really like that sound.I knew the tenor player has a lush classic style and I wanted the piano to match that. I also have this notion that, in big band music, the piano is not supposed to cut through but rather accentuate the other instruments. The Amber is ideal for that because of it's rich mid-voice and softer highs and lows.The next one is a bit more uptempo and will feature a bit of piano solo, but I'm debating if it should be AP or EP. If it's AP, I'll probably use the White Grand for its all-around versatility. Either that or Native Instruments The Grandeur sample. I'll be tinkering with those over the next few weeks.Thanks again for your comments!

title: RE: Virtual Big Band Recordings
post_content: harmonizer wrote:I only watched "Makin' Whoopee" so far. That was really well done.You talked about the challenge to sync the parts. Were the sax players in general playing more behind the beat? (sax is my main instrument).Thanks!Everyone is recording on their own against a sparse backing track. They don’t have the benefit of keying off the lead instrument, so the accuracy is not there.I start out by creating a backing “shell” in Band-In-A-Box with drums, bass and guitar. I move the tracks into Cubase, add a sparse piano track and a click track. I then remove the drum track from the shell and send it to the drummer to record his part. I also send a shell without the bass line to the bass player so he can record his part. Once the drummer’s part is in, it goes to the rest of the band to record their parts individually. As parts come in, I add them to the project.What tends to happen is that everyone has their own slight interpretation differences which results in each section having a rather loose sound When you put them together. In the saxes, the two altos are usually pretty on par with the exception of some slight accent/dynamics differences. They both tend to play in front of the beat. The tenor player played slightly behind the beat, which sort of dragged the section a bit so I nudged him up a bit. Bari is a tough instrument. It’s a big horn and it takes time to the air to get through, which then sounds like late notes. I moved him up a lot because I wanted each section to sound punchy and the bari is the key to that punch for the saxes.There were other cases where someone held a note out too long or not long enough, so I made some corrections there as well. The trombones presented a few challenges as well. Bone 1 has a rather mellow and smooth sound while Bones 2 and 3 were rather punchy and bright. They also had a few rhythmic misgivings.If you listen to the America The Beautiful recordings, you’ll hear it more clearly. The audio track on the video has very few rhythmic adjustments and not a whole lot of EQ/dynamics blending, while the remixed audio recording on SoundCloud is much clearer. You can hear each section with better definition. I took a lot of time on the remix to line up the rhythmic elements so the hits and counterpoints would stand out.Overall, this continues to be a great learning experience for me as a hack audio engineer.

title: Virtual Big Band Recordings
post_content: Another recent production to share.This is a jazz standard called Autumn Nocturne. I’ve always thought this was just a beautiful song. The tenor sax is my friend Marty. The rest of it is me with the help of technology.The drums and bass are generated by Band-In-A-Box. The drums are pure audio, while the bass isr MIDI data where I then used an acoustic bass sample from Kontakt. For this song, I wanted to learn more about Kontakt. The string section is also from Kontakt, which gave me the chance to also learn a little bit about arranging strings.The piano is the Nord White Grand. I really like its sweeter tone compared to other pianos which are heavy in the overtones. It reminds me of the jazz recordings of the 50’s and 60’s. I was shooting for an intimate vibe, reminiscent of that era but with a slightly more contemporary touch. Recorded straight )no EQ or reverb), with a touch of post production tweaking.I hope you enjoy it. It's time to move on to more uptempo stuff, as I've been spending a lot of time with jazz ballads lately.

title: Virtual Big Band Recordings
post_content: I have another one posted on SoundCloud.This was a quickie. A friend asked me to do a rendition of Moonlight in Vermont. My big band does a bossa nova arrangement behind our singer, and it sounds nice, but there is something about "bossa nova" and "Vermont" that just don't click with me. I decided instead to think about a snowy evening nestled near the fireplace.This is a simple one with only three instruments (and no Nords this time). The bass comes courtesy of the great Ron Carter and Band-In-A-Box. The piano is The Gentleman from the Kontakt collection, and the organ is the B3-V2 from Arturia. I tried using the Mellow Upright, but the Gentleman had just that little bit of extra sparkle that I think hits the mark. I also wanted to experiment with the B3-V, using my Electro 6D as a controller.I know this is a mellow one again, and am now working on something a bit more upbeat to share soon.

title: RE: Virtual Big Band Recordings
post_content: Gorgeous Mike.  Really enjoyed that.

title: Virtual Big Band Recordings
post_content: Got another one here. Pretty far out of my normal zone. I try to always learn new things with these projects.This is a 5/4 time rendition of Greensleeves, the traditional waltz. It started mostly as an exercise in meter. I wanted to see if the tune could be adapted to 5/4 time, and experimented with some small polyrhythm phrases. There are examples of 4 over 5, 6 over 5 and 8 over 5 throughout.I had two sources of inspiration. The first is a recording of Take Five by Acoustic Alchemy, which has this reggae type groove that I really liked. Some of the sound profile such as the synth comping were based on that recording. The other element was Brubeck's Blue Rondo a la Turk, a song I've like since first hearing Al Jarreau's rendition in the early 80's.As I started to work through the arrangement, it took on a life of its own (no surprise there). The instrumentation is largely comprised of stock and custom-programmed patches from Arturia's V-Collection, using the Synclavier, Matrix 12, SQ-80 and Casio CZ engines. Drums are a combination of battery from Ujam's DEEP and cymbals/percussion from Steinberg Groove Agent. There's a Roland SA ePiano patch from my RD-800 buried in there as well. This track uses effects to a greater extent than anything I've done previously.Nord spotting: The acoustic piano is the Silver Grand, run through Arturia's Mello-Fi effect. My first attempt at adding lo-fi stuff.Unlike my past ventures, the bass and drum parts are largely original. The drums are based on the groove I mentioned above with the embellishments courtesy of Groove Agent. I started with a Band In A Box baseline, but ended up crafting my own to fit the groove.Not sure I'm done polishing it yet, but I wanted to share. I feel the first pass at mastering took a little life out of it and want to try to get something back.

title: RE: not music, but amazing nightingale song
post_content: my summer attempts to catch the golden oriole songOf all the birds in the Northern hemisphere, the golden oriole has one of the most bewitching songs often reminiscent of a florid flute melody if it were played in a low register. This rather large bird with yellow and black plumage prefers to live in the crowns of tall trees and rarely appears in open spaces.When moving through the treetops, a pair of golden orioles are most likely to either perform what sounds like a genuine flute duet with fanciful variations or simply communicate by using harsh calls that resemble yowls of a cat whose tail has been stepped on.This review contains a transcript of the sounds recorded in June during daylight hours featuring songs and calls of golden orioles accompanied by other birds, insects, wind, and other sounds of nature. These soundscapes were recorded in the depths of a mixed forest where a set of microphones captured a stereo panorama. The captured soundscapes are that of a meadow with a diameter of about 100 meters that produces a multi-level echo and deep reverb.The recording session begins in the early hours, and a soft breeze can be heard moving the crowns of deciduous and coniferous trees in a sonic imitation of the sea surf, somewhat drowning out the bustle of morning birds. The golden oriole sings in the distance but its legato melody is clearly audible in the center of the stereo panorama and completely fills the background thanks to the layered echo of a forest meadow.Listen to Golden oriole song accompanied by other birds:Closer to noon, the chirping of grasshoppers and bush-crickets comes to the foreground of the soundscape, creating a truly meditative environment, especially with the recurring rustle of the wind. Shifting a little to the right, the golden oriole spreads its song through the meadow, now complemented by muted calls of other birds including thrushes, wagtails, and swallows.Listen to Golden oriole song accompanied by insects and other birds:By afternoon, the wind significantly picks up and completely masks all sounds produced by insects and birds, except for the loud communication between the pair of golden orioles still audible in the left channel. The couple alternates the scandalous call with their usual song performed in a higher register, and their voices gradually subside as the birds retire into the depths of the forest. Here you can also hear the creak of a tree swaying in the wind.Listen to Golden orioles' talk accompanied by wind and other birds:In the next soundscape, the golden oriole is localized in the left channel, while on the right you can hear the shrill call of the shrike and the distant song of another golden oriole. The wind, grasshoppers, and other birds also continue to harmonize.Listen to Golden oriole song accompanied by wind:For your relaxation, here is another extended soundscape from June of this year recorded in the afternoon. The recording features the sounds of birds and insects of the grassy meadow sheltered in a dense forest far from urban or industrial areas. On this hot summer day, the insects not once interrupted their song throughout the heatwave while the wind intensified and abated, revealing small details such as the small hammering sound in the left channel. This is the sound of a song thrush attempting to break the shell of a grape snail against the stone to eat the slug inside. Spans of swallows and insects sometimes interrupt the idyllic soundscape by moving right in front of the microphones. Golden orioles can also be heard moving closer from time to time.Listen to Woodland sounds—bird calls, insects, and wind recorded on a summer morning:The soundscapes are processed with analog equipment and the maximum playback volume does not exceed their naturally-occurring volume levels, so you can listen to it without fear of hearing fatigue.

title: What's the WEIRDEST gig you ever played?
post_content: Hoping for some fun "war stories" here... so I'll kick it off with mine:Several years back, I got a call to play piano-bar style for a local ad agency's holiday event.  This particular company was housed in a former entertainment venue, and thematically speaking, they wanted to "acknowledge" two periods in the building's history: about a hundred years ago, when it was a saloon (ahem), and about 40 years ago, when it was a rock bar.So never mind the seasonal music... they asked me to concentrate on only two styles: ragtime, and late-60s-to-mid-80s rock.  They wanted me toalternatebetween those, for three hours.  And I did: "Stairway To Heaven" unabashedly followed "The Easy Winners", which followed "Back In Black", etc..  ALL ON PIANO ALONE.As a keyboardist, my main takeaway was a newfound respect for the Stride Left Hand.  What a freaking workout that was.  It's one thing to play a couple of rags as a throwaway, but 90 minutes' worth!?Confession: there were about four rags that I really wanted to learn, but there was only so much time to practice in advance.  So for just those, I sequenced the left hand.  Cringe, you say?  Well, no, that freed me to add density to the right-hand part with both hands, which was its own fun.  And besides, the clientele werewaytoo snookered to care.Now... your turn.

title: RE: What's the WEIRDEST gig you ever played?
post_content: I have a long list; but one we played was a wedding for a couple who were s*x therapists and the theme of the wedding was HIGHLY sexual.And just yesterday, I played a poolside gig for a clothing optional resort.   Out of 200 people in the pool area, I saw 1 bathing suit.  Maybe not weird, but shocking nonetheless.

title: RE: What's the WEIRDEST gig you ever played?
post_content: We were hired to tag along a company trip to a Norway ski resort thursday to sunday as their own after ski band.They had a "cabin" with 60 beds and some left over, so plenty of room (but we did take the whole cargo compartment in the bus with our gear).We ended skiing 1 hour before the lifts closed to prepare, so they had after ski in their own cabin when they came in.So far, nothing out of the ordinary....Later at night we did a more intense gig in the cabin.We have photo evidence of the CEO hanging by his knees from the ceiling lamp.People exiting the hotel hundreds of meters away (that had a band playing) said our party/playing immediately won over the hotel party although they were still right outside the hotel.At 3am the CEO entered the stage and took a microphone and said:"I have been contacted by the people in the cabin next door, and they're saying that if we don't stop making noise immediately they will call the police.I have never been in trouble with Norwegian police before... But I must admit I'm really curious... LET'S PARTY!"And then we commenced playing a couple of hours more.Weird..? Maybe not, but a little surrealistic at the time...

title: RE: What's the WEIRDEST gig you ever played?
post_content: A Supermarket.  Why anyone would hire a band to play in a supermarket is beyond me, but it was a paying gig.  We set up near the vegetable aisle.  I was closest to the avocados.

title: RE: What's the WEIRDEST gig you ever played?

title: RE: What's the WEIRDEST gig you ever played?
post_content: We had a gig at some pyramid type organization that had a full day WS with members.They were something like 100 in total.The most we had on the dance floor was 4 people.After 3 songs people started taking off, and after first set the place was empty.The organizer took the blame for not understanding this group of people were not going to stay and party, paid us in full and told us we could pack up.He also paid the DJ that was going to play all night, after we had finished our intended 3 sets...Strange gig...On a per-minute or per-song basis it was very well paid.

title: RE: What's the WEIRDEST gig you ever played?
post_content: Well, the only weird one that I could think of was I was 15, first garage band and we were looking for a drummer....A 35 years old guy came and said he need us to play for a party for old people...But we needed to learn some Accordion songs...Then I Played "La cumparsita" on my Hammond L100 and some other Tango stuff as well....Besides this one, I don't think I 've ever had a weird gig...

title: RE: What's the WEIRDEST gig you ever played?
post_content: At a women's correctional facility. Someone started throwing aluminum pie plates (like frisbees) at the band and then this went on for about 15 minutes until the guards stopped it.

title: RE: What's the WEIRDEST gig you ever played?
post_content: Jazz quartet gig in a basement floor bar.  We are playing Gentle Rain.  There is a noise, and one of the bartenders asks if it was an explosion.  It sounded like thunder.Shortly after, there is a commotion at the door.  One of the bartenders is trying to help a few people open the door to get out but it won't budge.  Then someone yells, that there is water up to the (eye level) window.   Just then water starts pouring down from  the ceiling light fixtures.   The staff wisks all the customers, us and our gear out the back door.Turns out there was a rain torrent, that hopped the curb, down the enclosed outside steps, overwhelmed the drain and filled up to the windows, while the next floor above us was flooding out, thus the water from the overhead lights.Gentle Rain is a nice jazz standard, but will always remind me of that crazy night.

title: RE: What's the WEIRDEST gig you ever played?
post_content: stopmakingsense, your crazy story reminds me of a video one of my kids shared with me last week.  It’s a flooded indoor mall, water pouring from the skylights way above, ankle-deep puddles below... with the band on a platform stage on the bottom floor, everyone watching them from the second floor and escalators, and they were playing My Heart Will Go On.It’s on Reddit, if anyone’s curious.

title: RE: What's the WEIRDEST gig you ever played?
post_content: Last year Aug. 4th long weekend in Canada. Hectic weekend for me every year but this was the exception. Coming off from night shift on Saturday morning, 1st day of 3 in club championship (golf) and its my wedding anniversary. Day two back to the golf coarse, finish up and clean up for a 2.5hr drive where my band was playing the "Freaks Olympics" Had no idea what we were getting into, we were told P.A system is there. Once we arrived went to check out the stage and P.A, look around there is no P.A on the stage, there is no P.A anywhere!! Finally find our contact they direct us into the saloon where the P.A was located. Finally check it out and blow off probably 3/16" of dust from the mixer, can't get s*** working and close to calling it off and cut our losses. Finally we get it to work move the stuff outside and hooked up 15 min before we go on stage. No time to freshen up but enough time to smash a beer or two and on we go. The smell of weed was everywhere and trust me we seen all kinds of people in all types of attire. Anyway turned out to be a great venue girls flashing us and the weirdest dude was wearing a sequined blazer, top hat, and nothing else on just strolling around. Once again it was a great night packed up and drove home made it home by 4:30am took a cat nap and played day 3 in club championship for 3rd place.  Wish I could do it all over again this year.

title: "Echoes" (Pink Floyd cover)
post_content: My almost 20-year old original Nord Electro has found a new lease of life as a pretty reliable MIDI controller for Logic Pro; unlike the Stage, the Hammond drawbar controls match up perfectly, allowing real-time playing.Several other people have covered this, and it's a bit of a cult rock classic, so I thought I'd give it a go. To pre-answer two questions 1) yes, this is all me - drums, bass, keys, guitar, vocals 2) no I don't have a real wah-wah pedal to emulate the "seagull" guitar in the middle so I had to imitate it another way.Echoes (revisited).mp3

title: Repeatre — to keep your repertoire and create setlists

It's PWA — progressive web application so it can be used not only as usual website — you can add it to the home screen of any smartphone as well (iOS and Android tested). In case you decide to try it:1) write me (here or atinfo@repeatre.app) and I will give you the full access to the premium features for free;2) any advice, suggestions and comments are welcome;3) any help with translation of english version is appreciated.Thank you in advance!Yura Birukov

title: RE: My New Band Member
post_content: Just to answer my own question from a few months ago:The BeatBuddy doesn't have a knob just to dial some swing feeling in. All sounds with all their imperfections (or not) are hard programmed MIDI files. But as long as you get the BeatBuddy and not its little brother, you can adjust any rhythm with a MIDI editor.So no way to adjust to play a given rhythm in 55%, 60%, 66% or 70% swing on the fly. But you can choose from  included, additionally bought, community driven or custom made beats.Today, I got mine. And am happy with it. Maybe, it's true that the presets are a bit 'full' of hits. You have to look a bit to get beats that don't tend to make too much of a wind. But on the other side, that's exactly what you'll like in the beginning: having a lot of 'sound' even if you miss a chord on your piano. Will it help practising or not? - Don't know yet.Thanks, Normhart, for the hint!

title: RE: Intro Tom from Melbourne
post_content: Welcome!  Here's a thread with a ton of info on amplification.  For pianos, you should strongly consider a pair of speakers to run in stereo.accessories-and-amplification-f8/nord-a ... 72-10.htmlThe default answer I would give for a starting point would be a pair of QSC K8.2 speakers if you need to self-amplify, or a set of IEMs (I prefer the ambient instead of sealed) if your keys are going through the FOH system and you just need to monitor yourself.For strings, I've found the most use out of "OrchStrings Marc HiVib" sample and adjusting the Frequency Filter and Attack/Release.There are fantastic tutorial videos for the Stage 3 on the My Keys to Music YouTube channel.https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC_xKuR ... BvAc63Y9qwGood luck and enjoy!

title: RE: Intro Tom from Melbourne
post_content: I agree with ajstan, if you don't know what to buy, a pair of QSC K8.2s is a great start.  Besides sounding great, powerful, light weight, reliable, etc. --- they can be used in many different ways, depending on the situation.  If those are too expensive, consider a pair of similar powered 8" with DSPs, e.g. CP8, Yamaha, EV, etc.If your budget is really tight, buy one speaker first, then the other.  Most Nord players appreciate stereo.

title: RE: Intro Tom from Melbourne
post_content: Greetings from California, Tom.  As said, the QSC K 8'.2 are well regarded, compact and kick A** for their size

They should have been made on the B3 or the Farfisa, but I have a hard time understanding the final part of the chord, when it changes into the next one (like Dm9 changing to Bb, then Bb to Am9/4 etc.), as the organs have no slow release. title: record with us - open source project
post_content: Hello from The Jam Lab!http://www.jamlab.usYouTube:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uIU0q7r ... Kl6BeRBkvAWe started the open source recording project in 1999 in Orlando Fl. We moved to Houston in 2003 and then Asheville, NC in 2006. We normally start a recording session of improvised music as a trio. These are sink or swim 100% improvisations. We sometimes use a chord framework or mostly just jump right in to it. Then we hope to find some jam worthy portions and post them on the web. Other musicians from around the world are then free to add their new parts to our tracks and post those results as a V-jam or Cyber-Jam. We have some incredible musicians contributing to this body of work.We have hundreds of tracks  posted on the mothership. My ISP is very rural, so have patience on downloads. The results vary according to the players on that session or cyber-jam. The styles include rock, jazz, blues, progressive. This includes traditional and experimental tracks. There are no musical rules.This is your invitation to record some improvised music. To hear the NS3 piano in action check our Jam 4 Jeff (Lorber) southern style track. Fans of Alan Holdsworth need to check out Hugh Ferguson on guitar on the cyber-jams page. If you find a track you want to record let me know and I can build a mix with more room for your parts, if it is needed. There are folders with pre-mixed minus one instrument as well for you to record with. All are welcome!Peace,Kurtkurt @ deepcreekservices.us

title: Ivy Flindt - Indie Pop from Hamburg
post_content: I got a call from these guys last year and have been playing with them since last summer (which means something like — four streaming gigs and one live show for an outdoor audience. Crazy times.).Tonight we were invited to play the hallowed grounds of the Hamburg Elbphilharmonie — no audience, but live-streamed and archived here for your perusal:I'm particularly fond of the sound design on "I Wish I Had a Girl" (21:55) and "In Every Move" (29:10).My setup is a Stage 3 compact for most of the stuff including left-hand bass on a couple of songs, plus a Wurlitzer 200A and a Mellotron Mini.On full sets, I also have a Roland FR-5 V-Accordion along for one song (not this time, though).Stool is an Ikea Nilserik.

title: RE: Ivy Flindt - Indie Pop from Hamburg
post_content: Wow. I dare not to call that minimalistic, as it's well woven sound in a sophisticated way. Better call it tidy. Is this the sound of these times?analogika wrote:Stool is an Ikea Nilserik.There's more than one detail I'd be interested in. The singer has two monitors plus IEs? And you even don't have a sub mixer for your instruments? All delivered to the engineers.The only bombastic thing seems to be the pedal park of the guitarist.And you all are filling this empty house just with that intimate sound?Great! And thank you for sharing!

title: RE: Ivy Flindt - Indie Pop from Hamburg
post_content: Wow, really loved it! Great music while installing my Big Green Egg bbqGood to see people are finding ways to bring music in to the world.May I ask why did you bring the real Wurlitzer and a separate Mellotron? Do they sound much better than the samples from Nord? The Mellotron is basically the same thing right? It's also sample based instead of the real tapes. Off course the Wurlitzer is the real dealSpecial thumbs up for all the German equipment (mics, monitors and probably stands too)Thanx for sharing!!

title: RE: Ivy Flindt - Indie Pop from Hamburg
post_content: Thanks for the kind words!The singer only recently switched to in-ears. I think she feels safer knowing the monitors are there.The Mellotron is the band‘s, so i took it over as given. It’s a „Mellotron“, which counts as a genuine Instrument. The patches they’d set up are mostly layered, so they‘d take up two synth slots, which means I wouldn’t have any left over for the bass. Plus, I like the ergonomics of the setup, and the mello looks nice on the setup.The band grudgingly accepts the Nord as more than just a „Substitute“ despite being a fake organ and fake piano.I mean, they cart around a freaking vibraphone.Yeah, the keys are five channels of DI (Nord is stereo out plus mono on Channel 3 for the bass). Plus one for accordion when we have it along. The FOH guy is their own.As for mics: yeah. Love the 421s, as well.And that Wurli is special.

title: I'M BACK
post_content: Hi Guys,I've just spent 3 days going through the 17 pages of topics I didn't look at for the last 2 years...well, maybe one year and a host only but the story behind my "disappearance" from this forum is that, end of 2018, I started a new band, Funk/dance band, I think some of you were aware about it because I had posted our setlist in this forum.So, starting everything from scratch, finding people who wants to practice and really build a show for corporates and wedding was not easy as well as convincing my wife to let me installed everything in the basement.Then, because in 2019, after having tried several drummers, we had found finally a good one, I needed a drum kit, as he didn't have a spare one. The fact is, even if he was thinking to buy a very cheap one around 300 CAN$, I wanted to have a great sound even during our practices so, I decided to invest in drums.I was a complete newbies so, I spent a lot of time on forum, mainly Drummerword and DrumForum. So, I was lucky to find from one of the contacts I had in looking for a drummer a very nice guy who is a collector and repairs himself drums in his workshop. I bought from him a vintage Tama Star drumset 1973 with 3 rack toms, one floor toms, a rack, and Hihat, 3 cymbals and accessoires...Cymbals Zildjian 70's made in Canada!!! In the factory that is Sabian nowadays...But you know how crazy I may with gear...Adding that to the fact that I had taken 6 months of drums lessons when I was 15 in the 80's made me to found again in love with cymbals...they are crazy awesome special beasts and below is the result:Practice place in the basementFullSizeRender.jpg (451.68 KiB) Viewed 8780 timesPractice place bisIMG_2776.JPG (370.85 KiB) Viewed 8780 timesKeys CornerFullSizeRender (3).jpg (944.44 KiB) Viewed 8780 timesDrums intermediate stage20200626_124127 (1).jpg (88.01 KiB) Viewed 8780 timesFew cymbals20200626_124112_004.jpg (1.23 MiB) Viewed 8780 timesAlmost finished20200626_123758.jpg (1.7 MiB) Viewed 8780 timesFinished!!!EAD85F5A-CC29-4A0D-8AFA-4B27B664D49C.jpeg (1.71 MiB) Viewed 8780 timesDrums kit "Left Wing"C5683350-8E0A-405A-AA37-93A2ACE2E7AB.jpeg (1.66 MiB) Viewed 8780 timesDrums kit "Central Wing"71646447-AF62-4519-9D89-E77EAF8320F0.jpeg (1.57 MiB) Viewed 8780 timesDrums Kit "Right Wing"CD6C71E6-D926-4CD1-AD65-7720FA0A33DD.jpeg (1.71 MiB) Viewed 8780 timesDifferent colors...20200626_124344.jpg (3.51 MiB) Viewed 8780 timesSo, in 2019, we practiced a lot and we were able to get two booths at the wedding show in January 2020, being the 1rst band in 30 years to be allowed to play live, it was a huge success, 750 contacts to deal with but, BUT...COVID!!! So, we had to stop practicing, doing it a bit when we were allowed in 2020 but since last October, we had to stop completely...so, I play my new toys during my breaks as I work for home as well since March 2020...But I'm still the keys player:BUT I'M STILL THE KEYS PLAYERIMG_1533.JPG (1.12 MiB) Viewed 8780 timesThat's it's now that I understand way better what is going on on drums forum, I will read and participate regularly again on this forum, Gearslutz and so on...Ha, and I placed all microphones in the drums, ready to record, via the Mackie Onyx 1640i that I had in the Den/Studio but...We are still waiting for the good to go from the health authorities here in Winnipeg. So, I was busy with music as usual, next plan is to build a movie from the recording we did at the wedding show for the website but I want to do the re-recording and overdub in the basement for instruments and in the studio for vocals...So, again, new projects...AND....THAT'S ALL!!

title: My Handmade Wooden Nord Grand Stand:
post_content: Hi all!First let me introduce myself, I'm a 22 year old pianist / artist / carpenter from Arizona, USA! I've been playing piano for 17 years, a Nord user for 4 four years, and a lurker of this forum for a couple of those.I upgraded from a Nord Piano 2 to the Nord Grand last year, and was having some annoyance with my flimsy metal stand shifting around too much while playing aggressively. Missing the feel of playing on an acoustic piano and not being able to justify spending ~$800 on Nord's official wooden stand, I decided to build my own! It's made to look like an old upright piano base, and really feels like it with the sturdiness it provides.Thanks for reading/ taking a look! I'm very happy with how it turned out, and hope to post more frequently here.Best, TylerP.S., hope this is in the right place! Couldn't decide whether to post this here or "Accessories / Amp" subforum

title: Introducing myself shortly
post_content: Hello everyone,finally I manage to write a self-introducing post!I'm a sardinian (--> italian) living in Germany.I started playing piano when I was about 8/9 years old, then studied it from 10 to 18/19. I studied classical piano but love progressive rock just as much (international classics like Genesis, ELP and King Crimson as well as italian prog 'classics' like PFM, Le Orme and Banco del Mutuo Soccorso).In my teenage years I played in several bands, spanning from rock/hard rock covers (mostly such as Deep Purple and Pink Floyd) to italian classics (like De André) and folk-rock original music.In those years, beside my vertical acoustic piano, I played whatever keyboard I could find or borrow, proudly including my brother's toy(?) Bontempi MRS 49 (which had in general terrible sounds but "strings" that sounded astonishingly similar to launeddas!). Luckily I eventually managed to buy an Alesis QS8.2 first and a Roland RS-70 later.The latter kept me from insanity during my Engineering studies (far from home and from my piano) and later on.Last summer, after 12 looong years living without a properly-weighted piano, and after spending a year looking for a satisfying piano, I bought a Nord Grand and could not be happier with my choice!Now I can finally re-train my fingers on a proper keybed, enjoy the awesome Nord sounds and get back to where i left...Cheers to you all!

Daisy was Oscars first teacher, as their father (a CN Rail porter) could only afford one set of lessons.Love Hymn To Freedom, nice job! My very first musical memory as a young child is that Night Train album. Classic.D.

title: RE: Oscar peterson Cover - Nord stage 3 as a midi controller
post_content: Those are stories that I love. Thank you, D., for telling. I can only tell „a friend of mine knows Ian Paice“ or „another friend knows Jean Jacques Kravetz and Barbara Dennerlein“. I wish I had met one of the giants. About 30 years ago I had breakfast at an Helsinkian Hotel with the guitarist of Jerry Lee Lewis the day after I visited their intimate gig at the hotel bar. But no chance to get in contact with Jerry himself.

title: RE: Oscar peterson Cover - Nord stage 3 as a midi controller
post_content: Well we're mentioning being friends with well known, or at least world class, musicians:  my brother in law (well Ex BIL now but we're still friends and play together occasionally) is Tony Saunders. son of well known Bay Area B3 organist Merl Saunders (RIP) that played with Jerry Garcia in most of his outside projects from Grateful Dead since 1971 and were best of friends.  Merl was well known in jazz circles, played with Miles Davis, Bonnie Raitt, B.B. King.  Son Tony's first keyboard lesson was from family friend Herbie Hancock.  Sly Stone gave him an organ when he was 10.   He got into Bass when Tom Fogerty, John Fogerty's (both in Creedence Clearwater Revival) brother gave him a Fender Bass. He's played Bass with Stevie Wonder, Sly Stone. Jerry Garcia, David Crosby, Steve Stills, Eric Clapton, and Chaka Khan.  Oh, he's won 2 Emmy Awards also.  Good man, loves working and nurturing young musicians.  I was good friends, and kind of dated Jim Campilongo's sister.  Met Jim when I was a better guitar player than he decades ago.  No longer, not even close.  Mostly only guitar players know about Jim, one of the best Telecaster guitar players in the US.  He plays with Norah Jones, who had some big pop hits here in the US a while ago.  She's won 9 Grammy awards.

title: RE: My setup
post_content: The computer is running all my VSTs (list in my signature) - I can access any VST from either keyboard. I'm using Reaper as my DAW / VST host.The rack has a Fender power conditioner, Art Pro Audio 4 CH DI, M-Audio ProfFire interface and the Mac Mini computer.All the power in the rig leads back to the power conditioner so I just need one AC plug whereever I go. All the audio/midi cables are bundled in the back so setup time is not too bad. And it all fits into my Toyota Yaris!You can just see on the floor one half of the Yamaha StagePas 400i that I use for monitoring.I use the Nord mostly for pianos but I layer VSTs on it as well. Some tracks are playing back on the Mini for a few songs (percussion, extra synth parts etc)You should bring Chameleon (Herbie Hancock) for your band to try, we do it and people like it a lot, they will even dance to it.DH

title: RE: My setup
post_content: A museum/man-cave/intimate venue. Was actually a really nice evening for us. People brought their own wine and thus added to the ambience of the roomWe don't leap around much and now since we're all on IEM we're kind of tethered to one spot anyhow.I can have my rack on either side, my cabling permits it. I don't really need to touch it once the gig starts, I do everything (load/start songs, program changes etc) from the iPad or the top board - so I don't really care what side, depends on available space at whatever venue.Although again since we're now IEM I do tweak the mix (Behringer X18) once in a while - but works on both sides. You can see the Behringer X-Air app on the PC screen.DHBP

title: Introducing myself, and my new rig (with pictures)
post_content: Good evening Nord Forum!I started learning keyboard later in life, but it's been so much fun.  I began playing about a year and a half ago, and I've been playing every day since.  There's a group of us at work that get together and jam on fridays and that's done wonders for my playing.  I've played guitar for 25 years now, so switching to a new instrument has been very inspiring.Since I'm new to the keyboard, I wanted to give myself a project before I dropped a ton of money on a Nord, so I started building speakers and a keyboard stand.  Other than music, woodworking is my main hobby, so it was a natural fit.I started with the speakers, mahogany, roughly 2'x1'x1', it was my first foray into crossovers, but the internet is apparently full of wisdom these days.Then it was on to the stand, both the base and the top.  I wasn't sure if I was going for a two keyboard setup at first, but more storage is never a bad thing.Then the baseThen it was just a matter of putting it all together and making a few purchases:Here it is all buttoned up:And then here it is open and ready for business:I've only had my Stage 3 for a week, but I am so very impressed with it.  I think I'm all set for years to come.Thanks for watching.

title: RE: Introducing myself, and my new rig (with pictures)
post_content: Jason, what a sweet setup that is!Recessing your lighting into the lid is genius; loving the dovetail joinery on your cabs, too.(I can't help but wonder, how much downforce can your drawer take, fully extended?)

title: RE: Introducing myself, and my new rig (with pictures)
post_content: With the drawer fully extended, Jason has to be careful when he does his Jerry Lee Lewis covers.  All kidding aside, that is some sweet woodworking.  I wish I had one like it for my studio

title: RE: Introducing myself, and my new rig (with pictures)
post_content: Wow!

title: RE: Introducing myself, and my new rig (with pictures)
post_content: Thank you both for the kind words, I really appreciate it.I tend to have a lighter touch than Jerry Lee Lewis, but I was worried about the same thing when I started designing.  More than that I suppose, I didn't just want the drawer to be strong enough, I wanted it to have no wobble in it whatsoever.So, I drastically overbuild everything.  The locking drawer slides that I used aren't your usual drawer slides.  they're 3" tall and 3/4" thick and rated at up to 500 lbs.https://www.ovisonline.com/14-Locking-D ... P2412.aspxIn addition to the drawer slides, the drawer itself is designed to be very strong.  Made with a combination of 3/4 plywood and solid mahogany, its vaguely triangular in shape.  The front of the drawer is narrow so it doesn't knock into your knees when playing, but the back of the drawer is 3" thick.  Inside the drawer it's got support struts much like an airplane wing.  When I finished building it I stood on it and couldn't feel any flex in the drawer itself.  Here's a good shot of the profile on the drawer:Finally, none of that strength matters if the drawer slides aren't attached to the base the right way.  I was concerned about using screw in wood, since over time they might loosen.  So I put brass inserts into the base and bolted everything up tight.With all that done, I'm happy to say that there's no wobble or "bounce" at all in the final product.  If someone ever does something violent enough to break the drawer, the keyboard would have been damaged anyway.

title: Electro 3 Wurlitzer + Hammond + lead A1: Dick Laurent
post_content: Just wanted to share with you a song we just recorded (live in studio) with my band. I am using my good old electro 3 for Wurlitzer and Hammond (Hammond appears towards the end of the song). Wurlitzer is amped through my Jazz Chorus 160. The other board is the Prophet Rev2 which I use for bass. Hope you like it.

title: RE: Electro 3 Wurlitzer + Hammond + lead A1: Dick Laurent
post_content: I like it. The recording quality is excellent.I would like to hear a bit more hi hat in the mix.

title: RE: Electro 3 Wurlitzer + Hammond + lead A1: Dick Laurent
post_content: Nice one, the bass + wurly work great in that song.  Where's the keys solo?!  I remember you started out with NLA1 for bass.  Happy with the switch to the Rev2?  I've had one of those on my wish list for ages.

title: RE: Electro 3 Wurlitzer + Hammond + lead A1: Dick Laurent
post_content: CountFosco wrote:Nice one, the bass + wurly work great in that song.  Where's the keys solo?!  I remember you started out with NLA1 for bass.  Happy with the switch to the Rev2?  I've had one of those on my wish list for ages.Ha, thanks, keys solo comes in some of the other songs to be released soon, you can hear a snippet in dicklaurent.ch. Indeed, I also still have the Lead A1, but use that one mostly in my jam band for online sound-exploring. I never really got a bass fitting to our 70's sound out of the A1, but still love it for instant sound-creation. Rev2 is a very nice sounding instrument, but if you are used to Nord, you need to be prepared for a leap back in convenience of interface. Everything just takes time to set up on the Rev2 and many design choices just don't seem logical to me.@harmonizer: now you note it. Well, you probably know how it goes with mixing, right? At some point you can't really hear it anymore. We recorded in Helium records, Basel, very nice experience.

title: Introducing myself
post_content: Hello!I actually found out about this forum in January from my new Electro 6D printed manual!I had piano lessons as a kid but from my teen years onwards it was all about the electric guitar. Then around 2001 I joined a band where was asked to play keys, too. I had to buy a board! I went throug a few big name entry level synths, until an Electro 2 felt just right. It was all I needed, easy to transport, no deep menu diving, just set and play!This year it finally was time to update. With the 6D I love the acoustic pianos, it's added versatility and its limitations, too! And from this forum I have learned many tips e.g. how to layer sounds and make a synth sound interesting without a pitch bend and a mod wheel.

title: Introducing myself
post_content: Hi everyone,My name is Joe, I am from England and have been playing the Piano since I was 7. I’ve played keyboards in a couple of bands and for a few years have been thinking of buying a Nord (actually the Stage 2, when I first began dreaming).I finally have the cash together and will be buying a Stage 3 in the near future, so hopefully will be able to get hints and tips here. The only thing I am currently scratching my head about though, is which Stage 3 to buy. Aside, obviously from the physical sliders on the compact version and the different lengths of keyboard, is there anything Else I should be considering before taking the plunge. Thanks in advance.Rambleshanks

title: RE: Introducing myself
post_content: Aside from budget, length, weight and physical drawbars, the only other real question is action.  Do you prefer to play on a weighted or semi weighted action?  The semi weighted is a good compromise if you're leaning more towards organ, synth and EP, but also want to be able to play acoustic piano sometimes.  The weighted actions are kind of necessary if your focus is playing acoustic piano (or if you're happy playing other sounds on a weighted keyboard).

title: RE: Introducing myself
post_content: Welcome!And yes, the answer really depends upon your needs.My primary interest is a portable alternative to the Hammond, with some piano and synth needs, so I’ve been a compact user (2, now 3) for five years now.

post_content: You should really try out the different actions -  Weight and action are the two questions when it comes to choosing witch Nord Stage 3.   Welcome to a friendly forum!
