title: SONIC FORMS
post_content: Brand newDynamic Synthesisalbum is here:Sonic environments | ORbits for public and private spacesRoland Kuit - KYMAIn the tradition of Takehiha Kosugi and Alvin Lucier, Kuit needs to explore the fundamental physics of acoustics whereby the concept of time and space as a vital continuum is morphed with its surroundings.In his lab, Kuit explored the behavior of orbiting Lissajous figures:Dynamic synthesis is used to create information streams on a van der Pol oscillator.A system of parametric equations: {\displaystyle x=A\sin(at+\delta ),\quad y=B\sin(bt),} x=A\sin(at+\delta ),\quad y=B\sin(bt)Design principles: balance, harmony, gradation, repetition, contrast, dominance.Design elements: line, shape, size, direction, texture, hue/toneA mutual relationship exists between the elements and their structure. The structure provides the elements with their specific, perhaps changing, meaning in nano timbre/ time.This information comes from so-called transients whereby the duration varies between a small part of a period, from 1 usec to 3 or 4 milliseconds.'Articulation' functioning as identity.This onset as impulse makes it possible to distinguish the identities of these sonic forms and transforming them to autonomous audio sculptures.The structure works as a context.The elements determine which structural measures they can be subjected to in order for their identity to be enhanced, for their meaning to be differentiated and extended.Roland Emile Kuit - KYMAiTUNEShttp://itunes.apple.com/nl/album/sonic-forms/1457276825AMAZONhttp://www.amazon.com/dp/B07PXNSH77/ref ... =1-1-spellSPOTIFYhttp://open.spotify.com/album/2j4bZMTHJ2AIG1jeFJPxICPreview SONY / The Orchard

title: RE: SONIC FORMS
post_content: For the "balance and harmony" better  listen to squeaky swings maybe,  its free and sounds so organic!

title: RE: SONIC FORMS
post_content: Ivan Jochner wrote:For the "balance and harmony" better  listen to squeaky swings maybe,  its free and sounds so organic!No, that is a complex swing back & forth and.......... aside, but funnyIn your example, swings are used in many engineered objects, such as clocks, metronomes, amusement park rides and earthquake seismometers. In addition, engineers know that understanding the physics of how pendulums behave is an important step towards understanding motion, gravity, inertia and centripetal force.P = period; which is the time for one pendulum swing [sec]l = length from the fixed point at the top of the pendulum to the center of mass of the bob [m]g = gravitational constant (9.8 m per sec2)π ≈ 3.14 (dimensionless constant)My approach is usingORBITSas concept. Integrating technology on a conceptual level, does not imply greater stylistic and aesthetic complexity. On the contrary,technology has the function of relocating the potential of creativity to a different conceptual realm. This relatively new situation has a direct impact on the ability to convey eclectic musical ideas and suddenly many more creative options are available. Again, effectiveness of the musical message is not related to the complexity of the concept itself. This relies on the context, the aesthetics and the function of the technology involved. From the standpoint of innovation, the ideas resulting from the use of technology are to be supported by substantial arguments to justify their novelty, as an attempt to merge musical developments with the technological.On PROSTUDIOMASTERSDownload:https://www.prostudiomasters.com/album/page/31963On KKBOX JapanDownload:https://www.kkbox.com/jp/ja/album/3sBG2 ... index.html

title: Introducing myself
post_content: Hi all,After some time of looking around here, time to introduce myself as I will be digging in some topic a bit deeper..My name is Roel, I have been playing keyboard and drums for a long time, and doing several live cover bands at the moment. I have been using Yamaha's all my live, from the early PSR, a 9000 pro, several clavinova's and stage piano's, until now only having my good old Yamaha Dx7s left.A couple of years ago I decided to switch to a Nord Stage 2ex, and never, ever regretted it. Although the deep menu's of the Yamaha will get familiar after using it for hours, the simple setup and user interface of the Nord is incredible. I loved the organ and piano sounds as well right away.After having troubles with the keys making noise on the 2EX 76, I swapped it for a stage 3 76 - unfortunately I was not told I could not transfer any of my programs. Took me a couple of weeks to redo everything, but I am back again. After the latest OS updates, finally having the right list view, dual keyboard options for complete panel B back, I am completely happy.Live, I use the Yamaha dx7 and Nord, connected via midi, and an iPad with ForScore and 1Chart. Besides, I use an Alesis Vortex keytar to play the Nord while walking the stage. In the near future, I am looking for:- some nice programs and patches for new covers we will play- knowledge how to completely setup the dx7 using the external Midi section of the Nord- knowledge on how to use iPad software to organise sheet music and directly setup the two keyboards.Please don't hesitate to contact if you see any need for it, and hope to get and find input for my questions!

title: RE: Introducing myself
post_content: Hi Roel,Welcome to the forum. One question: Are you happy with 1chart?Greets,Eumel

title: RE: Introducing myself
post_content: Hi Eumel,Yes, that works great. Best thing for our band is easy to share the native file with the guitar player, add my own notes to it and- be able to transpose the whole shabeng to another key- wich results in a perfect score just in another tonal key.What I do to prepare for a rehearsal with new covers, is just sitting with the iPad and 1chart, listen and write the scheme and notes. Able to write down chords as well as sheet music in a chart.Though, for a gig I export it to pdf s and use forScore. That give me better ability to sort, and (next thing I am sorting out...) to program the Nord and dx7 via midi.

title: first gig
post_content: Hi there,so I finally had my first gig as a keyboard player last weekend (I've played drums, guitar and bass on stage before - all in as mediocre a way as you can imagine). It was at a birthday party, three other bands were scheduled as well. We are doing Bob Dylan covers in rock, I play organ 90% of the time and a little piano or Rhodes. Usually I set up my MX61 as the lower manual, but I didn't want to haul around too much stuff this time (and I correctly figured it would be a small stage), so I just brought my NE3.onstage.jpg (239.95 KiB) Viewed 1540 timesAfter finding out that I best switch the left hand patch 1 octave up, everything went smoothly.

title: Whipping Post
post_content: This is my tribute to Gregg Allman and all the other Allman Brothers who are no longer with us. I'm playing all the instruments - drums were programmed in Logic Pro X (I'm just not good enough to play them live), bass is a Rickenbacker 4003, all guitars are a Squier Classic Vibe Telecaster and - most importantly for this forum - the organ is my trusty Nord Stage 2, done in pretty much one take. I can't sing like Gregg so I didn't bother trying. :-/I identify with the song because it describes my ex-wife quite well, although it sounds quite mean for me to say that.Whipping Post.mp3

title: Mixing Board Suggestion for Live Gig
post_content: I'm looking to upgrade my mixer for live performance.  I want to run in Stereo live so I'll need a L+R out to go into each powered monitor; I'll also need a main L+R out to go to the main mixer PA.I need at least 8 inputs so I can run my NS3, Kurzweil Artis, and Rack Mount Sound Module all in stereo and have room for extra if needed if I decide to add software synths to my rig in the future.  I do prefer full eq for each channel.Obviously need something that I can put on top of my rack.  There are so many out there. I like the simplicity of the Yamaha MG12Xu though it's kind of big and more expensive than the Mackie's and Behringher's.Any suggestions on what you folks are using that meets the above criteria?

title: RE: Mixing Board Suggestion for Live Gig
post_content: If you're using a rack, I would highly recommend a rack mixer. I've used one for many years and find that the mixer is mostly a "set it and forget it" device and it is so much easier to have it permanently racked vs. dealing with a tabletop style mixer.Is there any reason you're not considering a rackmount mixer? There are several flexible solutions. I really like my Ashly.

title: RE: Mixing Board Suggestion for Live Gig
post_content: +1 for Ashly LX-308 B, 8 stereo inputs, sub in, sub out, main out, mono out, built like a tank.  Mine is 12 years old and still going strong, not a single issue.https://www.sweetwater.com/store/detail ... kvEALw_wcB-dj

title: RE: Mixing Board Suggestion for Live Gig
post_content: I have the Tascam LM-8ST and it's great too.

title: RE: Mixing Board Suggestion for Live Gig
post_content: I want full eq control as I'll only send 2 outs into the main board. I want to be able to have my own eq and effects and just send the feed to the mains for the PA and my on stage monitor. I would prefer a rack mixer; but the only ones appear to be digital and take up 2-3 rack spaces (would require me to get another rack).

title: RE: Mixing Board Suggestion for Live Gig
post_content: All of my keyboards have EQ and Effects built in, so it is not necessary for the mixer to have these in my case--dj

title: RE: Mixing Board Suggestion for Live Gig
post_content: A single space rack mixer is what you need. No need to worry about EQ etc.

title: RE: Mixing Board Suggestion for Live Gig
post_content: I use a Behringer X32 Rack.Along with 16 input channels, it's also an audio interface.I set-up multiple buses/outputs: L/R (FOH), Click Track, Playback for intro tracks i.e Pink Floyd.I also have our sound guy send me a stereo monitor mix which I then route to another bus/output for my IEMs and QSC 8.2.You can also set-up different Scenes for different rig configurations. I have different scenes for Home Studio, Rehearsals and then live.Pretty much a one-stop shop for me.

title: RE: Mixing Board Suggestion for Live Gig
post_content: The X32 Live sound card is a real bargain too.....no more need for a laptop to record or soundcheck.

title: RE: Mixing Board Suggestion for Live Gig
post_content: I use Behringer Xenyx 1002b with 4 stereo + 2 mono (used for my DAW input atm). Quality-wise not the best but it does what it does and its really cheap.

title: Buying a New Mac Book Pro
post_content: I want to buy a New Mac Book Pro and I was thinking about the 13" with the 2.3GHz dual-core 7th-generation Intel Core i5 processor, but my question is if the i5 is powerful enough to run a DAW, VST or softsynth and samples, or do I nned the i7 ?

title: RE: Buying a New Mac Book Pro
post_content: I asked the same question about the Mac Mini a while back and get responds that the I5 is powerfull enough ....So, with the new generation, it shouldn't be an issue....But I'm not the king of computer though....

title: RE: Buying a New Mac Book Pro
post_content: I had to replace my aging dual-Core 13“ because it couldn’t handle the MainStage load I was throwing at it.Went quad-Core because I really don’t want to have to think about it, and haven’t looked back.

title: RE: Buying a New Mac Book Pro
post_content: You won't put iZotope Ozone on all the tracks and play live with zero latency, an i7 would not be enough, neither.+ 1 with analogika, go up (i7, quad core) if possible, you'll have more power for plugins.

title: RE: Buying a New Mac Book Pro
post_content: It really depends, as everyone said, on what you're doing and how many VSTs of what kind. I have a quad-core iMac retina with i7 and I still can't load it up with tons of plugins (I use a lot of Arturia V Collection) at 64 sample buffer. You can always tradeoff buffer (latency) for performance, to a point, but that really depends on your workflow. If you're 99% "in the box" and so input/output latency is less of a concern, then you can *probably* get away with a fast i5. But the CPU clock speed, more than the i5/i7 difference, is what you're going to want to take advantage of in this case. The math in most of these audio plugins is pretty simple and they usually aren't fully accelerated for SIMD and other tricks (though, sometimes, they are). But, it's technology. It costs a LOT and it becomes obsolete quickly, and it's never quite "fast enough" to do everything we want. Will the i7 "feel" like it's worth the money in the end? Probably not. Will the i5 be fast enough to do what you want? Only you can get a feeling for that answer. But the i7 will have a slightly higher resale value in the end (depending on how many years from now you sell it of course) and will probably be useful to you for longer, so if you're able to swing it, I don't see a reason not to.

title: RE: Buying a New Mac Book Pro
post_content: Just have one question, is the difference between a 2.2GHZ 6-Corei7 and a 2.6GHz 6-Core i7 very substantial ? is 2.2 powerful enough or would I need 2.6 ?

title: RE: Buying a New Mac Book Pro
post_content: Your mileage may vary, but a lot of what I do is not parallelized and so raw single-core speed is much more useful. Some DAWs do a very good job of using all the cores (I don't know which, offhand, but I would assume Logic should do that since it's an Apple product), but Ableton Live seems to need a mix of raw speed and cores to do a good job, and too much of either at the expense of the other is less good than a balance between the two. For reference, I'm using a 4GHz 4-core right now, and while my CPU meter rarely goes over 50%, I can easily force dropouts with low buffer sizes (64 and under) - this means only 2 of my four cores are used (the rough 50% loading) but they're fully used (hence the dropouts). My laptop, which has a 3.something GHz 2-core, will sit at nearly 70% CPU but perform about equally with the 4-core on the same Live project. This makes me think the number of cores in Live is less important than the CPU speed.Personally I find clock speed is more important than total cores. I would prefer a 4-core 2.6 over a 6 core 2.2. I find the number of cores doesn't translate as well to latency and VST performance as do the CPU raw speed, but that's my experience with my DAWs and video editing tools, again, YMMV.

title: RE: Buying a New Mac Book Pro
post_content: +1 for all the answers, I do a lot of out of the box, mixing on a real board, no plugins, well just an UAD but on an external HD, external reverb, compressor and so in, so....I5 is OK for me....

title: RE: Buying a New Mac Book Pro
post_content: Yes, within reason. I use that for my most common tasks all the time and have no issues with memory pressure.

title: RE: Buying a New Mac Book Pro
post_content: Any current MacBook Pro is good but get the i7 + 16GB if you want to run fun VSTs or effects.  Cypher2 with the LinnStrument runs much better on the current MacBook Pro than it did the previous generation, which was also a max'd out i7 w/ 16GB (they're both 1TB SSDs).

title: Sound research into space with NASA
post_content: Roland Kuit's sonic research:These sound research examples will be send to space by NASA integrated in the OSIRIS-REx Mission in September 8, 2016.(image by NASA)MISSION TO BENNUThe first U.S. mission to return samples from an asteroid to Earth, addressing multiple NASA Solar System Exploration objectives.THE MISSION:The OSIRIS-REx Mission seeks answers to questions that are central to the human experience: Where did we come from? What is our destiny? OSIRIS-REx is going to Bennu, a carbon-rich asteroid that records the earliest history of our Solar System, and will be bringing a piece of it back to Earth. Bennu may contain the molecular precursors to the origin of life and the Earth’s oceans. Bennu is also one of the most potentially hazardous asteroids and has a relatively high probability of impacting the Earth late in the 22nd century. OSIRIS-REx will determine Bennu’s physical and chemical properties, which will be critical for future scientists to know when developing an impact mitigation mission.OSIRIS-REx is scheduled to launch in September and travel to the asteroid Bennu. The #WeTheExplorers campaign invites the public to take part in this mission by expressing, through art, how the mission’s spirit of exploration is reflected in their own lives. Submitted works of art will be saved on a chip on the spacecraft.

title: RE: All round coverband, what setup?
post_content: I'm using both a Kronos 2 and a Stage 3 Compact with ForScore running on an iPad pro.  Each have wireless Bluetooth MIDI and I send patch changes to each keyboard to queue up the next song based on my lead sheet.  I have presets setup on songs for solos and just touch my iPad to switch patches quickly.  I don't really read the Lead Sheets for the chords, just use it as a place holder for the songs in the set and to send patch changes.Works like a champ!

title: RE: All round coverband, what setup?
post_content: Thank you all for your replies.A lot of you use Set List Maker or Bandhelper. I'm also looking to those apps but something is really clear.During a gig I would like to use in some songs (not all) a backing track. It can be a midi file or an audio file. When using a backing track I would also like to use a click track for the drummer. So I will use a audio interface to separate the output channel for the click track and the backing track. Both apps can support this.Can both apps start a click track? And if yes, can it sync with the backing track? It would be logical if it can tempo sync with a midi backing track, but an audio track???How do you use backing tracks?

title: RE: All round coverband, what setup?
post_content: I asked that few times to Arlo Leach and never really understood how it was going to work, syncking a click AND an audio track at the same time, knowing that the audio track could be recorded at 120.33 and the click being set at 120 only. He walked me through the website and some emails, he's very good at helping but it was not making sense for me just to start the click from the Ipad on Bandhelper and assuming the other audio track wil be in Sync. So, I bought a Drumbrute, it has a click/metronome that could be removed from the audio output if you plug a headphone into the headphone output.I have the ipad sending the click/metronome to the drummer from the Drumbrute, the click form bandhelper, just the click and I also use the Nord beat apps to trigger a Proteus 2000 classic drum samples...I don't sync them, the drummer has a little Mackie Mix 8, I send/connect all the different clicks he has to follow and dependign on the song, he has always at least one click, coming from the metronome on the drumbox, or the click from the ipad if I didn't need to program any drumbrute pattern for the song, or the sound for the Proteus 2000.Complicated but works like a charm...I think I could have sent a midi clock to the drumbrute a swell, but that doesn't solve your click+audio tracks anyway....Is bandhelper is analysing the tempo of the audio track and adapt it to the tempo of the Ipad/bandhelper click, or the opposite like it does when we slow down a song???Maybe but never did it, sorry.

title: RE: All round coverband, what setup?
post_content: I try now Ableton.Ableton has to help me durings gigs with backing tracks, click tracks and program changes.In Ableton you have session view and arrangement view. During a gig I want to start fast a new song in Ableton and not always have to open a new Live set. So using the scenes in session view seems to be a good option.But I use audio files of for example 8 measures. This audio file has tocplay for example as intro and the next time after 80 measures. This is in session view difficult to make. In arrangement view very easy, but there are no scenes and you have to open for every song a new set.How do you use Ableton on stage and do you have tips for my problem?

title: RE: All round coverband, what setup?
post_content: HI,Sorry I missed your last message.Indeed, the session view is the way to go in my opinion. (That's how I used it anyway)It allows you to trigger scenes that can be part of songs, entire songs, whatever you want. With clicks, samples, with their own tempo and everything...With every scene being able to send midi messages, program changes... etc...Sweet memories of a time I could do soooo much more with Ableton and a midi keyboard than with my NS2exYet I'm not going back... But that's another discussion.Many workaround for your issue.Have one scene with your 8 mesures intro + 80 silent mesures + your sound again. -> One trigger lauches the whole song.Or have different scenes (ex: one for intro, another for outro) and trigger them with a controller, a note, a pad, a pedal, whatever... at the right moent (so if you miss or add a mesure somewhere in the song, you're not screwed at mesure 80 because you're not in sync anymore)Or have different scenes with informations on what to automaticaly do after playing. So that after scene "Intro" is played, it automaticaly plays scene "Blank" for 80 mesures, then passes to scene "Outro". So only one trigger but three differents scenes.... There are probably other ways...

title: Sonic artist Roland Emile Kuit at ICAE2018
post_content: To mark the 100th anniversary of the foundation of the First Armenian Republic, Yerevan will host the “International Contemporary Art Exhibition: Armenia 2018. Soundlines of Contemporary Art”, which from September 25 to October 25 will engage the capital city with more than fifty international artists exhibiting in seven different locations around the city…“Soundlines of Contemporary Art”, curated by Mazdak Faiznia and Marina Hakobyan and created and organized by Shaula International LLC, is held under the high patronage of the Presidency of Armenia and the patronage of the Canadian Government, the Ministry of Culture of Armenia, the Ministry of Cultural Activities and Tourism of Italy, the cultural promotional project of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Italy Vivere All’italiana, the Italian Embassy in Armenia. The event is further supported by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Armenia, the EU Delegation to Armenia and the Armenian General Benevolent Union (AGBU).Composer and sonic artist Roland Emile Kuit at the Aram Khachaturian MuseumComposer and sonic artist Roland Emile Kuit is considered a pioneer of the art form generally referred to as “sound installation”. He taught this form of audio art at the Vrije Academie The Hague, and introduced this sonic art to the installation area. A metamorphosis from the traditional speaker boxes into ‘sonic spaces’.Kuit’s sonic work ranges from experimental sound-architectural installations to acousmatic performances, often in cooperation with artists, designers and scientists. Kuit is researching chaotic systems, sound at atomic levels, morphology and decision-making processes beyond algorithm and stochastic approaches.Kuit lectures, performs/exhibits worldwide at universities, art galleries, museums and creative hubs.ACRYLIC INTONATIONS – Roland Emile KuitKuit was this year at the SONO Studios in Prague recording his latest work ‘Tactile Utterance’ for Tomas Rajlich with the Fama Q String Quartet. Kuit had the opportunity  to record a painting Tomas Rajlich in his atelier. For this occasion, Kuit had brought his ZOOM H6 recorder and connected 4 contact microphones to the canvas. As Rajlich was working, proportioning out and shaping the acrylic paint, Kuit managed to seize this sonic autograph in paint of Tomas Rajlich.These recordings were taken back to the Netherlands to Kuit’s studio. Here he had to find ways to deal with these raw recordings. The idea was to create a quadraphonic sonic art space by processing the material into sonic art. Roland used the Kyma system to analyse these sounds in the spectral realm.As Rajlich is modifying the appearance, hardness, flexibility, texture, and other characteristics of the paint surface, Kuit had to find a way to work likewise. Kuit’s idea of working in the spectral realm is that he can add more ways to deconstruct sound. He has now the possibility to separate frequencies, amplitudes and time, reconstructing sounds composing new textures.Kuit created from acrylic sounds the spectra used by Oscillator Banks of 256 separate oscillators. Each oscillator is associated with a partial from the time-varying spectrum given in the Spectrum field. As a result this data is modulated and articulated into the ‘sonic space’. Air as canvas, acrilyc has a voice now.The exhibition will have an official catalogue in two volumes and in English, published by Manfredi Edizioni, with opening sections by the President of the Republic of Armenia, the Minister of Culture of Armenia, the curators Mazdak Faiznia and Marina Hakobyan, and Shaula International LLC.http://donemus.nl/sonic-artist-roland-e ... -icae2018/http://panarmenian.net/m/eng/news/258074

title: RE: Sonic artist Roland Emile Kuit at ICAE2018
post_content: Minister of Culture Armenia Lilit Makunts formally welcomes ICAE2018 Composer - Sonic Artist Roland KuitAt Hay Art Mshakutayin Cucasrah Kentron, YerevanNEW SONIC FORMS"As a European based composer - sonic artist, I am approaching Yerevan with an open ear, not knowing what to hear, meet or find here. I feel the philosophy and arts have roots into the long history of this country. Armenia proofs with the TUMO Center where education, culture and science meet in such a special way, that this form of learning is working and even expanse to other counties through the world.I find this mindset in the ICAE2018 of Shaula International LLC too.A courageous way to blend new forms in arts and new cultures in this wonderful event "Soundlines of Contemporary Art".As composer - artist, I am creating new forms by sound research and morphology. My exhibition in the A. Khachaturian House Museum will be a perfect audible example for under these colors as I blend painting and sound together in the audio sculpture "Acrylic Intonations". For this occasion I recorded the painting proces of Tomas Rajlich. By analizing these sounds, I could re-synthesis these processes into a new form whereby time, frequency, amplitude and space are dealt with seperately, and therefore having the possibilliy to seize new sonic shapes.Thank you ICEA2018 for such an exciting amalgamation of the International Arts. My gratitude towards the A. Khachaturian House Museum, one of the seven locations of this exhibition, such beautifull environment for this dialogue in art." - Roland Kuit

title: RE: Sonic artist Roland Emile Kuit at ICAE2018
post_content: Wednesday 24th October 2018 23:00 C.E.T.The Yerevan Metro Installation, a phenomenological approach.Between 10th and 21th September ICAE2018 sonic artist Roland Kuit and Karin Schomaker held a workshop with the students at the TUMO Center for Art and Technology. How to create a sound art installation?The students recorded the Yerevan metro system and edited these sounds with computers. F.i. to hear the emotion of, in the environmental sounds, the data was down pitched and the fundamentals (the frequencies we hear the objects of sounds) were filtered away. The residues were the upper harmonics, now in reach of our hearing, could be molded into a new language by these young students. All resulted into this installation at the top floor of the TUMO Center Yerevan, Armenia......https://www.concertzender.nl/programma/ ... es_467863/

post_content: ICAE2018 - The making of THE EXHIBITION"Between the 1st of September and the 28th of September all the team of ICAE2018 had a fantastic time cooperating closely with several artists that came to Armenia to produce their artworks, take part into workshops and be present at the opening ceremony of the International Contemporary Art Exhibition: Armenia 2018. title: RE: Sonic artist Roland Emile Kuit at ICAE2018
post_content: Hardly the same thing, but perhaps a distant relative, the memorial constructed at the site of the Oklahoma City bombing contains, among many other important elements, an inscription:We come here to remember those who were killed, those who survived and those changed forever.May all who leave here know the impact of violence.May this memorial offer comfort, strength, peace, hope and serenity.(emphasis added)  These are places of great emotional power.  Yet the world seemingly continues in this downward spiral of violence in many places.  True enlightenment seems further away now than it has at any point during my ~60 years on this planet.  Violence cannot be cured with more violence...

title: Songs with my Lead A1
post_content: Here is a new song, I´ve performed with my Lead A1 and Korg Kross 2.That´s the way I play at home. Bass and step sequence line comes from Korg´s sequencer, drums by it´s drum track which I can start individually.A1 is split in pads left and lead right. Kross is split like that, too. That way I have two pad and two lead sounds available without switching.All lead sounds and one pad comes from A1. I share ny patches at Dropbox.https://www.dropbox.com/sh/jy8lr67jsojx ... JokTa?dl=0Sorry, I´m not attractive anymore for being present in the video.Kind regards from Austria,Herbert

title: RE: Songs with my Lead A1
post_content: Oohoooo, Pupka, all your patches are in Dropbox, there is so many of them, thanks a lot...Pupka is a very prolific guy, he doesn't participate that much on discussion on the forum, maybe he's also a discrete guy, at least according to the photo but he's so nice to share all the patches and his work....Thanks a lot, I have no NLA1 but I wanted to make the point that this kind of attitude is very appreciated....Well, a lot of people do that as well on this forum and that's why it's a great place to be....SincerelyPS: and the songs are very good!!!

title: RE: Songs with my Lead A1
post_content: Thanks for the nice feedback, Quai34!I respect our colleagues, who rather sell their patches and I often buy them as inspiration, even lots of them don´t fit my style of composing.For me personally I have a lot of fun with editing and I like to share it. I do same with my other synth´s patches, and I´m astonished, as example what you can squeeze out of an "entry level" workstation as the Kross 2.A1 for me is one of the most versatile synths at the current market. 4 parts multitimbral (which I use regulare when recording up to four sounds simultaneously), 24 voices, 47 oscillator basic waveforms, split, great FX, ....and is editable as an good old analog, being able to edit without a deeper knowledge of subtractive synthesis (editing a menu diving synth as the Kross means you need to know exactly what you want to change.Regarding my forum activity, also a victim of gear aquisition syndrom (GAS), I´ve learned to concentrate composing and recording instead of discussing gear. I like to write, when I have the feeling,  that I can share some new infos that might help.Sharing my composition might help choosing the gear, that´s why I mention it at my videos.Kind regards,Herbert

title: RE: Songs with my Lead A1
post_content: Quick questions. How long does your Nord Lead a1 take to boot up once you've pressed on/off button at the back?Is your Nord lead a1 warm at the top panel near the power cable power supply area then its in use?

title: RE: Songs with my Lead A1
post_content: 1.) About 2 seconds, the delay unit of the power supply prevents cracking when turning on.2.) Power supply is situatet at this position, so it can be warm there.I´ve just finished a video playing live with A1 using split and Korg Kross 2.

title: RE: My lovely ones at my last gig
post_content: Quai34 wrote:Whoaaa, a girl who smiles at the keyboard player, THAT is awesome....and a lovely one....On a different note, are you sure you can access all the control of the Stage 2?And what is the first unit in the rack? An Audio interface for your computer/main stage? And why do you need a patchbay? You cannot wire everything at the back?Yeah that's amazing, and I didn't even pay her to do soAll my programs (both NS2 and NE4D) are controlled by Bandhelper (like Setlistmaker). So I switch programs (in a setlist) with a pedal connected with bluetooth to my ipad.So that's why I don't need to look. If I need something to change, I'll just have a quick peek in between the boards.The top unit is indeed an audio interface: A Focusrite Scarlett 18i20. Not using it atm for live (only for recording, but maybe later). The patchbay is used to connect both the DI (direct input) and audio interface to both my boards. Yeah.... I could have used the link option in my DI, but it's just a failsafe if the Behringer DI *cough* stops working.So I quickly can reroute my signal to something else if needed.

title: "One man band" using my NS3 (Rihanna, Moloko tunes etc.)
post_content: Hi dear forumites,after my recent80s pop videoI recorded some more contemporary pop tunes as piano instrumentals, this time also using live foot percussion to create beats:My NS3 is setup like this:- Left side of the split (which btw is set to "large" overlap, that makes playing so much more fun!) is a layer of a double bass sample and the "imperial" grand sample (with decreased hi-freqs using the "soft" setting).- Right hand side is a layer of a nice synth sample (with a MOD envelope controlled filter sweep) combined with the main sound: a Rhodes Mark I (with 3,7 kHz boosted by 9 dB for more "bell") for "Sing It Back", and an upright piano for the other two songs ("Umbrella" / "Euphoria"). Who guesses what .npno sample it is?It's just great to have an instrument that sounds so fantastic!Happy regards to all!Alex

title: RE: "One man band" using my NS3 (Rihanna, Moloko tunes etc.)
post_content: Sounds great, Alex!  I see what you did there, with your OLEDs.So the pedal-triggered sounds - did you map them manually to your NS3 sample, zone them somehow, or something else?

title: RE: "One man band" using my NS3 (Rihanna, Moloko tunes etc.)
post_content: PScooter63 wrote:Sounds great, Alex!  I see what you did there, with your OLEDs.Had to cover them. The flickering on the video recording is very distracting. Unfortunately, my cam (Sony HDR MV1) has no option to change the recording frequency, which might help to get rid of the flickering I guess...PScooter63 wrote:So the pedal-triggered sounds - did you map them manually to your NS3 sample, zone them somehow, or something else?The left foot plays a cheapjingle ring, recorded by aShure Beta 91mic. My right foot plays a "Finhol Kickbox", that's  basically a stomp box, but it's not analog, it triggers a digital sample (cajon sound) internally. I just roll off the high frequencies to get a decent kick drum sound.

title: City scapes Paris- Amsterdam
post_content: 2018.04.25 23:00 C.E.T. Electronic Frequencies:City scapes: Paris – AmsterdamSonic art and environmentalsComposer and sonic artist Roland Kuit has been exploring and broadening the language of sound for over 25 years. In search of new forms of listening Kuit started to create synthetic sonic environments in the ’90’s. Resulting in sound exhibitions in art galleries followed by publications in art magazines as l’Orbe and Avenue Magazine, Sound On Sound Magazine and WIRED. To free these sonic concepts from the traditional speaker boxes Kuit began the transition of his sounds into installations:1/ Paris (for Orbe magazine nr. 9. Music machine), Roland Kuit,1998Roland Emile Kuit is a composer of contemporary music whose works can be purchased at Ircam from the Center Georges Pompidou in Paris. This classical musician uses the flute, the harp, the bassoon, but also the direct sound recording (atmospheres of public places, interviews …). He also uses a computer with echo chambers with frequency modulation to work the sound as one carves the clay. The original audio CD of 20 ’32 “entitled Paris traces the wanderings of Kuit within this capital. The sounds of the Metro, the words of the students at the university campus, the winter and the melancholy of the lonely bassoon distorted by the computer are all distinguished.2/ Amsterdam (for Avenue Magazine, uitgave #5 VOL.2 Amsterdam inside out), Roland Kuit, 1995The canals as a blue waterline though this piece. Pigeons flying up and the sound of their wings morphing to the cadence of a street organ. The bells of the Wester tower and tourists. The Vondelpark and markets salesmen. F.C. Ajax football supporters and the harbor control. The water of the canals closes this city scape.3/ Topographic City textures, Roland Kuit, 2018Scanned city topographics from a morphed and annealed Paris and Amsterdam. Modified spectral sonic textures as a sonic landscape.Concertzender City scapes Paris - Amsterdam

post_content: Hi everybody, I am Venus, from Iceland and just got my first Nord Stage 2 HA88 and couldn't be happier with it !Of course it's a lot to begin with ( not use to this kind of keyboards) that I am diving right into it and it is delightful, at first I thought about buying a new MIDI keyboard to compose symphonic music on my computer but I have found this baby and it is so much fun to play with !Can't wait to manage my own libraries and make it like homeIt gave me a true will to go live with it as well ! So, " you come and play but I don't move anything anymore for a practice....". I hope you will enjoy it...sincerelyhttps://photos.app.goo.gl/7O6B2BG1UCIKhrb02

post_content: Just... mind-blowing!Is all that stuff yours? Even the guitars and basses with their effects and amps?

title: RE: New practice room in the basement
post_content: Yes....I was for 3 years 1500 km away from my family for Job and then, no other stuff to do on my spare time than play music....And spend $$ for gears...And it was a small town (15.000 people) with only military and Oil Workers (Cold Lake, AB, canada), so, it was difficult to find people to play with....One of the solution I found was to tell them "hey, you got the skills, I got the gear, just come and play"....So, now, with my new band, the bassist and guitarist will use my Amps and my pedalboards and they are happy and I am too....But somes are Stuffs that I have for years like the old TC pedals or ABY box...So instead of letting them taking dust in a box, I decide to put them operational on a pedalboard....For the basses and guitars, I found really good deals from people who had 30 guitars (the two G@L ASAT I bought...) and 18 basses...Yes, I saw them!!!! They were collecting them but we're always going back to the same so, they decided to sell few of them at crazy low price with an almost new state....So lucky me....I'm not going to give my kids a lot of money when I will pass away but they will have good gear if their kids decide to play music....I see myself in the future as the "Music Grandpa...". Anyway, thanks for the nice comments...Sincerely

title: RE: New practice room in the basement
post_content: Really nice setup !!!!!Regards

title: RE: New practice room in the basement
post_content: Very nice and clean !

title: RE: New practice room in the basement
post_content: Very impressive practice room.  A dream for any small band.  One question - do you MIDI all the boards to the lowest one and use that as master keyboard, or do you use all the keybeds?  - I easily get problems with my neck if I try to play in awcward positions - but maybe I am more exposed since I work with computers all day long...

title: RE: New practice room in the basement
post_content: I wanted to make sure I could reach all the boards with my hands even in a seating position, so, yes, they are all midfied to each other on a A880 Roland Midi Patchbay that has memory so, Bandhelper in my ipad sent not only program changes for all the synths I use for a song but also the configuration of the A880 like who is the master, who is the slave. So even a sound played on the top P08 with the right hand let me use the Stage 2 with left hand....But when I practice/prepare for a song, I'm trying to use one side of the "L" or the Other, I mean Stage + D50 and NL2X or C2 + P12 + P08.I thought I wa done with 3 keys (the NL2X was planned to be bought the day I bought the Stage 2, Pablo was,a good adviser on this one) with the D50 Imhad for years....And I found a C2 with a so good to pass deal....The P08 was the Synth of my dreams for years and when they discounted it due to the release of the Prophet 6, I bought it ....thought I was done but a P12 new from a store where the guy brought it back after 2 weeks, "not my thing" he said,,,well it was mine....That's it for the story but I have a lot of fun with the set up.Sincerely

title: Playing a *Real* Fazioli 9ft Grand Piano! Beautiful sound!
post_content: Hi guys,I am relatively new to this forum but I am already finding it really helpful, so thanks!I recently was very lucky to get an opportunity to record my Jazz Piano trio at Fieldgate studios in the UK where they have a 9ft Fazioli Grand. Its probably the best sounding Grand Piano Ive ever played (I have played a Steinway Model D in college which is also incredible but I think i prefer the Fazioli), with a beautiful, clear 'pearly'  sound with great clarity throughout the whole range of the instrument. Obviously the Nord XL sample of the Fazioli does a good job but in reality, hearing and playing the actual instrument itself brings a whole level of detail to the sound and keyboard action and response that you cannot replicate!Here is a video of me playing the Piano with my Jazz trio:We play the great Tommy Flanagan calypso tune, "Eclypso" from the seminal hard-bop album "The Cats" recorded in 1957 (another great year for Jazz) originally featuring John Coltrane. One of my favourite versions of the tune is from Flanagan's vibey "Overseas" Piano trio album from the same year. It also features some fantastic drum and brush work from Elvin Jones.The mic pre that was used was a Forssell smp-2, not sure what the mics were.Comments and Critiques welcome

title: RE: Playing a *Real* Fazioli 9ft Grand Piano! Beautiful sound!
post_content: Whooaaa, good for you, when I was talking jazz lessons at the conservatory, one time per month I had the opportunity to play on the Steinway grand piano at the concert hall of the conservatory, it was amazing....So, I feel very well what you describe...thanks for your post...Sincerely

title: RE: Playing a *Real* Fazioli 9ft Grand Piano! Beautiful sound!

title: RE: Playing a *Real* Fazioli 9ft Grand Piano! Beautiful sound!
post_content: If you look on the sample download page, Nord describe the sample as a 'medium' sized grand... a 9ft Grand is not a medium sized piano, its around as big as they come.http://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-libr ... lian-grandThe picture suggests it is more like the F228 if you compare the Nord picture with the ones on the Fazioli website, which ties in with the 'medium' description.http://www.fazioli.com/en/pianoforti/indexAlso the sample itsself doesnt strike me as a 9ft piano with a thundering bass like the Steinway and the Bosendorfer samples do.So overall I wouldn't say 'Italian Grand' is a 9ft model sample from the clues given.

title: Co-production of two forum members via Internet
post_content: Hi folksCristian from Romania, forum member "Criss" and me in Austria had the idea to produce one song together, sending the parts via Internet.The arp and lead at the bridge and after is played by Criss, pads and the lead before the bridge is played by me.We have been using Nord Lead A1, Novation Ultranova and Basstation 2.That was fun and we´d like to continue.Kind regards,Herbert

title: RE: Co-production of two forum members via Internet
post_content: Nice idea. Nice result.

title: RE: Co-production of two forum members via Internet
post_content: Thanks Puukka. Some nice sounds in there. I have been curious about the Ultranova for some time. It seems to have some good sounds and the price is quite low compared to other synths. Any comments?

title: RE: Co-production of two forum members via Internet
post_content: At this song I used the pads of the Ultranova.The Ultranova having 3 octaves, no split, only being monotimbral wouldn´t be a sustitute of the A1, but a cheap add-on.It also has a very good and mighty FX section with 5 effects you can use same time. It´s strength are lively and spheric pads and leads, which are not replicable completely at the A1. I tried several but at the end, some of the sounds at the Ultranova, especially using the mighty modulation possibilities or wavetables, kept unique. No wonder, 3 Oscillators, 3 LFOs 6 EGs, 20 Modulation paths...So I recommend it for it´s mighty synth engine and sound.On the other side I don´t like it´s plastic design and the few, wobbly knobs, but sound rules.Kind regards,Herbert

title: RE: Co-production of two forum members via Internet
post_content: By the way, this was my attempt to recreate some of my favorite Ultranova patches. Simple pads and lead works fine, bass and arp sounds no problem, spheric pads and leads I like more at the UN.http://www.norduserforum.com/nord-lead- ... 14470.htmlKind regards,Herbert

title: ATLAS V ripples in SPACE
post_content: All sounds are composed from a NASA Atlas V recording.The Atlas V family, which includes the flight-proven Atlas V 400 and 500 series, are the latest evolutionary versions of the Atlas launch system. Atlas V uses a standard common core booster™ (CCB), up to five strap-on solid rocket boosters (SRB), an upper-stage Centaur in either the Single-Engine Centaur (SEC) or the Dual-Engine Centaur (DEC) configuration, and one of several payload fairings (PLF). A three-digit (XYZ) naming convention is used for the Atlas V 400 and 500 series.This recording is to celebrate one year NASA’s mission OSIRIS-REx. The OSIRIS-REx was launched on 8 September 2016. It has been traveling for more than a billion kilometers though space to grab a sample of dust from the astroid 101955 Bennu. NASA is hoping to find the origins of this universe in these molecules. The OSIRIS-REx will plant a chip containing art while taking the sample. On this chip works of sound art and sound research of the composer-sonologist Roland Kuit. This work is a journey and an ode to the rocket Atlas V.Atlas V Ripples in SPACE – Roland Emile Kuit, 2017Used sounds from NASA Soundcloud under Ceative Commons-Licencee:Rocket Engine Sounds: Atlas V LaunchApollo 11: We Have a Lift-OffRoland Kuit - KymaFree download, Happy Holidays!http://archive.org/details/ATLASVRipplesInSPACE

title: RE: Rig I used this Summer;Since modified
post_content: Looks great! Needs more red!

title: RE: Rig I used this Summer;Since modified
post_content: Looks very impressive -  but a question from an amateur for you pro-people  -  Don't you ever need chords diagrams/arrangements etc?   Impressive to remember all the songs and arrangements on 6 different synths in headBut I guess you've played the the same songs hundreds of times...

title: RE: Rig I used this Summer;Since modified
post_content: I was trained classically as a kid but once I got into rock bands I learned everything by ear. Personally I play better when I have internalized the music - I still use a chart here and there to remember more harmonically complex songs, but my sight reading was never good enough to read a chart cold at first play. I'll use a chart to pick out parts initially but will end up memorizing them. As for playing many boards at once, been doing that for decades, it's just something you get used to if you do it all the time. Although my rig is now one piano touch and one synth touch to keep it a little simpler.DH

title: RE: Rig I used this Summer;Since modified
post_content: I have kind of the same, but in a L shape with 3 keys on each side. As of having difficulties to remember which synths or chart you play, yes, my sight reading is enough to read and play a chart all the time....Then, notes about sounds used on each part of the song is written on it and I still have notes on setlist maker on my Ipad for every song as well....And I'm not a pro but have been in so many situations in gigs that I want to be prepared....

title: RE: Rig I used this Summer;Since modified
post_content: Why so many keyboards with overlapping sounds?  Can you explain what each keyboard brings to the gig, the others like the Kronos, do not?   I have yet to do a gig with the Kronos that it couldn't handle.

title: RE: Rig I used this Summer;Since modified
post_content: Oh, I can answer that! Because he can!For reference, this might come useful in the future:"You can't have too many synthesizers!"

title: RE: Rig I used this Summer;Since modified
post_content: Mr_-G- wrote:Oh, I can answer that! Because he can!For reference, this might come useful in the future:"You can't have too many synthesizers!"Um, if you are a heavy gigging musician who doesn't have the luxury of roadies and rented backlines, it's a royal PIA to carry and setup SO many keyboards, mixers, pedals, and amplification.   If he's just swaggin, then I can understand it, but practically speaking, it's not very wise.

title: RE: Rig I used this Summer;Since modified
post_content: Because it looks so good, like Pink Floyd or Genesis...And who said that music has to be wise? I agree, you could never have too many keyboards....More seriously, there is no way you could have the same pleasure in playing a Moog and tweaking the knobs while you are playing with your Kronos....For the JD800, maybe the Roland strings/Pads sounds that has always been something special for me....He also said he has already downsized a bit his current rig...

title: Rietveld Space Artist
post_content: Rietveld Space ArtistFilm by Bertus and Marco Mulder. Electronic music Roland KuitRietveld described his approach as an architect like this:‘When we limit, isolate or demarcate a segment of what we tend to call ‘general, infinite space’ for a given purpose, protect is from certain influences, and size it down to a human scale, we (possibly) create a chunk of space that becomes experienced reality – for it has become part of our human dimension.’Info:http://www.muldermoviesmulder.com/36Store:http://www.muldermoviesmulder.com/winkel

title: A couple of tracks using the Pianet N sound on my NE3 73.
post_content: First of all, a 1960s-style instrumental, "Sun Meets Rain". The bass pulse and synth "twinkles" are from a Korg Volca Keys monosynth. The electric piano is a Hohner Pianet N sound on my Nord Electro 3, with a home-made passive fuzz unit in some places. I am also using an unlooped Mellotron string sample. Non-keyboard instruments include an electric 12-string guitar and electric double bass.Next is a disco-influenced instrumental, "Stuffed Olives". Drums are from a Korg KR Mini drum machine. Again, the electric piano is the Pianet N sound on the Nord Electro 3. The lead synth and synth strings are both from a Yamaha Reface CS polysynth, and I am also playing bass guitar with a pick.Both tracks are from my "Galactic Lounge" playlist.

title: Kröller-Müller Museum RIETVELD PAVILION Concert
post_content: 09.07.2017:World premier RIETVELD PAVILION - Roland Emile Kuitat Kröller-Müller Museum.Photography by Roland KuitPhotography by Henk Porckhttp://soundcloud.com/roland-kuit/sets/ ... d-pavilion

title: RE: Kröller-Müller Museum RIETVELD PAVILION Concert
post_content: Album RIETVELD PAVILION - Roland Emile KuitThis open structure was designed by Gerrit Rietveld in 1955 for Sonsbeek Park in Arnheim for the exhibition of small sculptures. In 1965 it was rebuilt in the sculpture garden of the Kröller-Müller Museum on a site Rietveld himself selected.According to the principles of Neoplasticism, Roland Emile Kuit invented sound and elaborates upon it. He engages in research as a ‘sound architect’. Kuit constructed between 2010 and 2017 virtual electronic systems where spectral chaos was converted to serial sound constellations.  On this album Kuit balances on the interface between research, architecture, music, sound art and space. Neoplasticism and sound converged in the pavilion.Roland Emile Kuit: KymaThe world premier of this work took place 9 July 2017 at Rietveld Pavilion Kröller-Müller Museum Otterlo.The NetherlandsCover design by Karin SchomakeriTuneshttp://itun.es/nl/_-dmlb

title: Another Rig
post_content: This is my "no soft synth allowed" rig.  Not pictured are the EV ZXA-1s that I use for stage monitors.  I played for a living from 1984 to 1997 so I have a love for hardware keyboards.  Don't get me wrong, I love my Logic Pro X and all my UA plugins for recording, but for me, I'm a Roland/Nord addict.

title: RE: Another Rig
post_content: Love your pedal setup! Is that custom? If so, can you post a description of how it was made?

title: RE: Another Rig
post_content: Thanks Tom, its actually very easy.  As you can see I have a Yamaha FC5 for sustain and a Roland EV5 for volume for each keyboard.  The pedalboards are from Temple Audio.  The wider one is a Solo 18 at full length and the other is a Solo 18 cut down to 10" (Temple will cut them down to whatever width you want at no extra charge).  There are adhesive mounting plates on back of the pedals to secure them to them board.  And they can handle some pretty good abuse.  Temple makes a module that mounts on the side of the frame that has four 1/4" thru jacks.  They work with both TS and TRS.  Then I had snakes made from ProAudioLA to go from pedalboard to keyboards.  As you can see it looks pretty clean and everything is completely wired in the photo (pedals, MIDI in/out, and stereo audio).  No dangling cords or cables.  I'll take a picture of the underneath and side of the pedalboard so you can get a better idea.mikep

title: New Trippy Song/Video w/ Nord Lead 4 Sequenced by Octatrack
post_content: Story:I discovered a space-time distortion while visiting Chicago. The location of the anomaly is at track 8 at Union Station. Here is the video to prove it. The longer you watch, the trippier it gets.If you'd like mastered version of this track as a single you can pick it up herehttps://markmosher.bandcamp.comEnjoy.Artist Notes:This audio and video was captured in one real-time pass to a Zoom Q4N. The primary source video for 90% of the visuals is from the overhead view of the live studio session. The only other footage is a video field recording from Chicago's Union Station also recorded on the Zoom Q4N. The audio was not edited when I added video effects in post.The audio field recording was extracted the Zoom Q4N video shot at Union Station. It's mangled pretty heavily in this piece put if you listen closely, you can hear an automated voice informing you that you are at track 8 and 10. Interestingly, the speakers at the station are not directional and the audio is at different loop lengths - so just wandering about between these gates is a trippy polyrhythmic treat.Instrumentation and Instrumentalities:The piece is a combination of live sequencing and live performance. The Octatrack is used to host drum samples and recording. It is also used to MIDI sequence 3 synth slots on the Nord Lead 4 including MIDI automation. I perform live using all 4 slots on the Nord plus manipulate the Octatrack in real-time. Lots of real-time sound design and morphing. All the groovy synth sounds are exclusive to Nord Lead 4 all being created in real-time (meaning no synth audio was pre-recorded).

title: Nord Lead 4 + A1 Performance Video
post_content: Hi Nord UsersI've just put up a video of me playing performances on the Nord Lead 4 and Nord Lead A1. Usually we see videos of only 1 instrument performing but what if you sync performances on both of them having 8 sound souces to play around with instead of 4. I'm sending a MIDI Clock to both of them so they stay in sync from then on its just playing around with keysplits, arps, pitchbend and modwheel. No external effects used./Michael

title: A new "Red" in the family
post_content: Hi Guys,Well, nor really a new "Red Nord", but the Propret 12 has a lot of red...That's why I bought it, to match my C2...Just kidding. In fact, with all the buzz around the "Pure/real thing/Analog", I"ve never paid attention to the Prophet 12 and with a steep price like this one, I thought it was not for me...And then, 10 days ago, I realized that a store in St Johns, NL, had it at a 30% discount, new...A customer bought it and returned it two days after that because he didn't like it. The Store had it for 3 months, so, they wanted to get rid of it...So, I read all the reviews, trying to figure out what it could bring to me and then, I pulled the trigger...The sound is crazy. I think I have the last version, which means that the presets are from the P12 Module, I always hear people complaining about programs from DSI, but not me, in that case, they are awesome...And with the Prophet 08, they complement each other so well...That's it.IMG_3314.JPG (1.97 MiB) Viewed 3878 timesIMG_3315.JPG (1.95 MiB) Viewed 3878 timesIMG_3316.JPG (2.1 MiB) Viewed 3878 timesIMG_3317.JPG (1.91 MiB) Viewed 3878 timesIMG_3318.JPG (2.14 MiB) Viewed 3878 timesIMG_3319.JPG (2.06 MiB) Viewed 3878 times

title: Sit down or stand up?
post_content: Hi there,When having a look at some of your pictures/video, I noticed that some of you sit when they play live. Some play standing up in front of their gear.So... Basic question:Do you rather stand or sit down to play?I personally stand in front of my gear. It allows me to move when the vibe gets meWhen practicing my piano at home or working on some sounds/productions, I sit down off course. But live, I need to stay on my feet, even if I might cost me a bit of precision.What about you?

title: RE: Sit down or stand up?
post_content: Depends on what the show demands. Obviously sitting down is easier on the hips, but if the show requires more infectious stage presence, then standing up is where to be.

title: RE: Sit down or stand up?
post_content: Always sit...The Only time I stand is when I have a crazy solo with mod wheel on the third keyboard of my rig (I have an L shape with 3 keys stacked on each one...) and then, I need to be more confortable...Otherwise, I stay sit...If I want to move the crowd, I take my Keytar in fact...

title: RE: How much do you charge for a gig?
post_content: Wow!!!!  I can't believe what some of you guys are charging.  North East of England, band supplies all the kit.  Guitarist, drummer, keyboard player/second guitar, bassist, lead singer (5 people), 2 x 45 minute sets, £250 - £350.  This is the going rate.

title: RE: How much do you charge for a gig?
post_content: I'm guessing they're going for functions, private parties, maybe corporate gigs rather than pubs or clubs. Let's face, it for pub work you don't tell them, they tell you.

title: RE: How much do you charge for a gig?
post_content: Depends on what you want to earn. €50? €250? What does PA and light cost? €500 at least. What songs are you playing? Oldies or 'newies'? How good are you? Amateur or (semi)pro? My band will cost between €1950 and €2400 depends on the venue. I earn about €150 a gig.

title: RE: How much do you charge for a gig?
post_content: $/hour total show with your # of members, no lighting that you mentioned, and in town,  at least $1000. and that's dirt cheap.  Depending on your:  travel distance, venue type, accommodation included/required  and quality of production, well that's up to you to cover costs and pay the members.  Bar type gig where I am, 1 night in town 2,3,4 players don't matter, $400.00 is the ceiling.  I'm old school.  I won't play for less that $100 in town, (I'll sit home with the family)  and at that I really lose money.  It ain't like the old days.

title: RE: How much do you charge for a gig?
post_content: Oh wow, there're some really nice prices out there.I'm working in the classical music industry as a studio/concert singer, and we charge our prices on a per hour basis (for rehearsals too). Our usual fee is 9-12 EUR per hour, but a lot of our employers like to conserve some money buy ordering us only for 1 rehearsal + 1 concert, or try to record complete movie soundtracks in 4 hours worth of studio time.

title: RE: How much do you charge for a gig?
post_content: For pubs and clubs, you'll likely top out at £350 regardless of how many of you there are - they just work to a music budget.For functions, I work on an absolute minimum of £100 per member (including sound engineer if I'm bringing out a brass section as well).  Weddings and some corporate gigs are notoriously long days, typically they want you there in the afternoon before people arrive and you're not getting out until after everyone's left - so you are really talking about a 12 hour shift.  So I look to charge more towards £200 or more per person for these as this equates to £16 per hour per person which I think is more than reasonable.A DJ would look for at least £500 for a wedding.  When you look at it that way, you get more bang for your buck with a live 6-piece band at £1200.  Another thing is be careful about under charging - Most people planning a wedding set themselves a budget of around £2000 for a live band (corporates expect to pay more around £3000 - £5000 as a minimum).  Going in at £800 is giving the impression you are not the quality of band they are looking for - sure if you really are an £800 band then you will get some wedding work but no corporate work to speak of.I'll be honest, I've seen a lot of pub bands do functions and some are really not up to the task - not the right gear, not good enough players, can't read and adapt to the crowd or simply too much pissing about.  The difficult thing is being absolutely honest with yourselves and deciding whether you really can put on a full show rather than knock out a few covers.The best corporate stuff I do is for a pharmaceutical company.  We get £450 each plus all expenses paid - flights, hotels, gear rider, meals, after show drinks.  We work with an events management company who provide a complete stage crew.  For that money, they are expecting a slick show and that's what we give them.The key is learning how to gauge the budget available and pitching your price to your client appropriately.

title: RE: How much do you charge for a gig?
post_content: Good question. And I agree location(!) both across the globe but also town/city/... makes a huge difference.That being said, bars/pubs around here pay about 250EUR if you're semi-pro. FEstivals, corporate gigs, privates more about 600-1200EUR.But in this country live music unfortunately not so much appreciated since the "crisis" apart from the stadium dimension...

title: RE: How much do you charge for a gig?
post_content: Around £1200 for a typical 8-12 slot, we're a six piece.  Rate goes up if it's ~2 hours away or they want us to play for extra time.

title: RE: How much do you charge for a gig?
post_content: $100/man for a 4-5 piece cover band doing a standard 3 hr bar gig, plus a meal per person, is about what will get me to leave the house.$2-500/man for weddings. Lower if they're friends-of-friends or something or it's last minute and we're open. (But you can bet we're not gonna wear suits.)If the music is something I really believe in, or it's a buddy's vanity project or whatever, pay is much more negotiable as long as it's local.Worthwhile gigs are at least one of the following: a good hang, good money, and good music.The music OR the money has to be good to endure an otherwise dead gig.Realistically, you strive for two of those things.I have yet to have a gig that's all three ...

title: RE: How much do you charge for a gig?
post_content: In the USA it varies from region to region, but in my area Washington D.C. it's about $500/night for a 5-piece at a decent club. 3 x 45min sets.

title: RE: How much do you charge for a gig?
post_content: We ask between 300 € (most often) and 1200 € + meal, 8 musicians, 30 songs, soul/rock covers, going 40 kms around, west coast, France.

title: RE: How much do you charge for a gig?
post_content: Where I live, my band charged between €400 and €800 last year (6 people with instruments, full PA etc.) In Paris, at our band's level, prices are slightly lower because there is much more offer/competition.

title: RE: How much do you charge for a gig?
post_content: Hi All,Old thread but we've been playing recently on few gigs, 22 to 30 songs, in two or three sets, 2 hours to 3 hours depending on the breaks between sets and we were paid between 1200CAN$ and 1500CAN$, 5 musicians + a sound check guy, just so you know. In Winnipeg, it's way easier to get proper pay than in Cold lake, Alberta, where I was last year (Small town, 15.000 people only)...So, as some of you said, it all depends on where you live and how is the competition.Bye

title: Triptych of The De Stijl - Dutch art movement
post_content: Concertzender Electronic Frequencies"Art has to be forgotten. Beauty must be realized "--Piet MondrianThe art movement The Style exists this year a century. 100 years ago the artist Theo van Doesburg founded The Style and their magazine around a group of artists, consisting of, among others, Piet Mondrian, Bart van der Leck, Vilmos Huszár and Gerrit Rietveld. This group of painters, architects and designers strives for an autonomous, universal art, intended for the new man in a new society. Mondrian argues for a kind of music deprived of any kind of personal feelings, depth, warmth and empathy and the sound of which is no longer the ' roundness ', 'fade in ', ' reverberation ', or other typical instrumental characteristics of a romantic idiom.Video still by Karin SchomakerRoland Kuit researched in this context the relationship between sound and space. The artist Karin Schomaker researched Mondrian and movement. This area of tension between sounds and images got its world premiere as "Monads and Beyond" at the Mondriaanhuis in Amersfoort. (House of birth of Piet Mondrian). November 1, 2013.Roland Kuit is a creative expert in The Style and music. On 3 March, the film "Rietveld ruimtekunstenaar" by Bertus Mulder. A film about the Rietveld-Schöderhuis in Utrecht, for which the music is composed by Roland Emile Kuit. His installation "On the edge of Colour and Tone" will go to Berlin, London, Paris, Sydney, Melbourne, Buenos Aires and finally Kansas City. A sound art installation based on The Style guide lines.This group of painters, architects and designers seeking an autonomous, universal art, intended for a new man in a new society. Not the individual, but the big picture of society should be the norm. A completely new visual language should be able to appeal to all people equally. Their ideas about them published in the journal.http://www.concertzender.nl/triptiek-van-de-stijl/

title: RE: Triptych of The De Stijl - Dutch art movement
post_content: The Dutch Style connection: Dick Raaijmakers - Piet Mondrian - Roland KuitConcertzender Electronic Frequencies:Three broadcasts in which abstraction, DADA and sound art will transform the speaker boxes at home to autonomous sound sculptures.The Dutch composer Jacob van Domselaer (1890-1963) together, with Piet Mondrian, did researched creating a new form of music. Verticality, standing sound structures in which melody free and quiet. This research culminated as “Proeven van Stijlkunst” for piano. (1913-1916). The tone was set.Between 1950 and 1955, the Belgian composer and founder of the musical serialism Karel Goeyvaerts, managed to broaden this principle of the standing sound structures. Goeyvaerts stacked electronic created sinus tones on each other as sound objects.CAHIER-M published by the Dutch composer Dick Raaijmaker (2000) is about the morphology of electric sound. This inherently single-layered type of sound is discussed in the light of 'neo-plastic' music as suggested by the painter Piet Mondriaan in the 1920's. He advocated a kind of music that consisted of single-layered, 'single-colour' electric sounds.Between 2010 and 2013 constructed the Dutch composer Roland Emile Kuit virtual electronic systems where spectral chaos was converted to serial sound constellations. Sounds that are captured at the atomic level to their brought back to square trajectories. Hereafter broken down and reduced to the elementary.First broadcast 22-02-20171 - K5. Roland Emile Kuit, 2013 5:27 ****6 - Plastisism 2. Roland Emile Kuit, 2013 6:39 ****7 - Blue line. Roland Emile Kuit, 2013 4:37 ****8 - Crossings for PM. Roland Emile Kuit, 2013 3:46 *****9 - Music for Mondrian. Roland Emile Kuit, 2013 2:59 *****10 - Neo-Plastiek 2. Roland Emile Kuit, 2014 7:08 ******11 - Neo-Plastiek 4.
