title: Video: Improv Trio, featuring: Electro4D and Moog Sub37
post_content: This is a new project I've started with two other musicians from my previous band. It's an experiment in complete improvisation, so every show, video, and recording will be different. We're a three-piece consisting of drums, bass, and keys.My main board is an Electro 4D through a JHS Fuzz, Dunlop Wah, Minifooger Flange, EHX Memory Man, and Earthquake Devices Afterneath reverb. The signal is then split at the mixer, half goes to Motion Sound Kp-500 and SW-250 stack, the other half goes to an Orange TH100 tube amp with Orange 4x12 cab. My other board is a Moog Sub37 going through 3 minifoogers: Ring Mod, Chorus, Delay, and an Earthquake Devices Levitation reverb. I also use an iPad for granular synthesis, samples, and ambience."Guitars...we don't need no stinking' guitars."https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aA4yw_-AYHw

title: RE: Video: Improv Trio, featuring: Electro4D and Moog Sub37
Suggestions for a USB interface for demo recording
post_content: Hey guys,My band (5 piece: 2 guitars, bass, keyboard and drums + 3 vocals) is looking at different interfaces  for recording demos quality recordings of our upcoming album (we'll be heading to the studio to do a full fledged recording later on once we're satisfied with our arrangements).We're in the market for USB devices that have at least 8 preamps. Additional lines in are a plus or Adat in for more lines. We're looking in the 500CAD$-1000$CAD range. I'd like your suggestions.At the moment we're leaning towards the Scarlett focusrite 18i20, Scarlett Octopre Mk II, or the MOTU 8-pre but are having some difficulty making up our minds.Any suggestions?Thanks in advance!Dugrok

title: RE: Suggestions for a USB interface for demo recording
post_content: I don't have enough experience with this gear to help you, but I would only suggest to inclue the Roland UA-1610 Studio Capture in your shortlist (12 premium preamps, a very cool autosense feature...). I use one (10i10o) in my home studio and I love everything about it. I think it should be right in your price range.

title: RE: Suggestions for a USB interface for demo recording
post_content: If you are looking for something that has 8 preamps, my guess is that you mean you would like to be able to record the whole band at once, as opposed to one track at a time.  You mentioned that your band has this lineup: (5 piece: 2 guitars, bass, keyboard and drums + 3 vocals).  If recording the entire band all at the same time, I would guess you would need a minimum of 3 lines for the drum kit (2 condenser overheads plus the kick), 1 for each of the 2 guitars, bass, and keyboard, plus 3 for the vocals.  That would be 3+4+3=10 lines.  Even if you reduced it to just 1 instead of 2 overhead mics for the drum kit, you would still need 9 lines, if you were wanting to record the whole band at once.

title: RE: Suggestions for a USB interface for demo recording
post_content: But would I necessarily need to preamp all of the lines or just the ones that are going to be amplified?

title: RE: Suggestions for a USB interface for demo recording
post_content: Dugrok wrote:But would I necessarily need to preamp all of the lines or just the ones that are going to be amplified?You will need enough mic preamps on your interface to cover all the actual microphones plus DI boxes you use at one time, but you can use line level inputs (ie no mic preamp required) for electric instruments like keyboards etc.I'm going to assume that you're NOT going to record the lead and backing vocals live at the same time as the rest of the instruments, so that would reduce the number of mic preamps you need for a start. Ultimately, it's a matter of how many instruments you'll be recording SIMULTANEOUSLY that matters. You just need to decide exactly how you're going to do your recordings, and do the arithmetic about how many mic preamp and line level inputs you need. If you're intending to record your instruments mostly separately, that will reduce your need for mic preamps quite considerably.Basically:Drums - Recorded acoustically with mics. One mic preamp for each mic on the drum kitBass - Either mic up the speaker or DI the bass, one mic preamp needed. (You can do both simultaneously if you want. Some people do that to get the best possible bass sound, but it's not absolutely necessary).Guitar - Usually mic up the speaker cab. Not usually DI'ed, but some guitarists do use amps or effects that can be DI'ed or have line level outputs.Keyboards - You should know this one! Out the back to line level inputs.Vocals - mics.  'nuff said.If you can reduce your need for mic preamps to four, you can save a ton of money on your interface. Just thought I'd mention it.Edit:Another factor to consider when deciding how much money you want to spend is whether you're going to use the interface and other gear again in the future. The more use you need to get from your interface, the more it makes sense to spend the extra to get better quality stuff. If you're only really going to use it once for your demos, then spending a lot of money on high quality studio-grade gear doesn't make so much sense. In that case, it only needs to be "good enough" to get the job done.

title: New CD Releases Roland Kuit in Japan
post_content: I have two new CD releases in Japan.The 2CDBi - sonic- Roland Emile KuitBiとは自転車のBicycleの意味であり、実際に自転車の車輪をいじったりした音素材を使った作品が3曲収録されている。それらはこの作家の趣向から必ずしも車輪の回転とかスポークをつまびくとかいう即物的な音にはならず、電子的なレベルで解体された音粒子の連続として提示される。1枚目tr.1はなかなかノイジー。2枚目は58分1トラックという大作だが、30秒から1分程度の短いテイクが99連なる偏執狂的な内容。トラックごとに速度感が異なる微粒子的な音。スポークに発振器をつけて回転させる小杉武久の"Catch Wave 2002"やRichard Lerman "Travelon Gamelon"とも違うアプローチといえる。＜試聴＞ disc1-tr.1 / disc1-tr.2 / disc2http://omega-point.shop-pro.jp/?pid=95816679The CDMeditations for Flute- Roland Emile KuitマイナーながらOMEGA POINT的には一目おいているオランダの電子音楽作家の新作がまたも到着！すべてライブエレクトロニクスで変調されたフルートによる3つの連作。Meditationなので激しい跳躍はなく、"1"では前半で時折タンギングを伴った速いパッセージがあるものの、後半は茫洋とした風景が広がる。"2"では多少実験音響的なガサガサした変調、"3"では特に前半で、糸を引きトグロを巻くような変調フルートが、能のような間とともにおごそかな雰囲気をかもしだす。＜試聴＞ tr.1 / tr.3http://omega-point.shop-pro.jp/?pid=95816687

If there is an instrument I want to use and I don't own it or can't play it, then I might use a Nord Mellotron sound, or even my old Casio WK-3000, which has some great orchestral instrument sounds. title: Uptown Funk Mark Ronson ft. Bruno Mars Drum Bass Cover
post_content: Listen to this Crazy drum and bass cover of the famous song Uptown Funk by Mark Ronson ft. Bruno Mars played by Cecilia Nappo and Federico MaragoniIf you enjoyed it, you can share on your Facebook or Twitter pageThank you!To the Video >>

title: RE: Uptown Funk Mark Ronson ft. Bruno Mars Drum Bass Cover
post_content: I don't get it...is this a band playing a cover of a hit song or is it a karaoke routine on top of some sampled traxx?  the drumming is nice, the bass playing is nice, the vid shoot and editing are nice, everything is nice, but...I don't recall whose signature tagline this is, but somewhere in one of these forums I've encountered someone whose signoff line says "pressing Play does not constitute making music" or words to that general effect.  To each their own, but that pretty well says it for me.  In Florida I am surrounded by musicians, a great many of them really fine and accomplished musicians, who spend most of their days doing little more than pressing "Play" on a machine and playing along with the machine.  They make nice money doing it, pay their bills and raise their kids and those are all worthwhile things, but I'm just an old stick in the mud and prefer my music "Ital," that is, natural.  No sequencers, no canned traxx, no mysterious sounds coming from the speakers that make it sound as though there's five or more people on stage when there's only one or two.But that's just me...bless,pablo

title: RE: Uptown Funk Mark Ronson ft. Bruno Mars Drum Bass Cover
post_content: Thing is, that it takes a lot of effort to have 5 people on a stage to play music. Not musically, no, the human factor is the worst... I think there are a lot of (good?) musicians out there who don't find 4 other people who think the same about what they want to accomplish. Been there done that, spent the last year looking for a band, got disappointed a few times, got tired of that, went back to playing some solo stuff on piano, or piano/vocal singer-songwriter stuff. But I can't sing, so asked around for a singer. Turns out that even finding a singer who wants to sing in his native language is next to impossible, all the cool cats out there want to sing in English.So there you are, you are a 2 man band, a drummer and a bass player. What are you going to play?

title: RE: Uptown Funk Mark Ronson ft. Bruno Mars Drum Bass Cover
post_content: As it happens, I play quite often in a duo with a drummer/lead singer and also occasionally in a trio with a drummer/lead singer and a guitarist.  I play bass/kbds and sing backing with an occasional lead.  No computers/traxx needed.  I'm only with that trio every other Sunday afternoon, but we've held that gig for five years now with no complaints.  And the other two guys from the trio work full-time as a duo the rest of the week.  They've worked a steady 4-5 times per week (and often more in season) that way, a drummer/singer and a guitarist, for about 7-8 years, making good money, paying their bills and raising their kids off of nothing but music.I have no doubts that these people in the vid are good people and they obviously have serious musical skills.  I wouldn't have bothered to go out of my way to volunteer my thoughts on this, but they posted the vid and asked for response, so I'm responding with my personal opinion.  They obviously don't need to play on top of canned traxx to sound good.  I'd be much happier to see them play as a duo, or add a third if need be, without leaning on samples stolen/borrowed from the latest pop craze hit.  For me this works better as an audition tape for someone else looking for a drum/bass team, and I won't be surprised to learn that they do hook up with someone who happens to be looking for bass/drum help as a result of this vid.Your points about finding musicians (generally a crazy lot already, and it seems that the level of crazy usually increases with the level of talent) is well taken and I personally am blessed to have found people with whom I have been able to work for a very long time -- but just keep plugging away at what YOU do and seek satisfaction on your own terms and you may discover that the right person/people will come to you.Lastly, I'd encourage you to try singing even if you think you can't.  There are plenty of folks who've done well singing even though they have terrible voices when defined in the classical sense (Joe Cocker, Tom Waits, Rod Stewart, whatshisface from the Stones, oh yeah, Mick Jagger).  It's often more about the heart, and if you put your heart into it the vibes will follow.Bless,Pablo

title: RE: Uptown Funk Mark Ronson ft. Bruno Mars Drum Bass Cover
post_content: As far as I can see, they're just playing over the top of the original track, with their own drums and bass turned up to mask the originals. Not much of a work ethic, and certainly not worth recording and posting publicly. Just pointless showing off, all image and no substance. Misplaced egos, methinks. As for "Crazy!" - yawn.

title: RE: Uptown Funk Mark Ronson ft. Bruno Mars Drum Bass Cover
post_content: I was trying to be nice, but yeah, that pretty much hits the nail on the head.  Especially the "not worth recording and posting" part, unless as an audition tape.p

title: Recording Nord Stage 2
post_content: This is my first post.Be gentleLong story short, I own a NS2 and I want to record it using Sonar X3 through my Roland Quad-Capture.What's the best way to connect it, quality wise?

title: RE: Recording Nord Stage 2
post_content: Hi, Welcome to the forum.I suppose that you are talking audio recording? I do not think there are too many options for this. The NS2 does not output via the USB connector, so if you still have the NS2 set to output in stereo through outputs 1 and 2, then try connecting those two via TS (mono) cables to the 2 inputs of the Roland and that would get converted to USB audio. When you record those 2 audio streams in Sonar, make sure that they are fully panned in opposite directions so you do not have any phase cancellation effects.

title: RE: Recording Nord Stage 2
post_content: Two additional tips:set the master volume on the Nord to maximum and use no longer cables as necessary.

title: Nord Stage 2 Volume Setting Advice Needed
post_content: Looking for Nord Stage 2 synth volume advice.I play almost 90% synth (for this first set at least, which wasn't the original plan.  But that's going to change!  More piano!).  I have a double stack with an N73 on top and an N76 on the bottom.  My Sweetwater guy set me up with a cool mixer that I put on a boom so it's just above my top board, then I can adjust the master volume of both, just the N76, or just the N73 (three knobs).  Then I'm not fishing for the master volume on the N76 underneath, and I can change the volume of both boards at once.  I also have volume pedals allowing me the same functionality as well.But adjusting live when the songs aren't seared in your brains often affects the quality of my playing.  When I dial in my sounds at home to sound like they're at the same volume so I have less live volume to adjust, I then go play live at practice and certain sounds are still too loud or soft.  It's unnerving to know whether you're volume is correct as I start a fair amount of songs.  What I'm also finding is different timbres get sucked up more so than others.  My trumpet for example, if I set it the same volume as the other sounds, it just gets sucked up and no one hears it.  So that one I always have to jack up higher than the others.  I find that with strings too.  Does anyone else find this?Between the two boards, sometimes I'm splitting up to 2-3 sounds per board.  I've heard from most that it's trial and error.  Tweak at home as best you can, then tweak while you're playing live, then save your adjusted settings.But if anyone has any additional advice that I'm missing or anything that would help make this easier, please advise.Gosh, if bass players knew how good they have it.....

title: RE: Nord Stage 2 Volume Setting Advice Needed
post_content: Trust your easrs onstage and take mental notes which ones to adjust. I always find volume differences between sounds become much more apparent at high volume. Also the EQ on a given sound may sound great in headphones at home, but onstage can be boomy and muddy. And also if your are programming your patches at home in headphones in stereo, if you are summing to mono when you get to the gig, again your at-home mix goes right out the window. If you work with a FOH sound tech get their opinion too. The more volumes you can preset in advance the less hassle you'll have at the gig, but a volume pedal is always good for on-the-fly adjustments, especially as stage sound can vary from venue to venue. Trust your ears first though for sure.

title: RE: Nord Stage 2 Volume Setting Advice Needed
post_content: Hi ejwalker,All good advice above...only thing I can think to add is that the DRIVE knob may become your good friend.  Used is small amounts it will help you make those last-minute adjustments more easily.Bless,Pablo

title: RE: Nord Stage 2 Volume Setting Advice Needed
post_content: Nice - thanks Pablo and dhpb-nord!@dhpb Nord - thanks for pointing out the headphone difference.  At home, I do use headphones that are connected to both nords and the recording when setting volume for each sound.  Do you recommend setting my volume levels through my amp instead?  I always use mono so sounds like I might be good on that front?  And thank you for the high volume ramifications, good to note.  And thanks for the FOH advice.  I have asked a sound technician to work on this with me and will push to get this done before the gig.@Pablo - would have never thought of the drive knob.  Thanks!!!

title: RE: Nord Stage 2 Volume Setting Advice Needed
post_content: If you are able to play at full volume at home and can stay married if you do tryIf you have some kind of meter in your signal path (mixer VU etc) that will help you get generally close to keeping everything consistent. Use several viewpoints (home, rehearsal, gig) to build a complete picture. If you have any kind of sequencing/recording in your onstage setup, or have someone else in your band that can noodle on your favourite patches, walk out into the audience during setup/soundcheck and listen to your own rig from that vantage point - that will be a real eye-opener I bet.Having the rest of the band around will change things somewhat too. I find in generally it's never-ending, you're always tweaking, which is multiplied exponentially by the number of different patches / sound sources you are using. Where the Nords are sample-based they really can be completely different from patch to patch.A big learning experience (for me it was anyhow) is figuring out how to blend well with other instruments. It's always a challenge not to trample too much on guitar or bass guitar frequencies while keeping your own patches sounding good, and of course that changes with every musician you encounter. Part of that can be influenced by what notes you play (ie not playing octaves on everything in the left hand all the time if you have a bass player etc)I am really lucky right now as the guitar player I am working with is really keen on chords/voicing etc so we spend a lot of time talking about what we are playing together, to try and compliment each other. When you think in those terms sometimes the sound/frequency things take care of themselves if you are making good musical choices.Good luck!DH

title: Nord Electro 3 - problems with volum control
post_content: Hello.I hope this is the right forum for postning this.I currently play in a cover-band (hoping to making our own projects or finding someone else to play with in the future). We cover an american band called Clutch, which use/used a lot of organ sounds in their music.Here is a short youtube-video from a gig we played last year -This is very loud and fun rock-music, which for me is very challenging finding the right volume/balance when playing. When I practice at home, everything sounds good, but when playing with the band, I find it very difficult to have exactly the right volume/gain. I use many different customized programs for the different songs, but I find it difficult to have the right set of volume on the different programs. Even if the gain control is at the same level, some are even hard to hear when playing with full band when i turn it at max volume.We usually only play 3-4 gig a year, because of a drummer working in the oil business, traveling a lot abroad, so when playing at smaller pubs/rock scenes, and it always seems hard for the "sound guy" to give me the right set of volume out to the audience. I know that my role is to build up the "soundscape"(?), and to spice it up with a few solos, but sometimes it can be a bit frustrating after a gig when someone tell me that they didnt hear me play because of loud guitar, bass and drums :pAnyone have any tips/experience, or are there any accessories that can help?(English is not my first language, so I am sorry if my descriptions are awkwardly worded)

title: RE: Nord Electro 3 - problems with volum control
post_content: Yes, this can indeed be tricky! First of all it's important that your monitor mix is right, so that it sounds right to you. Once this is in place, the sound guy can adjust the out volume to match the rest of the band. Make sure your main volume on the keyboard is only about halfway up at this stage. This is all done during sound check.Later on at the gig, I bet the other guys play louder than before, so you should too! So just raise your main volume until it sounds good to you. This should sound good to the audience too!I can also recommend using a volume pedal so that you can easily change your volume while playing.Also, if you know someone in the audience, ask them to give feedback after a few songs.Finally, make a habit of recording your gigs, preferably with video. It's a really good way to get accurate feedback on the performance.Good luck!/Anders

title: RE: Nord Electro 3 - problems with volum control
post_content: The best accessory here is a louder stage ampThere's nothing more miserable than putting all that effort into learning songs, rehearsing and gigging just to be told that no-one can hear you anyway.Sounds like your PA system isn't loud enough to compete with the onstage volume the other band members are using. (An additional problem is that many sound guys just don't mix keyboards very loud; they often seem to think that the keys aren't as important as the rest of the band).Even if that's not the case, you need enough volume yourself on stage so that you can hear the keys loud enough without your instrument being turned full up - halfway up as elekromin suggested should give you enough "in hand" to be able to boost yourself for solos.But if you don't have enough power to hear yourself clearly in the first place, there's nothing you can really do about that.There's also the problem of balancing your different sounds within themselves. As you've found out, what works at home often doesn't work properly with the rest of the band, and adjusting the relative volume of your different sounds is a slow process of trial and error. Even the same sound at the same volume can seem to vary according to the song and arrangement. There are some tricks you can do to help. Try playing in a different register from the guitar player - if he's play a low riff as on your YouTube video, try playing a bit higher (and vice-versa), or adding a little more brightness with some higher drawbars. Adding a bit of overdrive can work wonders - even if the organ sounds a little bit too dirty by itself, the distortion will be obscured in the mix by the guitarist's distortion and it might just give you the extra volume and brightness you need. Unless you're doing the "Jon Lord" thing, trying to compete with the guitarist on his own terms won't work - he's got a Marshall! - so you should think in terms of finding the spaces which he isn't using at that moment. Actually, on that video, the organ level is a little bit quiet, but not too bad. It shouldn't take too much to get your volume where it needs to be.And as ever, take great care not to go too far with volume; your hearing is vitally important and you must protect yourself from hearing damage at all costs. If the band are so loud that you can't safely compete with them volume-wise, find another band.Oh, and try standing instead of sitting - it's rock and roll, dude!

title: RE: Nord Electro 3 - problems with volum control
post_content: Thanks for great tips!I was actually planning to play standing at our next gig this saturday, but I know myself good enough to know i will get a little extra nervous standing, start shaking in hands and legs, very very annoying. Lol. I guess the only way is to play standing at rehearsals over and over again until it feels natural. I have been sitting playing the piano and keyboard all my life.

title: RE: Stage 2 ex or Nord 5D
post_content: Well Allan you are the only one who can really tell actually, we don't know what are your needs and how much would you "suffer" from missing the  pitch bend and mod wheel in the NE5 or still not having the drawbars in the NS2EX.Of course NS2 EX is the more natural upgrade but question to ask yourself is: how do you use the NS EX today and what (looking at NE5D specifications) would get and/or miss? What music genre do you play and how important is to have more than 2 timbres, the Ext section and the other MIDI capabilities of the NS? Etc...

title: A Trip Down Memory Lane
post_content: I came across these recordings recently and they brought back fond memories as being from the first "pro" album I ever recorded, in about 1984 - 85 I think. The band was Stratus, formed by Clive Burr shortly after he left Iron Maiden, and was comprised of Clive, Bernie Shaw (now Uriah Heep) on lead vocal, Tino and Cris Troy (Praying Mantis) on guitar and bass, and me.The budget for the album was about 50 pence, and was recorded in Frankfurt at Dreamboat studio, now presumably long gone.These sound like they were recorded from vinyl, and were basically your typical British AOR-style rock from the mid-eighties, an offshoot of NWOBHM.The first track is a breezy up-tempo number, the brass (ahem!) being made up of about a million overdubs on an Oberheim OB8 and my Juno 60, and with a Minimoog solo at the end. I remember having a lot of fun putting the "brass" parts together like a jigsaw puzzle, with one of the other guys operating the synth controls - filter, pitchbends and such - while I played.The second track is just your typical cliched AOR ballad, but it features some lovely guitar work by Tino. I used the studio grand (a Steinway I think, but I'm not entirely sure), and an OB8. Quite how we got the piano to sound that bad is a mystery. Oh, and dig those ridiculous 80s drum reverbs!Romancer.mp3Give Me One More Chance.mp3

title: RE: A Trip Down Memory Lane

title: RE: Jamming some blues on my C2D!
post_content: Hey Robert - nice playing!  You get a much dirtier / punchier sound than I get on my NS2... what settings are you using (drawbars, percussion etc)?  It looks like the only thing you change during the jam is leslie on/off... is that correct?

title: RE: Jamming some blues on my C2D!
post_content: spradders wrote:Hey Robert - nice playing!  You get a much dirtier / punchier sound than I get on my NS2... what settings are you using (drawbars, percussion etc)?  It looks like the only thing you change during the jam is leslie on/off... is that correct?Thank you mate!first RH sound is 888000000 leslie sim OFF no vibrato, Perc on soft fast.then I turned on the rotor to slow.Then Full drawbars  with fast  Rotor.The whole time the "Drive" is switched "on" on 4.I actually just use presets ( 2 presets) So You dont see me actually move the drawbars.Peurhaps it's worth mentioning that for this recording I am using an old Yorville 100K mono amp which seems to add a bit of its own color (and have surpising lows).I also use sometimes a pair of Yamaha DRX12  which sound great too  but maybe a bit cleaner.I hope that helps!Robert

title: Greetings from the land of beer, french fries and chocolats
post_content: Hello from Belgium,Last summer I was looking for an 'analog' synth. There's a huge used market for vintage synths but they usually come with a price. And vintage synths often need servicing to keep them going. And I'm no technical guy so it had to be something new. The NL2x seemed very interesting but also the new NL4. When I finally went to the shop to have a try, they just received the new A1. And I immediately loved it ... and bought it.It does everything I need. Great sounding 'classic' vintage synth sounds and it comes with built-in effects. I certainly like the ensemble effect ... I even like the 'like' buttonAnd it's built like a tank. Easy to use, ...I still have a lot of undiscovered sonic territory to explore but until now it has been a great journey.My Nord Lead A1 joined the other members of my band: Yamaha Motif XF8, GEM Equinox 76 and a Roland D50.Greetings,Luc

The Roland Axe Synth is used for the bottom manual and is connected via MIDI to the E4D. All sound is generated by the E4D. The song is Birdlike by Freddie Hubbard. Hope you enjoy it!

title: Christmas gift

Better than Weightwatcher method !I've been used to play piano, meaning nothing to plug to play, and now, because I've join a band, I've tu upgrade my personnal software from MS Dos ... to Linux !And that's a hudge gap for me. title: RE: Christmas gift
post_content: One draw back in linux is that you cannot run the Sound Manager or Sample Editor because linux (actually Wine) does not see the Clavia USB driver.The Sample Editor works fine, but you cannot connect to the instrument;Somebody has reported that they do work under VirtualBox (but of course you need to install some version Windows in a virtual machine).

title: Nord Stage 2, Fazoli XL, and a pair of QSC K10s
post_content: Here's a video of me and my rig a few months ago. I'm using the Fazoli piano (probably XL, but definitely no less than L) on my Stage 2 with a pair of QSC K10's. I had the treble on Stage 2 EQ turned up a little which, upon hearing the video, I think was a mistake. Not sure if you can see the second K10 to my right as it might be out of the video camera's view, but it's there helping to provide a really nice stereo image. It was recorded with a ZOOM Q3HD so it's a pretty accurate representation of the sound. We were performing as part of a concert series called Jazz on the Vine which takes place each winter on the north fork of Long Island, New York at the wineries. Hope you enjoy it!

post_content: DJKeys wrote:Really nice sound!  I love the K10s.FYI, I recently sold my K10s because, to my ear, they weren't doing the Nord justice (I.e., sounded too electric for me and got boxey sounding at louder volumes). I bought a pair of RCF TT08A's on the recommendation of Dave Ferris. They sound great at home -- more clear then the K10s and no degradation of audio quality at louder volumes. My first gig with the pair of TT08A's is next weekend. I hope and expect this will be the end of my amplification quest for awhile.

title: A general "hi" and a dirty clav solo!
post_content: Hi all, first off, this is a really great forum - I've found many helpful bits of information on here that have proved massively useful to me and I'm sure I'm not alone in that (especially regarding Triple Pedal and single key velocity issues - and I currently have both)!I'm a multi-instrumentalist, full-time muso and gear nerd, so without further ado my current keys rig is:Nord Stage 2 88 (I do 99% of my live gigs with this)Waldorf XTkAccess Virus Ti PolarAccess Virus KCRoland JX8PNovation X-Station 61Roland SH-201As well as being my much loved all-round gig and studio work horse, I've found that the NS2 has some awesome capabilities for dirty, gritty wah clav sounds if you dig around a bit with the FX and EQ (it's a personal favourite sound for my ears) and I use that kind of patch as often as circumstances allow - here's a quick (and rather energetic) solo during a performance of Stevie Wonder's classic "Superstition" a few days ago using one of my nastier wah clav presets for anyone who's interested:Cheers and thanks for having such a great community!

title: RE: A general "hi" and a dirty clav solo!
post_content: I like your style. A lot.FWIW, if you've never played "Superstition" in the original Eb minor, you really need to. The pentatonic scale, including the hookline, is all black keys, so you can just hack at it blindly and do crazy percussive stuff that all sounds awesome.

title: RE: A general "hi" and a dirty clav solo!
RE: A general "hi" and a dirty clav solo!
post_content: Yeah, those Stage clav samples really suck, don't they…

title: RE: A general "hi" and a dirty clav solo!
post_content: Hey, your a real showman dude !!  You must pull loads of birds at the end of the gig !! lolYou seem to be very comfortable with the Pitch Bend.  I really can't get on with it and it totally ruins the Nord Stage for me.Very rhythmic playing and heavy emphasis on 8th/16th triplets.If I knew you were in Liverpool I would have come over to see you as I am only in Wallasey.

title: RE: A general "hi" and a dirty clav solo!
post_content: Thanks folks, you're too kind!I'm just impressed as to how dirty the NS2 can sound at the more extreme end of the spectrum, as most all-in-one-box-workstation style keyboards I have used in the past have had overall quite "nice" sounding engines for the non-piano stuff (I'm thinking of my old companions the Korg Trinity V3 and Triton mainly here) without external processing of some kind - and yeah, obviously the Nord inbuilt samples are as good as you'd expect!As for the pitch bend, I have to agree that I didn't like it at first having spent 10 years mainly using the Korg Trinity/Triton pitch&mod wheel system, but actually I now prefer the Nord method in that it feels and plays a lot more like a tremolo bar on an electric guitar to the point where you can pull off flutter effects by flicking it that are just impossible on a standard pitch wheel...it also feels less like I'm going to snap it off than on my other synths, but I'd still feel better if it was solid granite or pig iron - I dread the moment where mid-solo I find my left hand just holding a small piece of broken wood in the air! I'm eventually looking for a lightweight keyboard with all the versatility and quality of a modern Nord product but with Hammond-style durability that wouldn't object to the occasional violent Keith Emerson homage - the search goes on!And as for female attention...in my experience at least, most people seem to find keyboard solos the equivalent at getting a really high Scrabble score. In public.Feel free to hit me up on facebook or twitter, I gig weekly in and around Liverpool (I lived on Wallasey briefly myself 3 years ago) so I'm always out and about.Cheers

title: RE: A general "hi" and a dirty clav solo!
post_content: Hi PB,Nice one dude.I broke my leg and fractured my ankle on Xmas Eve so I am out of action at the moment !! lolYes, you are correct in that you can achieve certain Pitch Bend FX on the Nord which can not be replicated on standard keyboards (I like your term 'flutter').  I much prefer 2 x Wheels (for Pitch and Mod) but this might be because its what I have been used to since 1988.  Having said that, I do still think there is no justifiable reason for Nord to try and re-invent something which had nothing wrong it (just for the sake of being 'original') !!  And even more annoyingly, on my Stage Classic I can not even change the RANGE (so no more Octave-Pitch-Bends !!).I am not on FB or similar social network sites sorry.  But I am on most music forum sites etc.  Do you play freelance or always in the same band ??Paul

title: RE: A general "hi" and a dirty clav solo!
post_content: Would you be willing to share your presets for this sound? I have yet to dial in ones that I'm adequately pleased with.

title: RE: A general "hi" and a dirty clav solo!
post_content: The trick on the clavinet samples is distortion. And wah wah. And a really biting pickup setting.I LOVE the standard clavinet setting I've had on the Electro 2 for about eight years. I was able to dial up something similar on the Stage in a couple of minutes.

post_content: Great dirty clav sound ! Great sounding solo ! Congrats.

The Fender precision bass, Rhodes, Hammond B3 and flute were played with my Nord Electro 4 HP.Here is the result:

title: School Jazz Festival
post_content: Hey everybody,Every semester for the past 2 years there has been a small jazz festival with bands composed of university members. This year, unfortunately it was only 3 bands. title: My Keyboard Corner
post_content: I love my Nord keyboards!1.JPG (121.32 KiB) Viewed 3473 times2.JPG (103.72 KiB) Viewed 3473 times

title: RE: My Keyboard Corner
post_content: Welcome to the forum, nice setup you have there.Is that a Prophet 5 I see in the back, above what might be some Korg or Roland?

title: RE: My Keyboard Corner
post_content: WelcomeNice place !!  Here is a proposal for identificationKorg M1 or O1 ?

title: RE: My Keyboard Corner
post_content: Thank you for your comments!On the vintage side, sitting on the top tier is an Oberheim DX with MIDI.  I have another one without MIDI that I plan to retrofit and place next to the one pictured.  It sounds remarkably different.That’s a Sequential Circuits Prophet 5 Revision 3.3 with MIDI that I’ve owned for 20 years.  It just came back from Greg Montalbano in Oakland California so it is functioning just like it did in 1981.  Or, more like around 1984 when it was upgraded with MIDI.  It sounds incredible especially through the Ibanez CS9 chorus stomp box.Below the P5 is a Korg M1.  When I lived in Portland Oregon, I purchased this from Dick Peterson, the drummer for the Kingsmen (Louie, Louie).  At the time I had no idea that I was in the presence of greatness, but I collected enough clues from visiting his lavish house and amazing home studio to do some research that revealed that I indeed had a brush with fame.  He never returned further emails asking if he had found the promised owner’s manual.  I don’t think the provenance improves the value of the M1, and I can’t prove it, but it was an interesting deal.  I really hate the sound of the M1.  It’s just awful.  It has a really fresh and solid keyboard action so it makes a decent MIDI controller.In the rack is a Furman power conditioner, a Korg guitar tuner, an Alesis Microverb III, a dbx AFS 224 feedback suppressor, a MOTU midi timepiece, an Oberheim Matrix 1000, and sitting on a rack shelf is an Edirol UA-25EX USB AudioCapture interface.  That’s a Mackie CR 1604 mixer on top of the rack.I have an identical Peavey KB/A 100 just behind the pictured laptop computer for stereo goodness.As far as versatility and overall sound quality, the Nord Lead 3 is my favorite keyboard.  I absolutely love this thing.  I have read quite a few comments online disrespecting the Lead 3 and I just don’t understand it.  It sounds amazing to me and the interface with the rotary encoders and LED rings is ideal.

title: Nord & Voice Recording - Help - Howto - Setup
post_content: Hi,I'm trying to find a decent and simple setup to make voice & nord recordings.Edit1 : Added what I have in mind/goal doing this.Edit2 : I know my singin' skill are "limited", and I need to learn & practice how to sing, just want to do it good technical / recording conditions. Feel free for any commentsEdit3 : I'll follow up with detailed setup and settings, about connecting things for instance. It's a trial & error process.Edit4 : Finished the work, tried to keep what could be interesting for someone else doing the same thing.

title: RE: Nord & Voice Recording - Help - Howto - Setup
post_content: Here we go.I’m trying to setup some simple but decent technical conditions to record vocals while playing keyboard.Let’s put it down, using a sound card (Motu Microbook), a mic, a PC, and Ableton Live Lite Edition.Hardware connectionsEverything goes in and out of the sound card, like this :Mic goes into -> Sound card In 1Keyboard Out 1&2 -> Sound card In 3&4Sound card Main Out -> SpeakersSound card Phones Out -> Singer’s headphonesPic:soundcard.jpg (41.95 KiB) Viewed 2295 timesSound card mixer settingsUsing the sound card software mixer, here is what is routed …… to the headphones out :Mic In 1 -> Phones Out (direct monitoring)Kb In 3&4 -> Phones Out (direct monitoring)Computer Out 1&2 -> Phones OutPic:ToPhones.png (116.05 KiB) Viewed 2295 times… to the computer (to Host) :Mic In 1 -> Computer In 1Kb In 3&4 -> Computer In 3&4Pic:ToHost.png (129.4 KiB) Viewed 2295 times… to the main audio out :Computer Out 1&2 -> Main outPic:ToMain.png (129.37 KiB) Viewed 2295 timesDAW settings2 audio and 1 effect tracks are used, 1 for the mic, 1 for the keyboard, another for an effect bus.Track 1 settings : Audio In 1 -> Track 1 In, Track 1 Out -> Effect Track 1 only, Monitoring AUTOTrack 2 : Audio In 3&4 -> Track 2 In, Track 2 Out -> Computer Out 1&2, Monitoring OFFEffect Track 1 -> Computer Out 1&2Pic:overall.jpg (132.1 KiB) Viewed 2295 timesComments on how it works- When the sound card sends back the mic & kb audio signals to the singer’s headphones, there is 0 latency and 0 effect.- The DAW sends back the effect track 1 audio out (reverb) to the singer’s headphone.- When the singer wants to hear what has been recorded, change “Track 1 Out” -> “Master Out” in the Daw.- Monitoring is AUTO for Track 1, so the singer can hear / check his voice with effects, when the track is armed for recording.- Monitoring is OFF for Track 2, coz the monitoring is directly done by the sound card, the daw will only playback what was recorded.Audio processing- Effect Track 1 : reverb, no dry signal sent out (dry signal set to 0 level).- Audio Track 1 : noise gate, filter, equalizer, compressor- Audio Track 2 : nothing, the Nord is perfectNoise GateThe threshold is low (-40db), so the gate does not cut my voice when I sing quiet parts.The attenuation set at -17db, I pushed it down until I could not hear the rain and other background noise, but still the voice, even quiet and 50cm from the mic.Setting method, especially for the envelope (Attack, Hold, Release) :- loop on a meaningful audio clip,- find a point where I hear the setting’s effect- turn the setting until it sounds naturalPic:gate.jpg (9.71 KiB) Viewed 2295 timesEqualizer :Starting from zero …Added 1 point of correction to cut the low frequencies that do not come from the voice. It’s a “square low cut” shape, set to cut under 100 Hz.It reduced some of the proximity (loudness) effect, and some of the loud noises I made touching / taping things like the mic / standAdded a 2nd point to enhance high-mid frequencies, coz my voice sounded more like I hear it normally.Added a 3rd point to cut high frequencies that fo not come from the voice. It’s a “square high cut” shape, set to 8.5 KHz. It diminished the “sss” too.Setting method : Start with no eq, add 1 point, set the frequency, the gain, then the Q until it sounds natural.Pic:EQ.jpg (31.25 KiB) Viewed 2295 timesCompressor :Make the voice volume more constant. I targeted a 0db output, otherwise I found it introduced a hearable distortion.The threshold around -7 db takes the voice when its volume becomes interesting to make it ‘constant’.The knee at 6db makes the transition soft.I raised the ratio to 1.6, not more, or it sounded distorted / less natural.On the graph under, horizontal axis is the input, vertical axis is the output.Pic:Compressor.jpg (26.27 KiB) Viewed 2295 timesFilter, Delay, Reverb :No particular intent here, just a matter of taste.Pic:filter_delay_reverb.jpg (36.86 KiB) Viewed 2295 timesPic of another choice :filter_reverb.jpg (39.74 KiB) Viewed 2295 timesAbout the DAWThe recording, on the first post, was made under Logic and some of my bad settings.I decided to go (back) to Ableton Live because I see more clearly what I’m doing with it.Similar setup was done under Reaper too.The “Lite” version of Ableton that I use is limited to 6 build in effects/plugins per project.- END -

title: RE: Nord & Voice Recording - Help - Howto - Setup
post_content: Let' finish the work here.Here is what I did to make a "vocal double / chorus take" :- added an audio track,- set the "start record" and "stop record" point ( punch in and punch out in Ableton Live )- sung and recorded the part again on this trackThen a more interesting part, on this "chorus' recording, I did :- moved the sample starting point a bit backward : the little yellow mark/flag, at the beginning of the sample view, on the screenshot.- changed the stereo pan setting from center to 36% on the left : "36R" on the audio channel setting on the screenshot.- lowered the volume to - 5.4 db  on the audio channel setting.Using the "Detune" can make interesting effects to : on the bottom left, in the "Sample" setting. I've preferred to let it to "0 cents" here.Screen Shot 2014-02-14 at 1.52.03 PM.png (115.08 KiB) Viewed 2171 timesHere is the recording :-  The End. -All comments are welcome.

If you have any recomendation on how to make it sound better, please share it!!

title: RE: Red Clay recording
post_content: That lead sound is really good, well done. I will load it later. I was surprised that it was made with the NS2 synth section, it sounded more like a formant filter. Obviously there are tons of possibilities with the synth section.About the recording, others might give more informed comments, but something I noted is that the brass patch (to me) sounds a bit too prominent. Maybe some more reverb and a bit lower volume?Many thanks for sharing it, and that patch...  superb!

title: RE: Red Clay recording
post_content: Mr_-G- wrote:That lead sound is really good, well done. I will load it later. I was surprised that it was made with the NS2 synth section, it sounded more like a formant filter. Obviously there are tons of possibilities with the synth section.About the recording, others might give more informed comments, but something I noted is that the brass patch (to me) sounds a bit too prominent. Maybe some more reverb and a bit lower volume?Many thanks for sharing it, and that patch...  superb!Yes!!! The synth sound is limited but great!! BTW the mod wheel goes from 0 too 100% on the osc shape, and I generously and almost randomly modify it with my hand during playing.Someone also commented me on the brass being too prominent and even artificial... might replace that with something else for other recordings. Right now I am focusing on recording 1 song a day to gain some experience on audio editing. For that I record several takes of "live" solos and then just "glue" them together pasting the best sounding stuff and eliminating the mistakes (like missing a beat, or tonal mistakes). I have done 2 other songs but they were not so great since I was still experimenting a bit with latency and recording with my Zoom H6 but today its Witch Hunt day! If it turns out at least as good as Red Clay I'll upload itSaludos,Gustavo

title: I found a Hammond M3 on trash day
post_content: Hello all,I thought the days of finding a Hammond organ in the trash was long gone.Not so much, evidently.My wife and I were out for our morning walk, and what do I spy in the trash a couple of streets over?A Hammond M3 with reverb!So I promptly gets the truck and brings the organ home:Trash day organDSCN1505.jpg (1.96 MiB) Viewed 4765 timesSo this is going to be my new project.DSCN1506.jpg (2.01 MiB) Viewed 4765 timesFor the most part, it's all there (missing the bench, music rack, and power cord).Unfortunately, if the service log is correct, the last time the tone generator was oiled was 1981Date codes on internal components suggest the organ was made in 1960 and the reverberation unit was added after 1966The tone generator is too tight for a proper start.It was locked up tight initially.However, I've spot oiled it and worked it around by hand.It seems to be loosening up, but makes a gosh-awful squalling noise with frozen tonewheels slipping on their clutches.Life is strangeI now have a couple posts to go edit....Things about never finding a Hammond for under $100, never owning another Hammond again....You know, embarrassing stuff that I'll now have to eat my hat because ofI'll post back when it's working.Cheers, Hanon

post_content: DJKeys wrote:Wow!! What a find.Horacio wrote:You are very lucky!!Indeed!Makes me sad that someone just threw such a great old instrument away.But happy that I ended up with it.It's really in amazing condition physically, the walnut cabinet is just beautiful.My guess is: that it was well cared for as furniture long after it stopped playing as an instrument.It took me about 4 hours worth of work just to get the tone generator free'd up.The drawbars and vibrato scanner still need a good cleaning, plus I need to do a line out mod.I can't describe the feeling of it crackling back to life and becoming an instrument again.Thanks to all for letting me share this with you.Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: I found a Hammond M3 on trash day
post_content: Ouananiche wrote:The report on the one I got was that " the last time I plugged it in there was a lot of smoke coming out of the back"Hi Mike,all electronic devices run on smokeOnce the smoke gets out, it no longer runs.I've let the smoke out of a lot of gear over the yearsNow, if I could just invent a smoke compressor to put it back in, I'd make a fortune.I was really surprised that this organ worked at all.All of the tubes are original Hammond from the early '60sCheers, Hanon

title: RE: I found a Hammond M3 on trash day
post_content: This post is going to run and run! Looking forward to each chapter on how Hanon's amazing find is brought back to it's full operational glory

title: RE: I found a Hammond M3 on trash day
post_content: DoctorC wrote:This post is going to run and run! Looking forward to each chapter on how Hanon's amazing find is brought back to it's full operational gloryI figure, if I can't do anything else, at least I can provide a little entertainment and light readingDay 3.Status update:Noticed several dead tones in the tone generator "same tone spread across several keys"Tracked problem to one stuck tonewheel #24, and one broken wire from tonewheel pickup #39Un-stuck tonewheel, and resoldered the pickup wire (broken wire was hard to find as it was broken inside the insulation).Cleaned and lubricated drawbars.General cosmetic cleaning (vacuuming)DSCN1507.jpg (2.03 MiB) Viewed 3700 timesStill left to do:Install line out modification.track down several loud notes. (Might be resolved with line-out, since it could be speaker/ reverb resonant frequencies)Fix Vibrato/ Chorus (possibly bad tube).Fix reverb switch (the reverb is on all the time)Figure out what the slide switch on the side on the volume pedal was supposed to do.Thanks for reading.Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: I found a Hammond M3 on trash day
post_content: Hello all,just a quick day 4 update (and last update for awhile):Did the line out mod (this facilitated the new demo recording).Figured out the switch on the side of the Expression pedal (pedal tones' sustain)I discovered that the hot (loud) note problem wasn't speaker/ reverb resonance, but a problem with the tone generator (TG).It seems that the organ had been moved rather roughly without the TG locked down, probably when they threw it in the binHey, I might have even done it when I picked it up and quickly ran away with it laughingIt seems that a collision of the TG with the front or back of the organ can cause the magnet rods to get closer, and sometimes hit the TG wheels.I loosened the magnet rod and adjusted the offending tone #61(the line out mod made it easier to match the levels of surrounding tones)It just had to be one in the front that's hard to get toWith this done, the organ sounds good enough to do a quick demo of it.Trash_M3_demo.mp3foreplay_M3_1.mp3When I play a lot, I usually play that Boston one fairly well...I haven't been playing a lotStill no Vibrato/ Chorus (bad tube, waiting on parts){edit} Vibrato/ Chorus fixed by un-sticking scanner and replacing 6AU6 tubeStill need to fix the reverb switch.Long term plans are to re-cap the amplifiers, TG, and vibrato line boxJust quick side note:I had forgotten the rather unique,  musky, oily smell associated with tonewheel organs.Now my music room has an old familiar smell again. (it's probably just me, as in my excitement, I've forgotten to shower)Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: I found a Hammond M3 on trash day
post_content: Must be the tone generator oil on your fingers Hanon, I remember a previous take of you playing foreplay that sounded better but this one is on the M3! I believe Tom Scholz played it on a M3 as well, one of my all time faves on the Hammond along with the solo on Smokin'!What would rock have been without it? You got a precious relic there honor it every day!Shark.

title: RE: I found a Hammond M3 on trash day
post_content: shark wrote:Must be the tone generator oil on your fingers Hanon, I remember a previous take of you playing foreplay that sounded better but this one is on the M3! I believe Tom Scholz played it on a M3 as well, one of my all time faves on the Hammond along with the solo on Smokin'!What would rock have been without it? You got a precious relic there honor it every day!Shark.Hi Shark,I believe this is the best example of what happens when one quits playing, or practicingI may just change my forum name to: "procrastination and sloth" since I seem to be doing more to support that ideal than the "Hanon" practice regimen.The last time I posted Foreplay, I practiced it for a couple days straight, and had been playing a lot too.It's interesting to me that there was a time in the 70s and 80s when all I'd play was a Hammond B-3 and A-100, now the Hammond action feels strange to me, and I much prefer the NE3-61 for organThis is the first M3 that I've ever owned.I'd like to really fix it up and stabilize it's condition (particularly the capacitor situation" so this instrument can be passed on to another musician that recognizes it's significance and value (rather than being a trash day epitaph).I find it simply astounding that it even works at all after half a century of existence.All of the vacuum tubes are original equipment (1960 date codes)I really appreciate everyones indulgence of my thread, and allowing me to share this with you.Cheers, Hanon

title: My home studio in my Wife's den...
post_content: Hi,Below is photos of the studio I started to build from scratch two years ago after having left music for 20 years. Two years ago, my Christmas present from my wife was the possibility to transform the den into my home studio...my previous home studio was based on an Atari 1040 computer and Emagic Notator SL...for those who are old enough to know this....Main viewD2X_6581 (Copier).JPG (1.14 MiB) Viewed 4417 timesSynths and expanders, the D50 has a PA Decoder board with 8 banks of 64 programs. Two Ocean Beach drawbars are on the way to use the Stage II and the D50 as a two manual B3 type organ. Also, two Presonus Eris 5 will take place in July 2013 on each side of the keys for monitoring when I play keyboards...D2H_4216.JPG (1.58 MiB) Viewed 4417 timesExpanders close up, the Proteus 2000 is loaded with Composer, Protozoa, World and X-Lead 7 Rom. The XV5080 has SRX-01 dynamic drums and SRX-10 Big bras...next purchase SRX-09 World and SRX-06 Complete orchestraD2X_6585 (Copier).JPG (1.06 MiB) Viewed 4417 timesThe TX802 comes from my old studio in France 25 years ago as well as the D50. The XLR 19' units are two ART transformers used to balanced and isolate all the expanders outputs before going to the patchbay. One space is ready for another M-Audio unit in order to mix out of the box through the Mackie 1640i 16 Channels...IMG_0702 [].JPG (440.78 KiB) Viewed 4417 timesThe Mackie 1640i on the desk is for the premp, mics and monitoring and the Mackie 1640 (no i...) is for all the synths and expanders outIMG_0708 [].JPG (519.52 KiB) Viewed 4417 timesMicrophones : I added since a Kel audio HM-3C and an AKG C535D2H_4202.JPG (2.02 MiB) Viewed 4417 timesG&L US made guitar HSS Stratocaster style and Egnater tweaker 40, Ibanez SR1200 Premium XXV anniversary edition and Eden WT400+2X10 home made bass cabinet with peavey neo speakersIMG_0686.JPG (1.89 MiB) Viewed 4417 timeswith bass trapIMG_0719.JPG (2.06 MiB) Viewed 3380 timeslast set upD2X_0003 (2).JPG (6.16 MiB) Viewed 3380 timesYes I know, my computer is a 2007 Imac and my next purchase will be a Mac mini with two 24' monitor, the sofware is Cubase 6.5...Hope you enjoy it, I've had to learn evrything as in my old time, audio was not even available for the Atari...and Tweak website was one of the most helpful website for me, I've been reading it on and on and on in order to update my poor skills but I still have to work on cubase abilies...Thanks

title: Opinions on Improved Rehearsal Studio
post_content: Hey everybody,This is a continuation of this thread:http://www.norduserforum.com/your-music ... t4623.htmlI decied to post a different thread since this one is not about improving but demonstrating how it improved. Here we have the two scenarios:Before:2xBehringer B208D for keyboardsBass with Orange AmpGuitar with 70s Peavy AmpMapex horizon drumkitNo acoustic treatmentNo curtains, two exposed windowsAfter:2xElectro Voice ELX 112P for Keyboards, Guitars and BassMapex horizon drumkitAcoustic treatment foamspartially covering walls and ceilingThick Curtains cover both windowsAs always, I recorded this rehearsal (even though it wasn't my usual band, only me, my bass player and a not so good drummer) so here you can compare the before and after by hearing it.Before:Untreated Room - Just the Two of Us.mp3Untreated Room - Saga of Harrison Crabfeathers.mp3Notice how much reverb the recordings have and how poor the drum sounds.After:Treated Room - Loving You.mp3Treated Room -Rhytmn Break.mp3Notice the clarity of drums and almost no reverberation.

title: How to improve Rehearsal Room Acoustics?
post_content: I dont know where to post this, but I figured since I will show off a little bit, then this would be the right place.I have a rehearsal room I got a few months ago. Pictures can be foundhereYet the acoustics are terrible!! I always record our rehearsals with my Zoom Q3HD, you can find themhere(the best one I believe was Moanin, it gets interesting at around minute 4:00)So far it is a small room, about 6m x 4m and I have two big curtain sets. Before there was a lot of bouncy echo. Now there is no audible echo, but there is a lot of reverb and some weird resonations with certain frequencies.For the setup:Mapex Horizon Drumkit with Zildjian Ride and Paiste Crash and hihatMackie VLZ3 802 that mixes a Bass connected directly to it and my Nord Stage 2Behringer B208D, the cheapest compact PA I could find since I did not find the ones I wantedPeavey 1970s Tube Amp with EHX Double Muff and EHX Memory ToyWhat do you recommend me so that it all sounds less muddy. How can I make a much better recording of rehearsals without breaking the bank?Saludos,Gustavo

title: RE: How to improve Rehearsal Room Acoustics?
post_content: Hi Gustavo!Looking at the pictures - the curtains will help to dampen reflections (which is good!) but you've got a very reflective floor and no other damping on the walls.Ideally (budget permitting) - you'd put in a cheap carpet (deaden floor reflections which will give some artifacts on recording) and add some sort of other damping to the walls.The cheapest way of doing the floor is usually carpet tiles or a second hand carpet. On the walls, I'd put up curtain tracks and use curtains (thicker the better) over the walls. Alternatively, you could use acoustic foam, but it's not cheap.I think the wierd resonance is due to where the noise is cancelling out. With curtains over the windows, you've got rid of the most reflective surfaces. However the walls and floor will reflect and then get damped by your own bodies (as it's a small room and there are a few of you in there) - but because you're all standing in different places and possibly moving, it's not going to be a consistent cancellation.If you can damp the walls/floor as above, then the reduced reflection will mean less sound being damped by people/instruments and make the acoustic more consistent.Hope this is of some use!Cheers,Rob.

title: RE: How to improve Rehearsal Room Acoustics?
post_content: Thank you Rob, I agree with you.Gustavo, you may have a look at "Auralex Acoustics Roominators D 36-DST Anthracite".155 €here.As Rob suggested, you can think about all the surfaces in your room, each material has reflection and diffraction, the amount depends on the frequency.From that you can compute the amount of reverberation in your room,here.In practice, you can trigger a sound and measure the response in your room, it's not easy to do in a nominal (calibrated) way. Just walking around with a microphone and a software liketrueRTA, in different places can give you some heuristic.Hint : if you invite ~ 10 nice girls to the rehearsals, it will also absorb frequencies and reduce reverbCheers,Frantz.

title: RE: How to improve Rehearsal Room Acoustics?

title: RE: How to improve Rehearsal Room Acoustics?
post_content: If (or as soon as) you are happy with the acoustics while playing, and you just want to improve the recording, here is an idea that won't cost any money. Disclaimer: I've never done this, though I have tried to edit recordings from a rehearsal room and wished I had prepared for that systematically.First, generate a chirp signal, for example in Audacity ("Generate" menu). For a start, you can try a logarithmic chirp from 50 to 12800 Hz with a duration of 16 seconds; this will give you two seconds per octave and aligns nicely with the equalization tool in Audacity. Play this sound through the speakers in your rehearsal room, e.g. as a sample from your Nord Stage, and record the result just like you would record a song. It should obviously still be a chirp, with as little background noise as possible, but it will have lots of bumps due to room resonances. Load this result into some audio editing software again, and create an EQ curve that turns it back to the original constant-amplitude chirp ("Effect"/"Equalization" in Audacity). (You might have to do multiple EQ passes in series, using large filter lengths for low frequencies and smaller filter lengths for higher frequencies; just always use the smallest length that works.) Be sure to save the EQ curve(s) you use. After you have created one or more EQ curves that neutralize the resonances, just apply these curves to your recorded songs as well.If you are lucky, everything will sound better, but there is also the possibility that your keyboard will sound better (because it runs through the same speakers) but everything else will sound worse. In any case, you probably need to apply one additional EQ to reduce bass frequencies because your speakers cannot reproduce them as well as higher frequencies, causing you to amplify them too much.In case you get satisfactory results and want to reuse the EQ curves over multiple rehearsals, make sure the speakers and microphone are always at the same place.There might be tools to do this sort of thing, but I'm not an expert at all.

title: RE: How to improve Rehearsal Room Acoustics?
post_content: @Funkey: yes, you can do this with a pink noise source, rather than the chirp (so no need to sweep the whole frequency range as the pink noise should have the same energy in all octaves). I think this is what frantzkb suggested with the spectral analyzer. You also need to get a good microphone.The NS2 has a pink noise sample, but I have not checked whether the spectrum is close to the ideal.http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pink_noise

title: RE: How to improve Rehearsal Room Acoustics?
post_content: Late to this thread, but I've conquered this problem in my own way ...It's all about soaking up reflected acoustic energy in my book.  If it's a hard surface, the sound will bounce -- period.  The less, the better.When I re-did my basement a few years ago, here's what I did:- acoustic tile hung from the ceiling- thick, lush carpet with foam padding- power outlets everywhere, bathroom, couches, and a keg-erator (really!) -- ok, not about the acoustics, but ...- thick curtains on every window- multiple hanging wall panels, built by stretching fabric over large frames with pillow filler behind it (fabric store!)Needless to say, my wife was very helpful and supportive ...The room now soaks up sound like a freaking acoustic sponge.  You hear the instruments, not their reflections.  And you can play quite loud if you want, but it doesn't sound harsh.The problem now is that we sound very different on-stage, without all those great acousticsMaybe more than you had in mind, but I nailed it

title: Give me your feedback on this track please
post_content: Hi Guys,Take a minute of your of your precious time to listen to my latest original track and provide me with you comments (helpful)I created it using my Nordstage EX88, MC909 groovebox, Logic Pro and two handsThank you all in advance!Hope you'll enjoy itCheersMatthttp://www.vanmechelen.com

title: RE: Give me your feedback on this track please
post_content: Overall, I think you may have used a bit too much different sounds in there. For me that detracts a bit from the 'core' of the song.Some things I like/don't like:Faint ringing on the right channel, which happens through-out the song. You can especially hear it well from 0:06 to 0:10 (until the piano starts). Might be a compression artifact.0:47 - 0:53 I think the 'bouncing' bell like sound is a distraction.0:42 - 0:48 I like the changes in the filtering of the snare (or what is it?), since for me it adds more life yet doesn't loose connection with the rest of the song even though it is changing quite rapidly.1:03 - I like the 'mzzzz' sound just right of the middle, that is slowly changing and maintained over a few seconds - gives it more body. The same goes for the other atmospheric sounds shortly after this point in the song.1:12 - the 'blip' is maybe a bit loud, though in itself not out of place1:20 - I like the synth sound that starts at this point, it really adds something I think1:25 - here the music gets really 'busy', but in a good way - there seems to be cohesion between the things going on.1:35 - I think this string-like synth sound works well at this point.1:46 - Hmm, nice sound.1:57 - Yes!! The bit happening here (filter resonance?) is the best bit in the song, I think.2:02 - I have trouble following what the piano is doing here (this is probably my fault, not yours).2:13 - More filter goodness? What bugs me a bit is how it starts out in the right channel, seems to pan a bit between left and right for a second and then sits in the middle again.2:33 - 2:48 This bit bugged me the first few times I heard it, but it sounds just right to me now.2:43 - 2:46 These up-lifting chords make me want to play Final Fantasy again. That's a compliment.I like the piano, but I'm not completely sure about the reverb on it (or what I perceive as reverb).Anyway, just coughing up some hairballs. I don't even know the rights terms to use, so please take my comments with a grain of salt.

title: THE decision
post_content: after barely 6 months with my Electro4D, I was forced to discard it.Too good.It made me entirely reconsider my rig, the not-so-good sounds and user-unfriendliness of my old Yamahas, Kawais etc.And by the way, it made me completely fall in love with the B3 sound, making me long for a double-manual.So after much painful thoughts (and MUCH more painful evaluations of my bank account), the decision is taken.I'm selling ALL of my axes (including the almost-new 4D) to go 100% Nord.The local store is taking back my stuff and offering me a killer bargain for a NS2HA88 and a last-in-stock C2.Then all my needs and dreams will be fulfilled, and I will be a happy (albeit broke) keyboardist!

title: RE: THE decision
post_content: That's 34 kilogram of red matter from Sweden.Btw. aren't you going to miss the drawbars on the 4D?

title: RE: THE decision
post_content: mjbrands wrote:That's 34 kilogram of red matter from Sweden.I know, that's the only downside, but I play a lot of piano and I really needed an 88 weighted keybed.And anyway, I'll almost never carry both pieces together, I'm using the NS2 as a do-it-all axe for rock-pop, and the C2 for jazz and funky (and for studying organ at home).mjbrands wrote:Btw. aren't you going to miss the drawbars on the 4D?that was the most painful part of the decision!I'm pretty sure I will miss them, but the C2D was really out of my budget, and the local store was offering me a must-accept deal to get rid of their last C2.Anyway, I'm pretty curious to see how I adapt to the drawbuttons... a bit clumsier for sure, but it'll be interesting to be able to see the preset settings in advance.I'll let you know how it goes, I can't wait to receive my new red stuff!

title: Video of me and Nord Stage 2 at pub jam night
post_content: I am 39 and had never performed infront of anyone before I started going to this regular jam session at the local pub, I was very nervous at first and had another keyboard which didn't have the sounds I wanted, but I got less nervous and worked out some parts to play with the songs , and so I bought the NS2 and I started to make better sounds and have more funI can't read music but I am quite good at figuring out what notes and chords to play. I often play basslines with the Nord (usually just with electric piano sound) and also use organ, piano, and in one song here, trumpetIt is a good laugh and there are lots of bum notes (not just me luckily!)Enjoy![youtube][/youtube]

title: RE: My home studio
post_content: I only use Studio Drummer. Allthough it works not perfectly. Every time I start Kontakt I have to reload SD's database.....but there is a reason for that...Omnisphere is truly amazing. The sounds I use are synths, pads, strings and ambient effects. I use all that on stage. The sounds are warm, chrystal clear and sparky. I love it!!! It really surprised me how it sounds in comparison to the hardware synths of Korg, Yamaha and Roland. I never knew that there could be such difference in quality of sounds.I think Omnisphere can be of really good use for you Topcat. It suits your music. The ambient and atmospheric sounds are mindblowing! Like you never heard before. Ok, not everything is usable but the library is huge!!This is what I recorded in the first week I got Omnisphere -->https://soundcloud.com/meestersmusic/ho ... omnisphere

title: RE: My home studio

title: Poulenc Harpsichord Concerto LIVE - Stage EX
post_content: Hi all,Just a series of links of the movements of the Poulenc Concert Champetre, that I transcribed and arranged for my bandThe Monotremesin December last year.[youtube][/youtube][youtube][/youtube][youtube][/youtube]That's me on the Stage EX. I mainly used the double-string Italian harpsichord samples, but used my control pedal to shift to single-string on occasion.I also threw in some wah, and phaser, and of course I switch to clavinet in a couple of passages.For the final note of the entire piece, I set up a ping-pong delay and rapidly adjusted the rate of delay as I attacked the note. A simple and effective little trick I'm sure many of you know about!Enjoy the sounds and the arrangement, it was a good fun project and I'm hoping to show it to some like-minded musicians.Cheers,Adam

title: RE: Poulenc Harpsichord Concerto LIVE - Stage EX
post_content: Adam,Thats very good indeed !!  Reminds of some of the stuff i used to try and write at college.  The harpsichord suits the music really well and you have chosen your instrumentation carefully.i think you should have a conductor MD the piece rather than yourself cue it from the piano.  Not that you did a bad job or anything.The sections with wah wha and clav. reminds a bit off Frank Zappa's music.Paul

title: RE: Spankin' The Nord (Demo)
post_content: Hey Hambone,don't get me wrong from my previous post, I still LOVE and use Logic a lot! (mostly MainStage now, but still...) I think that whichever DAW you use can be totally awesome if you take the time to learn it! The reason I switched to Ableton for that kind of stuff, like Paul's video is because of how easy it is to trigger loops or sequences within Live. It's basically set up like a big grid (in session view) and you can start and stop any clip (loop/ song, whatever) so easily,I found I had to do a lot of extra work/ steps to accomplish this in Logic. I use both in my live setup, I absolutely love the quality of the Logic instruments, specifically their clav sounds, they're phenomenal! but use Ableton mostly now for launching clips, loops and backing tracks (with a Lemur app on my iPad)!Best,Martin.

title: RE: Spankin' The Nord (Demo)
post_content: Well that sounded very good. title: Just want to say hello
post_content: Dear all,just want to say hello.My name is Alex and I am from North Germany. I have around 20 years experience in stage music with several rock bands (mostly covers from Deep Purple, Uriah Heep, Bad company, Stones, Doors, etc.)After 1 year pausing, I've started in a Irish Folk band. My equipment rigth now is (don't laughan Orla Stage Piano with the iRig Adapter for the iPhone and SampleTank. But truly, this is not a stage equipment (of course, I switch the phone off while playing...)Now on my way to find a new Digi-Piano, I had the journey around all "typical" Pianos like Roland, Yamaha, Kawai. But they are all to big, too heavy and too complicate. My decision is now the Nord Electro HP3, which I want to fill up with some typical ethnic sounds like Harp, Bagpipe, Accordion and of course some strings.At the end of this week, I'll test the Nord and if it's haptical ok for me, I'll buy it.Now here, I have to read so much because this forum is very useful for a Nord-newbee like me.Cheers,Alex

title: RE: Just want to say hello
post_content: Let us know if we can answer any questions for you, and welcome!

title: RE: Just want to say hello
post_content: Hello Alex,Welcome to the forum and thank you for your kind words. When you go to try out the Electro 3, you should probably pay extra attention to how usable the use of samples on the E3 would be for you. I say this, because SampleTank has more features than the E3 when it comes to samples. For example, you can have a maximum of 1 sample per key, so you cannot do any form of velocity switching.The E3 is also mono-timbral, so you can only use one instrument at a time. For example, you cannot use a piano and a pad sound at the same time.  There are ways to 'fake' it using samples, but in general you'll loose the dynamics of the piano. The E3 also cannot do splits nor is it meant for controlling external equipment. While you would be able to use (for example) SampleTank to make the pad sounds to go with a piano sound on the E3, you wouldn't be able to (flexibly) switch sounds on the SampleTank from the E3 nor could you use splits (unless SampleTank could do that internally using a single MIDI channel).A second hand Stage Ex would be able to do those things (and probably cost about the same), but with weighted keys it would be quite a bit heavier. A 88-key Stage with a weighted keyboard is light for a full-size stage piano, but I think it still weighs a whopping 25 kg (or something like that).

title: RE: Just want to say hello
post_content: @bdoddsThank you very much for your welcome. You can believe, that I will come over with questions, when the CN E3 is standing on my table@mjbrandsThank you very much for your expressions about the CN and what it can't do. These points are also very helpful to make a decision.Normally, I only use one sound for a song. Also for me is important, to use at least only a piano, an accordion, a bagpipe or a celtic harp. maybe some strings for a sound carpet.I was impressed about the light weight of only 11 kg and also I don't need all 88 keys, so 73 is more than enough. Unfortunately, you cant find any keyboard, which has hammer action keys with only 73 keys and which is so light. This is a very good reason for me, to chose it. I'll use the keyboard while rehearsals, at home and at stage. So it must be not so heavy. Remember, I am an old man with a hammond used backCheers,Alex

title: RE: Just want to say hello
post_content: The sample section on an electro is more analogous to an old Mellotron, so think in those terms.  Accordion is available from Nord, but you may have a harder time finding a good bagpipe and harp, though I found a CD of 'world instruments' out there someone is selling with nsmp files.  It's advertised as for the Wave, but the nsmp files should work nonetheless.  I can't verify the quality or non-scam-ness of that site so I won't post it, but a simple google search will turn it up easily.  I'd make sure the Electro will do what you need from a sound perspective first.  Worst case if you have a source sound you can always sample it with the sample editor, but it's always nice when someone else has done the work already.

title: RE: Album Recorded on Nord StageEX 88
post_content: You're welcome Johannes. I really appreciate the great feedback!For non-Nord Stage Classic/EX users, here's some info on how to achieve some of the sounds in the album:Organ - MASTEROrgan Model: B3, Vibrato/Chorus: C3, Percussions: Volume soft, Decay slow, Harmonic (off), Sustain pedal: on.Drawbars: SUB BAS16: 8, SUB3 STR16: 3, FUND FLUTE8: 8 (all other drawbars off)AMPSIM/EQ: on. Treble -11.5db, Mid +10.5db, Bass +15dbREVERB: on. Hall. Dry Wet 3.5Arpeggio/Ping pong PianoStudio Grand2 YaC7.EFFECTS: Delay Rate/Tempo: 120bpm, delay feedback 6.5, delay amount 65, ping pong: onArpeggio RhodesEpiano 3 Mk11 ShallowEffects: Delay tempo 150bpm 200ms, Delay amount 54, delay feedback 6.9, ping pong: onEnjoy!

title: RE: Home - red home... my little music corner
post_content: Wow, an Ensoniq SD-1...

title: RE: Home - red home... my little music corner
post_content: Oh yes - my „new“ SD-1...I owned an ESQ-1 from 1986 to 2008 and I loved it. That sound was great (for that time) and „warm“ and I used a lot the sequencer because it was so easy to use.Unfortunately I sold it because we moved and there was no more space for my (several) keys.But I missed it later and so I looked for another Ensoniq.I fell over the SD-1 (built in 1991) in Denmark just a few weeks ago and it looked terrible: the keys were mega-dirty, one key was broken, the sliders and knobs looked like being unused for years - but it worked!So I gave all the keys a bath, cleaned the synth inside and outside, used some sprays, replaced the key, looked for 3,5“-disks (!) and OS- and sequencer-software and now it is a respectably looking SD-1.The sound is very „smoky“ but warm and fat and there is a lot of effects on the presets. But the programming and the handling of the sequencer is like I knew it from the ESQ-1. It just makes a lot of fun with such a “dinosaur”. I hope it will run a long time...

title: RE: Home - red home... my little music corner
post_content: Ensoniq made great stuff once. They also made some shite products, of which I -unfortunately- used to own one, the SQ2.But their list of good synths is long: the SD1, TS10/12, MR61/76/rack and of course Hiphop fav ASR-10. Pity they went under.

title: New Desk [Home Studio]
post_content: So about 2 weeks ago I got this desk from SoundCraft Station and I have it all setup as a workstation for both music and well... work. Thought some may find this cool, so there´s the pics. I am currently using my NS2 SW on the desk but these pictures were taken when my NS 88 was on the desk. The good thing is that it's quite easy to put it there.I have all my cables going on the back of the desk. On the left side monitor stand I have my trusty Mackie VLZ3 802 with my Onyx Blackjack on front (to easily control my computer´s audio level). I take advantage of the open back of the monitor stand to have all cables run through the back and leave a clean-cable free desk space. On the bottom I put a 6-Outlet Surge Protector that I power use to power up/down my mixer, speakers and keyboard. That's so I do not have to struggle turning on the Speakers or the mixer.Desk all setup with NS 88 ClassicIMG_20120927_172213.jpg (2.06 MiB) Viewed 4167 timesAnd here's a pic of the desk by itselfPlain DeskIMG_20120927_162533.jpg (2.18 MiB) Viewed 4167 times
