title: School Jazz band live [Youtube Video]
post_content: Hey everyone, yesterday we had a quite good (in our opinion) gig. It was at the food court of a school event and there were about 100-200 people there. We had quite a positive reception, even more than rock classics!!The interesting parts for you folks: I used only my Nord Stage 2 SW, mainly a piano, EP, B3 and a part of split between EP and Flute in "Niño Perido". What I disliked is my new keyboard stand. It's a Hercules 113-B and I got it for its light weight since I had to carry all the things by myself and wanted to do that in one trip instead of two. The stand is absolutely fantastic but its height turned out to be either too low or too high when I am standing up (but its perfect when sitting down).So here is the youtube playlist:And here is what I consider my favorite time of the gig:[youtube][/youtube]

title: Trio Triad Riot – powered by Nord C1
post_content: Hi guys,I thought I'd introduce one of my organ trios here – TRIO TRIAD RIOT from Regensburg, Germany.We've been playing together for about 5 years now, and two years ago we recorded our first CD "Turn The Turnaround Around" with mostly originals of our guitarist.Here's a link to our myspace profile with some clips of our CD:http://www.myspace.com/triotriadriotThe organ on the recording is my Nord C1, amped by a 1969 Dynacord Hi-FI Favorit II, a tube head with 85 watts, and a heavily modified 1978 Solton Dopplertone 150, a German/Italian Leslie clone. title: Sheet Music (Doris-Anne)
post_content: "Doris Anne" - Combo Arrangement of an original composition (Copyright - Paul David Seaman, 1998) scored for Bb Horn, Piano, Bass and Drums.  West Coast Modal Jazz in its style and choice of harmony.Doris-Anne score and parts new.pdf'Doris-Anne' (comp - Seaman)(292.63 KiB) Downloaded 491 times

title: RE: Sheet Music (Doris-Anne)
post_content: Hello Paul,Nice score, I'd like to hear it plaid, have you posted it yet ?

title: RE: Sheet Music (Doris-Anne)
post_content: Hi Frantz,i do have a recording but it is of a larger scale version i scored for Big Band, so i am not too sure if it would be helpful or not to the listener.Best,Paul

title: RE: Sheet Music (Doris-Anne)
post_content: Hi folks,As requested by a few members, here is the 'Head' section of my composition Doris-Anne.  It features the Guildhall School of Music Jazz Orchestra (2001).  Obviously the harmonies are more complex in this recorded version due to the composition being scored for 17 x instruments (rather than quartet).Anyway, i hope it helps.....Best,PaulDoris.mp3

title: RE: Sheet Music (Doris-Anne)
post_content: Yes Paul !! Thank you, I tried to play your tune, I got the melody over the A key (or it relative Db minor).But how do you play that Em9A13 chord ?

title: RE: Sheet Music (Doris-Anne)
post_content: Hi Frantz,The Em9 chord is voiced (from the bottom upwards) E,G,B,F#.  The Bass player will be playing the E (as it is written in his part) and so you can omit this note from your chord.  Therefore your Left Hand will be playing G,B,D,F#.  However, if you do not have a Bass player present then you will need to play E,G,B,D (unless you have very long fingers and can stretch all 5 x notes with your left hand !!).The same rules apply to the A13 chord.  So (upwards) G,B,C#,F# if you have a Bass player.  If not then G,A,C#,E.Notice that i have included to ROOT (E and A), and omitted the upper-extension (F#  and F#) in the chord if there is no Bass player present.These types of voicings sound good when written for Trombones in a big band (though i did not do so in this arrangement because i chose to let the Rhythm Section play these particular chords, and to feature the upper Trombones playing the melody on the B Section of the tune).Hope that answers your questions.Best,Paul

title: RE: Sheet Music (Doris-Anne)
post_content: Oh yes, thank you for your answer.I now move from Em9 to A13, I just change the big finger from D to C# and left hand from E to A  => sounds better now !I find what you are sharing interesting, your PDF is really nice with parts and solos indications ( E and F Dorian ...).I was puzzled on part A because the signature suggest the A scale to me, but the Em chord suggests a G pitch that is not in the scale, not a blue note, I could not make it "sound" good.  The E dorian includes that G pitch so ... I've been fooled by the signature.For the melody of "part B" and solos on F dorian, I was puzzled because I expected a signature change to Eb.Thank you for sharing Paul, and your comments are very welcome.Frantz.

title: RE: Sheet Music (Doris-Anne)
post_content: Dear Frantz,Thank you for your very interesting observations.Regarding the falling semitone intervals in the Left Hand chords of Em7 and A7, this technique is refered to as VOICE LEADING.  Generally speaking, good Harmony consists of one chord smoothly moving (resolving) into another.  And this is produced by applying good Voice Leading.Because this piece is a MODAL composistion, i could have written it in OPEN KEY (ie. with NO Key Signature).  But because each Section has such a strong sense of Tonality, i decided to assign Key Signatures (those being of the respective Relative Majors).For IMPROVISATORY Scale choices, i would use E Dorian (D Major) for the A Sections and F Dorian (Eb Major) for the B Section.i hope you find this useful.............Best,Paul

title: RE: Upgraded
post_content: Welcome to the forum Zephonic, nice setup you have there.Have you tried playing the piano sounds on the Fantom using the Nord? I was just wondering how that felt.Btw. do I spot more keys in the top right of that image, or is it somehow a reflection?

title: RE: Upgraded
post_content: Thanks, MJ. Fellow Dutchie, are you?No, that's the mirror. I am pretty much ITB nowadays and the NP88 and FanX7 are the only hardware I am left with. I do plan to replace the latter with a MotifXF7 sometime later this year.The Fantom pianos do sound a lot better when played from weighted keys, but they have a 'plasticky' quality and don't hold up when used with subpar amplification (which is most of the time). Roland's best sounds are on the expansion boards, the stuff in the Fantom is meh. But they really excel at velocity response and aftertouch. I am reprogramming the board as I no longer need it for piano/ep/clav duties.For now I'm using the factory sounds in the NP88, but when I get some time I'm gonna check out the other libraries. I heard the Bosendorfer and Bright Grand samples at Dave Ferris' place, but I kind of prefer the 'woodiness' of the Lady D. Haven't gigged with it yet, though.

title: Keycloth?
post_content: Would key cloth dampen the sound of the keys of the nord stage?Is it possible to add some?

title: RE: Keycloth?
post_content: Depends on the frequency of the sound I suppose. I think the metal bottom plate acts as a resonator for vibrations generated by playing on the keys. Dampening the bottom plate might be more effective. I suppose you could stick some of that 'asphalt' (bitumen) tape on the bottom under the keys - that stuff is used for sound isolating sheet metal parts in cars, HVAC, etc. It is made of tar and fairly heavy/rubbery.To see if this actually would help, you could try playing the keys while pressing your flat hand firmly against the bottom plate (say below where you're playing) to see if the sound is noticeably less. If it isn't, damping the bottom plate with stuff like that will likely not help (much).

title: RE: Keycloth?
post_content: I contacted Nord support about the key sound...they advised against putting anything inside the case to dampen the sound...instead, I put several layers of cloth (folded over bedsheet) between the Stage and the rack..it seems to help.

title: RE: Keycloth?
post_content: Whether damping is done inside or on the outside of the Nord; if vibration of the bottom plate amplifies the noise, preventing the bottom plate from vibrating (too much) should help. The noise is not likely to bother you when playing live, so if you could lessen it a bit at home by placing it on something (maybe some cloth as Sakari suggests) that would be excellent.

title: RE: Keycloth?
post_content: I was thinking keycloth because the thumping noise of the keys does not bother me.Only when I play fast notes,the keys release and cause a clacking noise that I though could be reduce by keycloth.thanks for the advice.Now I dont think that would work.

title: Flight Of The Bumble Bee on Stage 2
post_content: Just learnt to fly, well... to play Flight Of The Bumble Bee on my new Stage 2. Can't go as fast as I should (160BPM) without more training, this teaches you your limits. I don't have a real real piano at hands, so cannot tell if it would be easier on one. I used the Grand Lady D Steinway.[youtube][/youtube]

title: RE: Flight Of The Bumble Bee on Stage 2
post_content: Not bad at all, do you practice with a metronome? And by that I don't just mean getting tempos, but actually playing the whole piece with click...You could try that as an exercise: record another video with click in the background, even if it's slower (practice will get you there) but at least it will be in time..Cheers!edit: It's a little harder on a proper grand. You'd need to articulate better since the keys are heavier.

title: RE: Flight Of The Bumble Bee on Stage 2
post_content: Thanks. I don't use a metronome, and I don't have rhythm. I know, this doesn't make sense... I'm just lazy. Not sure if an heavier keyboard wouldn't be easier. Keys might "bounce back" faster, be a bit less "mushy", even if they are heavier too press? But I have a feeling the Clavia keyboard might be the best compromise for lazy players like me: not too heavy but still fast tight response.

title: RE: Flight Of The Bumble Bee on Stage 2
post_content: Laziness has nothing to do with it in my opinion. Playing with a metronome just solidifies your time.So I recommend practicing with a metronome at all times.Playing on a real grand that has heavier keys is universally agreed harder. You need to properly articulate your fingers and to have way better stamina.I feel this when I switch from the grand to my NP88 - way easier to play faster, though I lose some dynamics.

title: Last Thing At Night
post_content: I am a confirmed hard rocker coming from a classical/prog rock background. I don't do jazz or blues - they're just not in my DNA. So I was surprised to come across this when I was trawling through some old cassettes recently. It's live off the mixing board, warts and all, from the SFX Hall in Dublin back in 1987.The intro was a DX7 and D50 MIDIed together, and the main "organ" part, as well as the pad on the outro fade, was my trusty old Juno 60.Enjoy the guitar work of the hugely talented Pat McManus.Last Thing At Night live - new edit.mp3Edit - found some pics to go with it. Shades, spiky hair and A-frames - those were the days!HIGHGIG3.JPG (72.75 KiB) Viewed 2645 timesHIGHGIG1 PS.jpg (79.81 KiB) Viewed 2645 times

title: RE: Last Thing At Night
post_content: Are you going into "Sexual Harrassment in the Workplace" at the end there?

title: RE: Last Thing At Night
post_content: bdodds wrote:Are you going into "Sexual Harrassment in the Workplace" at the end there?No, it's a song called "Lonely Soul", but it is pretty much the same basic chord structure.

title: RE: Last Thing At Night
post_content: Yeah it's definitely a different key, but sounds so uncanny..  Good stuff, regardless - didn't mean to insinuate anything negative!

title: RE: Last Thing At Night
post_content: bdodds wrote:Yeah it's definitely a different key, but sounds so uncanny..  Good stuff, regardless - didn't mean to insinuate anything negative!Not at all, the writing was nothing to do with me, so no worries.

title: RE: Last Thing At Night
post_content: Besides, comparing you to Zappa is hardly an insult, imho..Man the d50/dx7 certainly brings you back, huh? Fantastic guitar tone too, considering the era..

title: RE: Last Thing At Night
post_content: bdodds wrote:Man the d50/dx7 certainly brings you back, huh?Yes, the D50 had just been released, I thought I'd died and gone to heaven...soundwise, it was streets ahead of anything else. Actually, I started using mine again just recently, it still does some unique things, and I find its top end cuts through a mix really well. I hated the DX7, the secret was to get your hands on the best available sounds - I had an Alesis Datadisk and everywhere I went, I used to sneakily copy sounds from every synth I came across. Producers and session players' synths left lying in studios yielded sounds far better than the general public could get their hands on. With the right sounds, the DX7 became very usable.Edit: Actually, I think the Datadisk came later, at first I photocopied blank patch charts and laboriously copied sounds I liked parameter-by-parameter. 147 on a DX7 if I remember correctly. I must have been mad.

title: RE: Last Thing At Night
post_content: So smooth!   Loved the pads...  And one hell of a guitarist!Thanks for sharing

title: RE: Last Thing At Night
post_content: RedLeo wrote:Yes, the D50 had just been released, I thought I'd died and gone toheaven...soundwise, it was streets ahead of anything else.yep, Staccato Heaven to be exactI love the song and gig photo.You are hereby inducted into the Eighties' Big Hair Hall of Fame.I quite agree about the DX-7.It seems as if there were only a small group of successful programmers out there.Top of the list was John Chowning, Bo Tomlyn, Brian Eno, Wendy Carlos.Bottom of the list was me and some guy in outer mongoliaIn all fairness, if guy in outer mongolia had actually seen, or even cared about the DX-7, he'd have risen several rungs above me.Thanks for sharingCheers, Hanon

title: Free albums
post_content: Hello all.My band and I would like to share our music with all of you.  We have just released our latest and last album "PFSF".  I wouldn't go so far as saying that this is a 'Nord-heavy' album, there are in fact 7 different keyboards used in the recordings. title: anyone using a sub in their rig???
post_content: Just wondering....there is a JBL EON518s available here locally at a very good price.  I am currently using a Traynor K4, one channel for NS2 73 and one channel for Privia PX3 (and other channel for Line 6 pod xtlive for guitar sometimes, will probably uupgrade that to hd500).  Anyone out there using a sub in their rig?  Thanks, and Happy New Year.

title: RE: anyone using a sub in their rig???
post_content: As I have had no responses either way, I'll take that as a "no" to my question.Thanks.

title: RE: anyone using a sub in their rig???
post_content: h8hoos wrote:As I have had no responses either way, I'll take that as a "no" to my question.Thanks.Hello h8hoos,I wanted to give this one some time to see how others would respond, before chiming in myself.I have a couple of old school thoughts which may no longer be valid in certain newer genres of music.This opinion from an old guy's perspective:I find accentuated frequencies from 75Hz down to be counterproductive in a stage monitoring environment.With that said, I find subs very useful and beneficial to the FOH (mains) system as it lends a nice definition to the bass, and bass drum(s) while clarifying the sound of the lows (simply by removing that spectrum from the 15" speakers) and sending them to a dedicated 15" or 18" sub bass system. When set up in a push/pull arrangement, subs can be devastatingly effective in a Rave, House, Dub mix.Every time that I have tried to use stage monitoring with 15" instead of 12" or 10" for keys, I find myself rolling the bass off because the increased bass frequencies of the 15" prevent me from adequately hearing/feeling what the drummer and bass player are doing.Hope this helps.Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: anyone using a sub in their rig???
post_content: I had been considering adding a sub for use in bigger venues, but Hanon's remarks give me something to consider. I routinely roll off the bottom end especiallypiano patches.  Having one for use at home might be nice however. It might also be useful for situations without  a bass player, when trying to punch out bass hopefully  without adding too much more overall volume.  Cheers Mike

title: RE: Barber's Adagio For Strings on NS2
post_content: Thanks. My background is classical piano training when I was a kid, more or less forced by my parents. I think for about 8 years. I didn't enjoy it a lot and was not motivated. I now realize I could have work much harder. I recently had a renewed interest, and I think Clavia is in part responsible for this. My ultimate goal with orchestral sounds is to do the Mozart (I'm his #1 fan and even moved my tough piano teacher playing it one timeconcertos (one solo piano vs the orchestra), so this Adagio was an easy piece to try to experiment and find a sound. I'd record 2 tracks: the piano solo, and a piano transcription of the orchestra. But again, I'm not very optimistic, all this does is making me realize how great an orchestra is. Hence my attempts to do it electronic, but then the more I tweak it to my liking, the less electronic it becomes, and when it ends up like an orchestra, what's the point, a real orchestra does it better.

title: My new NS2 76 setup, accessories & amplification
post_content: New user, thought I'd share some thoughts about my setup.Former setupI used to have a NE3 73 and a Yamaha S90ES (great piano sound). I like a simple and portable setup, so I never gigged with both of them together. Mostly I was gigging with the NE3, but I was never happy with the piano sound (especially not when playing mono) and the keybed for piano playing. So I found myself playing mostly organ or rhodes.My amplifier was an AER AG8, which is a little, light, but strong and powerful amplifier, with a great sound although a little too "muddy" for piano sounds.My keyboard stand was a Ultimate Support V-stand. It is not available anymore, although I still think it was the best and coolest stand in the world.NS2I now bought the NS2 76 HA to have both keyboards in one, and to rediscover the joy of piano playing. It is a fantastic instrument, but it is not easy to use - you need to read the manual. I still need a lot of time to discover all the possibilities.My main concern is the piano sound. The Bosendorfer XL is fantastic in stereo, and acceptable in mono. I do hope Clavia will once release a mono piano sound as good as the mono S90ES piano sound.Soft case & flightcaseI bought the Nord soft case. It's sturdy enough (much more padding then the NE3 soft case) and has good wheels. It also holds the music stand and the keyboard stand. But some critics...You cannot hold the bag at the top handle and then roll it, because then the angle with the ground is too small, and the bag touches the ground. You need to use the handle in the middle of the bag and hold the piano in a 70° angle, which is not very handy.When you first want to use the bag, you have to insert the padding in a right way. I did not do this good enough apparently, because there was still some zipper not covered, which damaged the side of my NS2.I also bought a flightcase in the event that it will be transported by someone else or perhaps (if I'm lucky) to travel by plane:http://www.thomann.de/be/thon_keyboard_ ... i_holz.htm. I am happy with it, although the wheels are not of the best quality.Nord Keyboard StandAlthough I am very happy with my V-Stand, the convenience of "everything in one bag" and the lower weight convinced me to buy the Nord Keyboard Stand.  It is very sturdy, and it is easier to move the NS, as the stand is attached to it.  It of course takes a minute or two to set up, whereas the V-stand was a matter of seconds.My greatest concern are the alternative longer tubes to play standing up. They simply aren't long enough, and I am of average height (1m75). I plan to modify the longer tubes by also adding a screw thread on the other side of the tube. I can then combine the shorter and the longer tubes to play in a standing position. To be continued.Nord Music StandLightweight, sturdy, extra wide, easy to install (just slide it in the keyboard) and fits in the Nord soft case. Absolutely recommended.AmplificationAs the stereo piano sound is so good, I decided to buy a pair of Electrovoice ZXA1-100 amplifiers, and the Yamaha Stagepas 300 trolley to transport them. I will probably get a JBL EON 510 bag too, for when I only need one of them.They sound as close to hifi speakers as you can get, go quite loud (although I have the impression my AG8 could go louder), and are small and lightweight. Biggest concern here is the hiss, which is there when you power on the speakers. This makes it unuseable in room practice/studio applications, but it is not noticeable on stage, except maybe for very quiet venues or classical performances.So now I have a setup that fits in nearly every car, and I can carry both the piano, stand and amps in one time from car to stage. Moreover, the NS2 is a pleasure to play on. Spent a lot of money, but I'm happy I did.

title: Sailboat Music Studio
post_content: Hi folks...I am delighted to discover this forum after settling on the NS2 (88) for my new rig... a good community is every bit as important as a well-engineered product!I don't have any current questions for you, but I thought it would be fun to say hello and note that the Stage 2 is going aboard a sailboat... installed under a lift-up panel embedded in the desk of the on-board lab (a region that would be the salon in most boats). I've pulled out the original cramped dinette and uncomfortable settee, and am building a console system with four 12U rack spaces and a desktop just under 8 feet wide. Lots of geekery is afoot, with a network of Arduino nodes, robust ham radio station, lab instruments, and systems... and with my musical interests, of course I have to have a built-in keyboard as well. My current rig is a Roland RD-700SX, and while I like it and have certainly not outgrown it, the physical size is relatively bulky and the user-interface paradigm is a bit cumbersome.So after a few weeks of agonizing over the choices (integrated workstations like Motif), a MIDI controller augmented by a rack synth and/or software instruments, downsizing to something cheap and expendable for the harsh environment, or just living with what I have which really isn't bad at all)... I seem to have latched on the Stage 2 as the perfect solution. Not only is it as tidy dimensionally as such a machine can get, but I love the immediate editability of the control panel and the overall look. I haven't even touched one yet, but am pretty sure one is in my near future.This boat project (Nomadness) is the successor to my earlier technomadic geekery - a computerized recumbent bicycle on which I traveled 17,000 miles around the US back in the 80s, and then the Microship, an amphibian pedal/solar/sail micro-trimaran. The new boat, at 44 feet, is quite a bit more comfortable.  Seehttp://nomadness.comfor the context... the Stage 2 will be a very visible part of the project as it unfolds.Anyway, thanks for being here... I look forward to participating and asking the inevitable newbie questions!Cheers,Steve

title: RE: Sailboat Music Studio
post_content: That does SOUND geeky, sold me at the Arduino part. Definitely GEEKY.Welcome to the forums!! It does looks like an interesting project, how the hell do you get the time to do such things?? Seems impossible to me. Specially with your weekly report.Found your video here:Quite good if you ask me, played with real emotion.Good playing, also we've been playing for about the same time now! (I started about 5 years ago when I got the Nord Stage)Saludos,Gustavo

title: RE: Sailboat Music Studio
post_content: Thank you so much for the welcome, Gustavo (and for the kind words on my Gnossiennes of last year... I'm really looking forward to re-recording them with the Nord). I really wish I had started long ago, and not at age 54.As to finding the time for gonzo engineering projects... it's what I do for a living.  I used to joke, while pedaling around the US on theWinnebikoand its successors, that it was a shame my old high-school guidance counselor never suggested this as a career option. In a sense, I never outgrew science fairs; my career, so to speak, is to build bizarre contraptions (though never gratuitously bizarre), travel with them, write about the adventures, and try to mine the systems for the occasional product spin-off.  (That last one has always been my weakness; I tend to just publish everything, which is easier but much less profitable.)The piano integration on the boat should be fun, and will be strongly shaped by this important truth:Water corrodes. Salt water corrodes absolutely.That translates into conformal coatings, a stowage system that sheds stray droplets past (and not into) the piano, vapor-phase corrosion inhibitors, improved sealing, and a few spares for I/O devices.  That latter is actually one of the things that most attracts me to this machine... it looks very solidly built, with real hardware for controls instead of a big touchscreen. Serviceability is a huge issue for anything that goes to sea, and even though this will be very well coddled in its mounting nest, it's still a challenging environment when things get feisty.As this comes together, I'll post here... the Stage 2 should integrate very smoothly into the wrap-around console, right down to the fonts and graphics.Oh, here's the "land-based" studio with that Roland I mentioned.  This pic is from 2007 or so, shortly after I built the desk:The Roland will go to eBay, and I'll probably sell that wonderful Mackie mixer... it's dead silent, but would not be at all console-mountable on the boat. For that, I picked up an Edirol M16DX, which separates the control surface from the black box bristling with connectors. A bit more hiss, but it solves a huge packaging problem.Cheers!Steve

title: RE: Sailboat Music Studio
post_content: Well lets hope that the sea lets your future NS2 live for a few years!

title: RE: Wurly boogie on NE3
post_content: Thanks, Hanon!Influences? Ray Charles, Dr John, Billy Preston, Booker T Jones, Nicky Hopkins, Professor Longhair. And yes, Ian McLagan! Although my main gig at the moment is The Skanx, a 9-piece ska/funk/reggae outfit (see earlier post  about my rig), my musical roots are definitely in the blues. title: My band and rig...
post_content: I play keyboards withThe Skanxhttp://www.theskanxband.co.uk, a 9-piece ska/funk band based in Penge, south-east London.Our line-up is:Lori: vocals, songwritingWayne: vocals, MC, trombone, songwritingNick: guitarJimi: bass guitarSimon: organ, Wurlitzer piano, StylophonePaul: drumsWendy: trumpet, backing vocalsStuart: trumpet, percussion, backing vocalsLiam: tenor saxophoneHere is a video:[youtube][/youtube]My keyboard rig has changed over the past 4 years, but I have always (deliberately) stuck to only two sounds; organ and Wurlitzer piano. When I started, I used a Casio WK-3000 for all my sounds - it's actually got a very good Wurly sound for the price, plus a dedicated drawbar organ and Leslie sim. I added a Stylophone to this fairly early on, playing them through a no-name 30-watt guitar combo.Towards the end of 2009, the band bought a vintage Wurlitzer 200, just in time to use it alongside the Casio's organ sound on the recordings for our début EP. I upgraded my amplification to an 80-watt 4-channel keyboard amp.In early 2011 we unfortunately had to stop gigging with the Wurlitzer as it was too heavy, fragile and temperamental. At the same time, the band bought a second-hand Roland VK-7 drawbar organ, and I have been using that ever since, along with the Casio's Wurlitzer sound until two weeks ago, when my father bought me a Nord Electro 3 73 for a (very generous) 50th birthday present! The reason I still use the Roland is that in many songs I use piano and organ at the same time, or change between them too quickly to switch sounds.Current rig:Stylophone S1Roland VK-7 organNord Electro 3 73the t.amp PA4080-KB combo ampFatar sustain pedalSchaller volume pedal with stereo splitter cableSimon Beck

title: RedLeo's Kbd Rig
post_content: Hi everyoneRedLeo kbd rig 2010.jpg (89.58 KiB) Viewed 3428 timesI thought I'd share my setup with the forum. This is last year's rig, the Roland A50 and Triton Rack have since been replaced with a Triton Extreme 76, while my rack has expanded to 6U with the addition of a Yamaha TX802. (It now sits on the floor beside me). Personal monitoring, which is in addition to any stage monitoring I am given, is either an ElectroVoice SXa1 or a Mackie SRM450, depending on how much volume I need, and is run from the Aux out of my rack mixer so I can turn it up or down without affecting anything else.I intend to add a VA synth - probably a NL3 - to take the pressure off my Extreme in the near future. I am really looking forward to this, the MOSS board in my Extreme is very powerful, but I'm finding it too much trouble to program, and I usually end up using the synth section of my Stage Classic instead cos it's much easier just to grab the knobs and twiddle.I'll post some pictures of my new rig as soon as I've got some.

title: RE: RedLeo's Kbd Rig
post_content: Hi RedLeo,Cool setup!I like what you did there with the rack and mic boom standWhich concert venue was that and where?I used to have a Triton Classic with exb-moss, I quite agree... Love the sound, hate the programming. It's not that it was difficult to program so much as it's lack of dedicated controls.Thanks for sharing your world. I wish more members would follow your example.Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: RedLeo's Kbd Rig
post_content: Hi HanonThanks for your kind words. I like simple solutions, and having the rack available to twiddle was a great advantage. In case you're wondering, it's not balancing by itself, it's secured with a couple of spider cables! Wait till you see my Amazing Simple Pedalboard Solution For The DIY-Challenged.The venue was the Mathew Street Festival in Liverpool, and I was playing for a Killers tribute band called The Fillers. It was a fun but very challenging gig. Believe it or not, my kbd setup was not really adequate for the amount of parts and sounds I needed. Nothing difficult to play, but a nightmare logistically.Yes, that was the same frustration with the MOSS board. Analogue synth programming needs enough controls so you can balance envelope, filter and oscillator etc adjustments against each other.

title: RE: RedLeo's Kbd Rig
post_content: Hi there, nice setup and great pic!!May I ask, do you really program the Yamaha TX802?? I hear its near to impossible to do so! and which sound do you get from that? Doesn't the Stage's FM section produce close enough results?About the VA... from what I have heard, the NL2x sounds more "analogue" than the Nord Lead 3, but of course that may be subjective. Also keep in mind you can get a brand new NL2x and that is not the case with the NL3. Another VA I would consider is something blue from novation (nova series). The new ultranova is probably their best VA but it has a very "limited" physical interface, although it is supposedly made to be easy to manipulate. I just gotta love those liquid filters!! Also, it's got a nice and decent vocoder.

title: RE: RedLeo's Kbd Rig
post_content: Hi gustavoThanks for your comments and some great questions!First, about the TX802: No, I don't actually program it myself, it's way beyond my capabilites apart from simple tweaks to envelopes and the like. Instead, I have a a large collection of pro Voice sounds which I have painstakingly gathered over the years from producers, session players and the like, which I then "mix and match" in Performances to get what I need. The two main reasons I bought a TX802 (again!) are:1. While ROMplers (or the Stage) provide basic DX-type sounds like bells and so on, if it doesn't have a sound I need, it's pretty much impossible to synthesise it from scratch on a non-DX type synth. I am a professional working musician, "close enough" isn't good enough for me, I often need to reproduce sounds for the original artiste, and my sound design has to be spot-on. Plus I have lots of cool bass, pad etc type sounds which I love cos they have a very different flavour from analogue synthesis.2. My Extreme gets used a lot, and its limited 8-part multitimbrality is an issue (I try to use one Combi per song for live performance). Handing some sounds over to other synths should leave the Triton free to do what it does best instead of trying to get it to do everything at once.About VA, I was looking for opinions about which synth to get. I thought a Nord would be best for me, as it needs to be reliable, multitimbral, have plenty of polyphony, and have pretty much all the knobs I need on the front panel. A true analog would possibly sound better, but modern analog synths are very expensive for what they deliver.I know the debate between the sound of the 2X versus the Lead 3 - some say the difference is like night and day, while others say the difference is pretty minor. I haven't seen anything on Youtube demos that convinces me that there's much real difference between them, and the Lead 3's enhanced synthesis capabilites, keyboard aftertouch, and front panel design - which many people say is simply the best layout ever - are pretty convincing. On the other hand, both synths suffer from limited 4 octave keyboards and a complete lack on onboard EQ or effects, so my mind isn't made up yet. All suggestions welcomed!To any admins: I know this is a Nord forum, but I am hoping that it would be good to have an area for discussions on other synths as well; all synths are dear to my heart and I love any opportunity to exchange knowledge, or indeed just general chit-chat, about our favourite toys.

title: RE: RedLeo's Kbd Rig
post_content: RedLeo wrote:To any admins: I know this is a Nord forum, but I am hoping that it would be good to have an area for discussions on other synths as well; all synths are dear to my heart and I love any opportunity to exchange knowledge, or indeed just general chit-chat, about our favourite toys.Hi RedLeo,The forum isn't exclusive to Nord gear. While that IS the primary focus, the members are free to discuss any musical equipment.Less than 20% of the instruments that I own are made by Nord.Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: RedLeo's Kbd Rig
post_content: Hi,indeed no problem to discuss other gear. Maybe we should separate Accessoires and Other Gear Forums to make this more clear. Worth thinking about!EDIT: In fact, always was kind of looking for a better structure of the general topics so took this suggestion and adjusted the structure somewhat, let me know if you have some ideas for further improvement.

title: RE: RedLeo's Kbd Rig
post_content: Well RedLeo it is nice to see that someone other than Brian Eno actually uses FM synths!Well I just followed my very own advice and decided to get myself a Novation Ultranova.I am on a shopping vacation with my family on Houston and walked into a guitar center decided to get a sub 800 synth and 2 mogami cables (I only got two cables left working correctly from about the 10 I have had). I wanted a Tetra, but there was noneSince I could not resist buying something, I decided to look at all things. Microkorg was ruled out as I have an MS2000BR at home I rarely use. Then the microsampler was fun but sampling is not really my style. So all left was the Korg R3, Novation Ultranova, Alesis Ion and Alesis Miniak. I am going to transport it by plane, so the Ion was a little bit to big for me to fit in my luggage. Then I truly disliked the Miniak Interface. The R3's vocoder was superb while the Ultranova's disappointed. Then there is those ridiculous R3's mini pitch and modulation wheels and the displays are not all that clear to see. Ultranova is Blue and that fits with my non black keyboard rig, plus it has got a very nice interface and the display I found was very clear and easy to read. Then for other sounds I just could not appreciate them good enough and decide to go for the one i liked the most on demoes and that was the Ultranova. I mean, just check this one out:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bNov2RJu5nwDaniel Fisher from sweetwaterSo I do not have a laptop nor 1/4 inch plugs so I got to wait till I get home to actually play it (which is tonight in midnight). but so far it is very nice quality considering it is plastic, good interace and great keybed. My only gripe is that the knobs are wobly but they do not feel flimsy so I have mixed feelings in that regard.So that's my story, I will post it in another thread and put a review of it afterward comparing it to the nord stage and my mopho.

title: LOOSE CHANGE - International Touring soul band from Kent, UK
post_content: Since everyone else is posting their music, here's some of mine. This is my main touring group, an 8 piece soul oriented band with lots of Hammond and brass. We do about 70 gigs a year, mostly weddings and parties, and generally have a good time (you may notice this from watching the video).This is quite an old clip now that we used as a promo for getting gigs over the summer, when I was still using the Electro. The bottom keyboard is some cheap Yamaha thing I borrowed for this gig - it's got its own sound turned off here and wired to the Electro's lower manual MIDI input.I've got some newer videos with the Stage 2 that should be online as soon as I get a chance to edit and upload them.I normally go stage right, but had to be stuck at the back due to lack of space in the venue (otherwise I'd be hidden behind the right hand PA stack)[youtube][/youtube]If you like this, and happen to be in the area (we do play on the continent and Ireland as well as the UK), have a look at our pageswww.loosechange.co.ukand we're on Facebook underwww.facebook.com/loosechangeband

title: Actionfredag - Norwegian Prog Band
post_content: Hey,We (Actionfredag) are a relavtively new progrock band, based in Oslo, Norway. Our self produced music is a mixture of progressive metal,  progressive rock, jazz, avant-garde, blackjazz and melodic metal. We regard ourselves as influenced by major 70's prog/jazz bands, aswell as newer melodic metal and avant-garde bands.Actionfredag was founded early 2010, and we've been enjoying making and playing music since then. We recently recorded our very first single: "Universe Dat Ass".Our band currently consists of:DrumsGuitarBassSynthSaxophoneIn near future we'll get a violinist and another guitar.We recently released our brand new websitehttp://www.actionfredag.comWhile mainly being ment for our norwegian audience, people who do not speak norwegian should not have too hard a time navigating the site.On the website you can find music, pictures and videos.  Aswell as concert and event-information.For convenience you can also find us at:Facebook:http://www.facebook.com/pages/Actionfre ... 0991139077Twitter:http://twitter.com/#!/ActionfredagMyspace:http://www.myspace.com/actionfredagThanks for your time, and enjoy!We would be very thankful for any comments, and responses to both our music and our website.- ActionfredagPS: We currently have no content featuring the new Nord Stage 2, but hopefully we'll get some more recording done after the summer!

title: RE: re: Hello from Hanon_CTS
post_content: Thank you , Hanson. This is a great board for information and meeting new friends.My Hammond also has the Trek solid state pre-amp and reverb installed. I recently re-capped the CV delay line box and really leaned up the sound.  There is a 147 Leslie connected to it, also.The Stage 2 compact had its maiden voyage last nite and performed very well. I am so satisfied with the ability to adjust and make changes on the fly, the Nord is truly a live performance keyboard. It has "replaced the SV1, Electro 3 and the rack with a Fantom R.Ahh the Korg SV1. I truly do like the feel of the keys, and the sounds are quite nice , especially the Wurlitzer and the Acoustic Piano from the sound pack 2. It is also easy to adjust parameter .  It is heavy and its odd shape makes it difficult to grab and maneuver onto a stand. It was really a compromise, in a sense, replacing it with the Stage in that I don't have the weighted keys, but the weight factor and complexity of my stage gear was becoming a burden in my "old age" LOLI had ordered a stage 2 76  but the ship date was moved back , so I elected to go with the compact and got a years extra warranty on it

title: My Rig
post_content: Nord Stage 88 EXUltimate V Stand2x Yamaha FC7 Pedals1x Nord Sustain PedalRack with:MOTU 828 mk2Emagic Unitor 8 USBKorg Triton RackEmo Power distroBig XLR/Powercon/Midi/NeutrikUSB/NeutrikFW400 Patch Panel.1 big custom built loom with Audio, Midi, USB, Power - from keyboard to rackMacbook Pro with Mainstage, Omnisphere, Alicias Keys, Galaxy 2 Pianos, Scarbee Rhodes, and others.my monitor mix comes in on 2 xlrs on the patch, and mixes with a seperate keyboard bus so i can control my own ear mix. patch has 8 xlr outputs for running clicks, tracks etc and seperating keys outputs. one power lead into the rack distro, one big loom to the keybaords, I am up and running in 2 minutes - so much better than building a studio on stage like i used to do!

title: RE: A little improv
post_content: oh that yellow thing is not a mixer. It's a DSI Mopho:http://www.davesmithinstruments.com/products/mopho/But now that you mention it.... my Mackie 802-VLZ3 does somewhat fit on top of the nord stage!Its advertised as a 2 mono, 3 stereo input, put its actually got a secret stereo signal called ST Return which you cannot EQ, mute or change volume. A great little mixer, very much recommended, I saw some allen and heat zed mixers, but I decided for mackie due to the fact that I've heard and seen them more often and it just felt better ;D

title: RE: Yet another improvisation
post_content: Hi Gustavo,I always enjoy your playing, and you have great potential.Recording your improvisation is the first step toward trimming them down into motifs and assembling them into more diverse compositions.I congratulate your courage for posting your music for us all to enjoy.These thoughts from a musician at least 30 years your senior: Never lose the sense of enjoyment that you feel from playing music. Never forget the enjoyment that hearing your music brings to others.Above all, if you like it, so will others.

title: RE: Yet another improvisation
post_content: Thanks Hanon!I actually have realized this previously. I think I have about 200 hours of recordings, and I have trimmed them down to several motifs (just about 1 or 2 hours of motifs) and I have several ideas I actually think I can materialize into songs, even got some "bare bones" for very epic prog-rock songs. I record almost all of my personal practice sessions and afterwards just cut the notably practice part and leave those little improvisations for later. That´s how most of the stuff I posted came to be, just me messing with sounds or practicing when I happened to have the camera on.I actually have several pieces written and recorded but my biggest problem is doing lyrics. So I actually hesitate on posting those since they are very far from being complete. I got a sort of poprock piece with just a few words sung (which I wrote with a guitarist) and also a piano ballad which are just missing the lyrics. Since I just got into vacations and have 2 free weeks I will try to write them down and post them afterwards.I also got a very funky weird piece that is just the nord stage and drums, I will do it an instrumental and probably will post it today or tomorrow.My girlfriend is probably better than me at doing lyrics, so I will see if she helps me do some decent ones!The problem is that vacations are rarely totally free-time! I got a few days worth of work to do with my home´s network and I got to put up a server for my dad, that could take easily a few days. But whenever I get inspired I will make sure to go record somethings!!BTW I am 19 and started music in my 15s (my parents never got me to take lessons and I decided to go by myself), and its always nice to hear good things from people with more than 7 times my experience!!Best Regards,Gustavo

post_content: Check my myspace out if you feel like it.http://www.myspace.com/sebastianlundsgaardIt mostly features me just playing long (and maybe boring to some) piano improvisations on my Nord Stage Compact.But there is also some other tracks with more instruments and stuff.I play everything myself. title: RE: My Myspace
post_content: Nice music. ANd very varying. I like the Funky one, relaly grooves. And nice chords changes like in Discopop. However, I would add a bit more of bass so go along with the battery and support the piano. And the drums, you play them on the stage?? sounds tedious ;-) So what are you using, The Battery, Grooveagent,??? Maybe playing a groovemachine like the affordable AKAI XR20 would make it easier to record your drums.And nice sound radindrops, I like the gently layered synth. Well the style is very "chaloureux" meaning probably good to impress girls ;-) or to play after getting home at 3am, kinda chilly!But ingeneral nice chords and improvisation! keep it up - hyggelig!! J

title: RE: My Myspace
post_content: Johannes wrote:Nice music. ANd very varying. I like the Funky one, relaly grooves. And nice chords changes like in Discopop.Thanks alot for the kind words :) I really apreciate you taking the time to listen too all the tracks.Johannes wrote:However, I would add a bit more of bass so go along with the battery and support the piano.I'm sorry i'm not familiar with "the battery". Are you talking about adding bass on Discopop only, or on all the songs (e.g. the piano improvisations)? I agree that I should add bass to Discopop. Maybe playing a groovemachine like the affordable AKAI XR20 would make it easier to record your drums.Yeah I play the drums from software (IK Multimedia Sampletank 2.5) through midi on the Nord Stage. Well the style is very "chaloureux" meaning probably good to impress girls ;-) or to play after getting home at 3am, kinda chilly!But ingeneral nice chords and improvisation! keep it up - hyggelig!! J[/quote]Actually there is no gently layered synth. Just alot of long reverb. I experimented a little with the reverb and I think it sounded pretty nice for the song. It can be good to impress girls sometimes ;-) but I mostly play it for my own enjoyment. title: On the run sequence on the Nord Stage
post_content: Yep, all done using ONLY the Nord Stage´s synth section.here is the vid:What I did is using the lfo a cyclic manner, i could make it act as a pseudo-sequencer, which just makes the Nord stage a tad more flexible.Pros: you get a small, hand inputed sequenceCons: you must get it perfect, increasing tempo slightly destroys the melodies, decreasing tempo WILL destroy the sequence.Just for your leisure :P

title: RE: On the run sequence on the Nord Stage
post_content: KUDOS!!Now that is really a great usage of the (said to be limited) Synth engine of the Nord Stage!But how do you let the sequence go on and on (AEG Release=+infinity??) while playing the crazy lead lines at the end? Switching Panels??IMHO the problem with the LFO is that it is hard to change the speed while maintaining the shape of the form (triangle or Sawtooth) unchanged by turning both potis at the same pace.Anyway, would you mind putting the patch up here? Would love to try it out!!Great playing btw!!CheersJohannes

title: RE: On the run sequence on the Nord Stage
post_content: Yep, switching panels!! People say the Nord Stage´s synth is limited, I say they haven´t thought all sounds well ;PAhm.... Stupid me I did not save the patch, all done on the live stuff and then I got to play some Dream Theater stuff, so i overwrote the performance. But it was based on a patch I previously made, so I should not have much trouble recreating it. I will definitely put it up later on the day (my day still has about 17 hours left ;) )I also have more sounds that use the LFO to sound like a sequencer, although I am not the first one to think of doing something like this:http://www.sonicstate.com/articles/article.cfm?id=146Although I did stumbled upon the NS´s pseudo sequencer by "mistake" I put the lfo in the cyclic mode, attack on fastest, decay at about half, played a polyphonic phrase and found out that it repeated the phrase.BUT there is somehting I did not mention, I dunno if the video shows it, but doing what I did tends to leave a sort of noise level onthat patch and on other patches it sounded like you are holding a pad. Which makes it sound like two sounds at the same time but can be annoying if you only want the pseudo-sequenceSaludos,Gustavo

title: RE: On the run sequence on the Nord Stage

title: The Cohen Brothers
post_content: HiThought you might be interested in our music - we have a web site athttp://www.thecohenbrothers.co.uk- and myspacehttp://www.myspace.com/thecohenbrothersand facebookhttp://www.facebook.com/thecohenbrothers- and the latest album is streaming there - there is only one keyboard on the recordings - Stage EX Compact and it was played live.  The only overdubs were vocals & a little bit of acoustic guitar on 2 tracks - no keyboard overdub - just the Nord played once with the whole band playing live.  Protools was the recording environment.The band is guitar/bass/drums/percussion[Roland Handsonic] + me (voc & Stage)Most tracks just use one setting - with Rhodes 1 Mk1 Deep (bit of chorus 1 & autopanning) + Hammond + string patchThe Hammond was routed through outputs 3&4 & recorded on a separate pair of tracks [and processed independently] - piano & string routed through main outputsThe title track Moving On used an A/B combination (Steinway + Mk1) plus Hammond plus string - routing as aboveThe album was recorded at Woodwine St studios in Leamington UK -http://www.woodbinestreet.com/- by highly experienced engineer/producer John Rivers - who usually used soft pianos & a dusty B3 in a corner - it was his first experience of recording a Stage - although he has recorded for Ocean Colour Scene, Paul Weller & many others - i was the first in with the Nord ! .... he loved it - amazed by the quality of the pianos ..... just wait til he hears the new v5 samples when i go back in early 2011We have CD of the album for sale - just contact me via the forum.We have just put a Youtube channel uphttp://www.youtube.com/cohenbrothersBe good to have any feedback - all the bestJulian

title: 6 short live clips of my band featuring my Nord Stage
post_content: Hi folks!http://www.youtube.com/view_play_list?p ... DFBF419DD0Here are 1 short video and 5 audio-only recordings of my 7 piece band, playing soul/blues/jazz covers, which demonstrate the Nord Stage in a live situation. I'm using the Nord Stage exclusively on these tracks, playing acoustic piano (yamaha C7 studio grand 2, v3.0 version), rhodes and some organ too, and think especially the rhodes patches sound great!This is NOT a dedicatd live recording, we just recorded the 2 MAIN OUTs of the live mixer onto a minidisc, but fortunately it doesn't sound too bad :-)Best regards from Karlsruhe, Germany,Alex Nagel

title: EP made entirely on Stage 76 Classic
post_content: Hi All,Our entire EP was done on the Stage.  We're a 3-piece, singer, pianos/synths and live drums.  All the keys are the Stage, even the Grand.  I had a real C7 at my disposal, but we didn't have time to mic it and the engineer thought the Steinway samples did the trick!http://www.myspace.com/backlitsfYou can also download hi-resolution mp3's if you like the tunes

title: RE: EP made entirely on Stage 76 Classic
post_content: Hi,great music!! Interesting line-up just with the Piano, Drums and Vocals!I really like the E-Pianos, nice harmonies, cozy but not too simple, and layered synths/low organs, though not sure if you play all at once?? If not, how do you do it live?And great Jazz drums but most of all congrats for your singer, great voice!! And I really like the Triphop like harmonies sometimes a bit against the base harmonies which create a great and interesting ambience! Maybe I can see you in concert when I am in CA t some point!Keep it up!cheers, Johannes

title: RE: EP made entirely on Stage 76 Classic
post_content: Thank you, Johannes,For live shows, I'm playing the essential parts, which is usually a piano on one hand and a synthesizer on the other.  A few songs are all piano, low octaves and fifths can fill in for a bass in some cases.  Sometimes that synthesizer is a bass, other times an ambient line.  The over-dubs are also done on the stage 76, there were a few places that needed a bit more "oomph."  We're playing somewhat regularly in San Francisco, so if you make it to the West Coast give us a shout.bye.david

title: An improv tune
post_content: Hello there all, here is a small tune I made on the run, I came up with the small thing at the beginning and I decided to record it. Everything is played on real time and it is completely NS. I recorded it with my PC´s sound card E-MU 1212m.I will also attach the program I made for this one. The whole improv lasted about 20 mins, but that is too long and even boring to post, so I am just posting the most interesting part, which was the beginning. Again, it is all real time, no editing.I attached the program I used: here is a quick walkthrough:Panel A, simply a Grand with some synth strings, the volume of the syth strings is controlled via the controll pedal. On panel B there is a wurlie on the upper side with a synth bass on the left side. The fliter sweep on the synth bass is controlled also via the controll pedal.GusHere is the link to the tune:http://rapidshare.com/files/247443858/E ... v.ogg.html

title: My myspace - The Making of Gentlemen
post_content: http://www.myspace.com/makinggentlemenWe've been playing for about nine months and we will be playing our first gig tomorrow (yay!).It's a rock band, and I use aNord Stage 76 rev. B.I use the following samples:Studio Grand 2 - Yamaha C7 XL v. 4.2Svenska pianofabriken - Rain Pianoand also2 harpsichord samples,one regular and one lute stop.In addition I also haveE.Piano 2 Mk I SuitcaseYamaha CP80but mostly for fun. I haven't used them in a song yet.The piano sounds I use are a mix between the grand piano and the rain piano.I always mix in a bit of the rain piano to add a little edge.In the organ section I exclusively use the B3. I haven't really found a use forthe Vox and Farfisa, maybe some of you guys have any advice?One of the sounds I am most happy about is a mix between the B3 and therain piano. I will upload it as soon as i get a chance.I rarely use the synth, but I have downloaded a harmonium-patch from theyahoo group that I use in one song. I think that is the only synth patch I use.I'm planning on implementing the harpsichords very soon! Can't wait!I'm planning on adding asamplerof some kind to my rig,so that I can use some of the samples I have downloaded overthe years.
